description: The Lean and Agile Project Management Certification is a brand new certification to convey a knowledge from a combination of prexisting industry standards. Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose will walk you through this series to cover everything you need to know from beginning to end. You will also be able to access supplemental materials including the ebook from SSDGlobal.net (the same site where you can take the certification exam).  Don't delay because if you are able to certify within a few months from the exam release date you will obtain a lifetime certification not required to obtain Continued Education Credits.

episodes.description: The Lean and Agile Project Management Certification is a brand new certification to convey a knowledge from a combination of prexisting industry standards. Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose will walk you through this series to cover everything you need to know from beginning to end. You will also be able to access supplemental materials including the ebook from SSDGlobal.net (the same site where you can take the certification exam). Don't delay because if you are able to certify within a few months from the exam release date you will obtain a lifetime certification not required to obtain Continued Education Credits.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:06.940
[SOUND] Welcome to your Lean and
Agile Project Management series.

2
00:00:06.940 --> 00:00:13.020
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose and
this a really exciting new certification.

3
00:00:13.020 --> 00:00:17.640
So you guys might not have been
able to research ahead of time,

4
00:00:17.640 --> 00:00:21.080
so we have the expert,
the developer in house today.

5
00:00:21.080 --> 00:00:23.392
Her name is Dr. Tara.

6
00:00:23.392 --> 00:00:26.669
And she's gonna tell us a little
bit about where to take the exam,

7
00:00:26.669 --> 00:00:29.120
how to take the exam,
what to study for the exam.

8
00:00:29.120 --> 00:00:31.420
So thank you for being here today Doctor.

9
00:00:31.420 --> 00:00:32.610
>> Thank you Cherokee.

10
00:00:32.610 --> 00:00:33.695
>> What do we look at?

11
00:00:33.695 --> 00:00:36.380
We decide that we wanna work
in project management or

12
00:00:36.380 --> 00:00:39.350
maybe this is a requirement for
a company that I work for.

13
00:00:39.350 --> 00:00:41.010
So where do I begin?

14
00:00:41.010 --> 00:00:45.809
>> Well the new Lean and Agile Project
Management Certification right

15
00:00:45.809 --> 00:00:50.859
now is only offered through SSV Global,
and that's my company, but,

16
00:00:50.859 --> 00:00:55.677
over the next couple of months
it'll be offered by other entities.

17
00:00:55.677 --> 00:00:58.130
So that's the first thing
that you wanna keep in mind.

18
00:00:58.130 --> 00:01:02.930
It's based on the book Lean and
Agile Project Management.

19
00:01:02.930 --> 00:01:08.090
And the concept behind it is that there's
traditional project management that can be

20
00:01:08.090 --> 00:01:15.140
made better, faster, more cost effective
by using Lean and Agile tools.

21
00:01:15.140 --> 00:01:16.000
So that's the concept.

22
00:01:16.000 --> 00:01:19.060
So the very first thing
that we did is we leaned

23
00:01:19.060 --> 00:01:22.570
out the project management lifecycle.

24
00:01:22.570 --> 00:01:25.620
And we call it the project
lifecycle composite.

25
00:01:25.620 --> 00:01:28.730
So different bodies of
knowledge have different

26
00:01:28.730 --> 00:01:31.090
phases that are supposed to
be recognized in the model.

27
00:01:31.090 --> 00:01:32.770
We really linked that out.

28
00:01:32.770 --> 00:01:35.880
So even if you don't have
a background in project management,

29
00:01:35.880 --> 00:01:41.440
you can now look at a project and
manage it in a very structured way.

30
00:01:41.440 --> 00:01:46.090
However, within that structure, within
that framework, you can use lean and

31
00:01:46.090 --> 00:01:49.380
agile tools to make any project
that you're working on better,

32
00:01:49.380 --> 00:01:51.210
faster, more cost effective.

33
00:01:51.210 --> 00:01:54.290
What I think is really valuable
about this course is that

34
00:01:54.290 --> 00:01:58.730
if you're managing some household
projects as well, not just IT projects or

35
00:01:58.730 --> 00:02:00.800
projects for your company in general,

36
00:02:00.800 --> 00:02:06.940
you can use this kind of structure to
work through your personal life as well.

37
00:02:06.940 --> 00:02:10.930
So what you do for
this particular certification

38
00:02:10.930 --> 00:02:14.650
is that you would go to our
website at SSD global solutions,

39
00:02:14.650 --> 00:02:20.800
you would locate the ITProTV student link,
which is right on the home page.

40
00:02:20.800 --> 00:02:26.990
And there are some prerequisites that you
need to do in order to sit for the exam.

41
00:02:26.990 --> 00:02:29.690
One of the major prerequisites
would be satisfied

42
00:02:29.690 --> 00:02:33.550
by watching this series because
that's the educational requirement.

43
00:02:33.550 --> 00:02:36.230
So you would sign an affidavit
that you did, in fact,

44
00:02:36.230 --> 00:02:38.520
watch all of the shows in the series.

45
00:02:38.520 --> 00:02:41.790
But there are some reading assignments
with some questions and answers.

46
00:02:41.790 --> 00:02:44.380
We do require that you submit a project.

47
00:02:44.380 --> 00:02:46.290
However, we give you the template.

48
00:02:46.290 --> 00:02:51.100
We want you to submit a project using
the new PLC, the Project Life Cycle.

49
00:02:51.100 --> 00:02:53.410
You can rework an old project.

50
00:02:53.410 --> 00:02:57.190
If you don't have a project, we have
hundreds of projects available that you

51
00:02:57.190 --> 00:03:01.160
can work on that are actually real
projects, so that kinda makes it more fun.

52
00:03:01.160 --> 00:03:02.761
And then you sit for the exam.

53
00:03:02.761 --> 00:03:08.661
Once you pass the exam,
you are considered LAPM level one.

54
00:03:08.661 --> 00:03:11.369
There's only going to be
two levels to the LAPM,

55
00:03:11.369 --> 00:03:14.352
there's a lot of interest
in the industry right now.

56
00:03:14.352 --> 00:03:16.430
So you would be on the cutting edge.

57
00:03:16.430 --> 00:03:21.436
And I think one of the sort of the
advantages for ITProTV students is that,

58
00:03:21.436 --> 00:03:26.683
if you come in and take the test within
the next few months, there really are no

59
00:03:26.683 --> 00:03:31.887
continuing education things that you
have to do to keep the certification.

60
00:03:31.887 --> 00:03:34.538
The certification is your
certification for life.

61
00:03:34.538 --> 00:03:39.225
That will be changing as well because
since the continuing education

62
00:03:39.225 --> 00:03:43.200
credits haven't really been
completely developed yet.

63
00:03:44.240 --> 00:03:47.200
As people are taking the test before that,
they'll be grandfathered.

64
00:03:47.200 --> 00:03:48.684
So, I think that's kinda fun.

65
00:03:48.684 --> 00:03:51.643
Although, I know everyone out
there will want to learn anyway.

66
00:03:51.643 --> 00:03:56.390
So if you end up taking the test and still
have to do those continuing education

67
00:03:56.390 --> 00:04:00.445
credits, I think that they're
gonna be valuable to the craft.

68
00:04:00.445 --> 00:04:02.385
>> I know,
I hope I can find some time to do this.

69
00:04:02.385 --> 00:04:06.289
I just have a couple other certifications
that I'm looking at as well but

70
00:04:06.289 --> 00:04:09.809
having a certification that you
don't have to re-certify every

71
00:04:09.809 --> 00:04:11.799
few years is a really great concept.

72
00:04:11.799 --> 00:04:12.898
>> Yeah, exactly and

73
00:04:12.898 --> 00:04:17.890
I think really the take away from this is
that as we move forward in this universe.

74
00:04:17.890 --> 00:04:22.040
People are starting to realize that we can
kind of piece meal things together and

75
00:04:22.040 --> 00:04:23.870
just take the best of the best.

76
00:04:23.870 --> 00:04:26.550
So being able to make my project better,
faster, and

77
00:04:26.550 --> 00:04:29.050
more cost effective by using lean and

78
00:04:29.050 --> 00:04:33.150
agile tools to do that, I'm touching
all these different methodologies.

79
00:04:33.150 --> 00:04:38.660
And I think what the LAPM Level one
exam buys you on your resume is

80
00:04:38.660 --> 00:04:42.420
that if you go into an environment where
there's been mergers and acquisitions and

81
00:04:42.420 --> 00:04:45.610
everyone's kind of working on their own
thing, it's a way that you can say,

82
00:04:45.610 --> 00:04:48.120
you know what,
I'm familiar with all these methodologies.

83
00:04:48.120 --> 00:04:50.990
And maybe I'm not an expert but I get it.

84
00:04:50.990 --> 00:04:53.090
And as an IT professional,

85
00:04:53.090 --> 00:04:55.620
I think I could work at this company
no matter what you're working on.

86
00:04:56.970 --> 00:04:58.490
>> So what should we bo looking at,

87
00:04:58.490 --> 00:05:02.050
or what are we going to be looking at
as we continue through this series?

88
00:05:02.050 --> 00:05:05.454
>> Well the first thing that we'll
talk about is how to get certified,

89
00:05:05.454 --> 00:05:07.792
which we've kind of
covered in this segment.

90
00:05:07.792 --> 00:05:11.894
But the big thing that we're gonna focus
on is that right now there are three

91
00:05:11.894 --> 00:05:14.890
bodies of traditional project management.

92
00:05:14.890 --> 00:05:16.460
And so it used to be really easy,

93
00:05:16.460 --> 00:05:19.370
there used to be one that everyone
was pretty much following.

94
00:05:19.370 --> 00:05:22.340
But now there's kind of
a few different spins.

95
00:05:22.340 --> 00:05:25.250
So we took all that information, and

96
00:05:25.250 --> 00:05:29.330
we condensed it into our version
of the project lifecycle.

97
00:05:29.330 --> 00:05:31.070
And we're saying, you know what?

98
00:05:31.070 --> 00:05:33.800
In four phases you can
hit all the high points.

99
00:05:33.800 --> 00:05:37.880
So we're gonna spend a lot of time
talking about the actual model to

100
00:05:37.880 --> 00:05:41.560
use if you wanna make your projects
better, faster and more cost effective.

101
00:05:41.560 --> 00:05:43.980
And then of course we're
gonna cover lean and

102
00:05:43.980 --> 00:05:47.410
agile tools that play into
each one of those phases.

103
00:05:47.410 --> 00:05:51.290
So for example the first phase
of our model is selection, so

104
00:05:51.290 --> 00:05:53.090
we have all kinds of selection tools.

105
00:05:53.090 --> 00:05:56.200
How do I know I've selected
the right project?

106
00:05:56.200 --> 00:05:58.740
How do I get by in that type of thing?

107
00:05:58.740 --> 00:06:03.764
And then when we move to planning,
we remind you of the traditional project

108
00:06:03.764 --> 00:06:08.568
management tools because that might
be the environment that you go in.

109
00:06:08.568 --> 00:06:12.510
But then we talk to you about how
lean in and agile plans project so

110
00:06:12.510 --> 00:06:16.410
that you have more tools
than your tool chest, right?

111
00:06:16.410 --> 00:06:20.826
And then we go to the third phase
of the model which is execution and

112
00:06:20.826 --> 00:06:22.762
we give you tips and tricks.

113
00:06:22.762 --> 00:06:27.303
And then, of course, on the student page,
there's other handouts that will kind of

114
00:06:27.303 --> 00:06:31.290
get you thinking, how can I execute
this project in a seamless way?

115
00:06:31.290 --> 00:06:35.965
And then finally in closing,
we talk about some things such as the 5S

116
00:06:35.965 --> 00:06:40.720
Model which is really a Lean Six Sigma
Model that agile people are using

117
00:06:40.720 --> 00:06:43.640
that helps us keep physically organized.

118
00:06:43.640 --> 00:06:46.889
>> Well I don't know about you, but
I'm really excited to go ahead and

119
00:06:46.889 --> 00:06:48.380
learn this brand new content.

120
00:06:48.380 --> 00:06:51.610
And the way that it's been packaged for
this brand new certification.

121
00:06:51.610 --> 00:06:53.770
So let's go ahead and get started.

122
00:06:53.770 --> 00:06:58.440
If you plan on learning our Lean and
Agile project management, stay tuned.

123
00:06:58.440 --> 00:07:00.910
We have some really great
information headed your way.

124
00:07:00.910 --> 00:07:02.220
See you.

125
00:07:02.220 --> 00:07:05.644
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose discuss how the Lean and Agile Project Management certification process works and what you should be focusing on to study for the exam.
episodes.title: Introduction
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:02.976
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.976 --> 00:00:06.374
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.374 --> 00:00:08.318
>> [MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.318 --> 00:00:12.077
>> Your watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:12.077 --> 00:00:16.242
>> Welcome too Lean and
Agile Project Management Theories.

6
00:00:16.242 --> 00:00:18.660
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:18.660 --> 00:00:22.834
And I can't even begin to tell you how
excited I am to be here in the studios

8
00:00:22.834 --> 00:00:27.010
today because we're gonna be
looking at brand new certification.

9
00:00:27.010 --> 00:00:28.520
And literally hot off the press.

10
00:00:28.520 --> 00:00:32.090
So I'll have Doctor Terra Vanzant Stern
tell you all about it,

11
00:00:32.090 --> 00:00:34.280
because well, she's the expert.

12
00:00:34.280 --> 00:00:36.260
So thank you for
being with us today, doctor.

13
00:00:36.260 --> 00:00:38.550
>> Thank you Cherokee, and again,

14
00:00:38.550 --> 00:00:43.740
I'm excited too because many people have
been talking about how we could blend

15
00:00:43.740 --> 00:00:48.140
Lean and Agile into project management for
about a decade.

16
00:00:48.140 --> 00:00:52.050
And we've had some attempts where
we've had Lean Project Management,

17
00:00:52.050 --> 00:00:56.090
Agile Project Management, and in fact,
you may have taken some courses in there.

18
00:00:56.090 --> 00:00:58.790
However, my company, SSD Global Solutions,

19
00:00:58.790 --> 00:01:03.050
is the first to publish Lean &
Agile Project Management together.

20
00:01:04.300 --> 00:01:07.140
So I am very very excited.

21
00:01:07.140 --> 00:01:08.210
>> Well congratulations.

22
00:01:08.210 --> 00:01:09.050
That's great news.

23
00:01:09.050 --> 00:01:10.290
>> Thank you.

24
00:01:10.290 --> 00:01:13.310
Now in the Lean &
Agile Project Management,

25
00:01:13.310 --> 00:01:16.550
the objectives are that
we wanna introduce you.

26
00:01:16.550 --> 00:01:21.263
I mean the real objective is we wanna
show you how you can use Lean & Agile

27
00:01:21.263 --> 00:01:25.740
tools to make your projects better,
faster and more cost effective.

28
00:01:25.740 --> 00:01:31.490
The other thing that we want to do
is we want to explain the LAPM exam.

29
00:01:31.490 --> 00:01:35.725
So the LAPM exam, sorry,

30
00:01:35.725 --> 00:01:40.950
is only now available
through SSD Global Solutions

31
00:01:40.950 --> 00:01:45.160
because we created the exam and
we have the base core material.

32
00:01:45.160 --> 00:01:47.600
So we will be the industry standard.

33
00:01:47.600 --> 00:01:51.720
In another year or two there will be other
companies that you can take it from.

34
00:01:51.720 --> 00:01:55.240
Now the advantage is that if you
do take it in the next year or

35
00:01:55.240 --> 00:02:00.300
so, there's not going to be any
CEUs that you have to do to keep up

36
00:02:00.300 --> 00:02:03.880
that certification like you would normally
do in most certification programs.

37
00:02:03.880 --> 00:02:06.530
>> Great.
So technically you'd essentially be

38
00:02:06.530 --> 00:02:07.500
grandfathered in.

39
00:02:07.500 --> 00:02:08.580
>> Absolutely.

40
00:02:08.580 --> 00:02:11.180
So you'd be grandfathered
into the program.

41
00:02:11.180 --> 00:02:17.050
And you would also be on the cutting edge
of those people that say they're Level I.

42
00:02:17.050 --> 00:02:21.330
The LAPM right now were only going
to have a Level I and a Level II.

43
00:02:21.330 --> 00:02:24.530
So, those of you that
are interested in Level I,

44
00:02:24.530 --> 00:02:27.840
there is a Level II to go to if you
decide that you wanna continue.

45
00:02:27.840 --> 00:02:29.690
>> Great.
>> But right now it will just be

46
00:02:29.690 --> 00:02:31.460
the LAPM Level I Exam.

47
00:02:32.800 --> 00:02:38.230
Now the whole purpose of Lean & Agile
Project Management, as I said before,

48
00:02:38.230 --> 00:02:43.230
is to teach you how to make a project
better, faster, and more cost effective.

49
00:02:43.230 --> 00:02:47.740
In the past this has been something
that's been dedicated to process

50
00:02:47.740 --> 00:02:49.150
improvement projects.

51
00:02:49.150 --> 00:02:53.020
The difference between a project and
a process improvement project,

52
00:02:53.020 --> 00:02:55.495
is that a project you pretty much
know what you're going to do.

53
00:02:55.495 --> 00:02:58.200
You know the beginning and
end, you know the problem,

54
00:02:58.200 --> 00:03:02.250
you know the solution, you may even
have a project plan available.

55
00:03:02.250 --> 00:03:06.723
And how the project process
improvement tools can help you is

56
00:03:06.723 --> 00:03:11.510
you can kind of streamline some
of those things that you're

57
00:03:11.510 --> 00:03:15.590
doing in a project right now by
capitalizing on process improvement tools.

58
00:03:15.590 --> 00:03:20.430
So a process improvement project
usually you know the problem,

59
00:03:20.430 --> 00:03:21.710
but you don't know the solution.

60
00:03:21.710 --> 00:03:24.670
So there's a whole bevy of
critical thinking skills

61
00:03:24.670 --> 00:03:28.980
that we have figured out how to apply
to just regular project management.

62
00:03:28.980 --> 00:03:30.240
>> Well great, let's go ahead and

63
00:03:30.240 --> 00:03:33.470
get started with all this
new brand new information.

64
00:03:33.470 --> 00:03:35.920
I'm super excited and I hope you are too.

65
00:03:35.920 --> 00:03:38.930
But for this particular episode,
we'll go ahead and wrap up, and

66
00:03:38.930 --> 00:03:42.470
I'll sign off as your show host,
Cherokee Boose.

67
00:03:42.470 --> 00:03:46.320
>> And this is Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

68
00:03:46.320 --> 00:03:49.164
>> See you next time here at ITProTV

69
00:03:49.164 --> 00:03:55.476
[MUSIC]

70
00:03:55.476 --> 00:03:58.813
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Cherokee Boose and Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern begin to discuss concepts that are supported by PM-BOK®, Prince 2 ®, and ISO 21500. Specifically, you learn what a Work Breakdown Structure is and how significant it is to your project.
episodes.title: Session 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.066 --> 00:00:06.741
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.741 --> 00:00:08.249
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.249 --> 00:00:12.082
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.082 --> 00:00:16.720
>> Welcome to your Lean and
Agile Project Management series.

5
00:00:16.720 --> 00:00:19.630
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:19.630 --> 00:00:22.970
Here in session 1, we're gonna talk
about well, where to begin and

7
00:00:22.970 --> 00:00:26.700
how to get started for
this brand new certification learning.

8
00:00:26.700 --> 00:00:28.460
So, in studio today, we have Dr.

9
00:00:28.460 --> 00:00:31.560
Tara Vansant Stern, thank you for
joining us today, doctor.

10
00:00:31.560 --> 00:00:35.350
>> Thank you for having me Cherokee,
this is a very exciting program.

11
00:00:35.350 --> 00:00:36.990
>> So where are we gonna begin?

12
00:00:36.990 --> 00:00:39.810
>> Well I think what I
wanna do is I want to go

13
00:00:39.810 --> 00:00:43.880
over a little bit about the certification,
cuz it's still so new.

14
00:00:43.880 --> 00:00:44.820
>> Okay.

15
00:00:44.820 --> 00:00:48.863
>> So this certification,
as I said, is a new exam.

16
00:00:48.863 --> 00:00:53.245
And the idea is if you take
all of the ITProTV courses and

17
00:00:53.245 --> 00:00:58.780
want to be certified, you can go to
the SSD Global website to do that.

18
00:00:58.780 --> 00:01:03.206
Right now, we're the only ones that
are offering that level one exam.

19

00:14:50.050 --> 00:14:51.710

00:14:55.410 --> 00:14:57.780

00:14:57.780 --> 00:15:02.330

255
00:15:02.330 --> 00:15:07.740

00:15:07.740 --> 00:15:09.030

257
00:15:09.030 --> 00:15:11.450

could be a milestone.

258
00:15:11.450 --> 00:15:16.490
The fact that sometimes it could be

259
00:15:16.490 --> 00:15:19.020

260
00:15:19.020 --> 00:15:23.220
A deliverable, on the other hand,
is anything I promise the client.

261
00:15:23.220 --> 00:15:25.950
So I might have promised
them a status report.

262
00:15:25.950 --> 00:15:31.125
I might have promised them a what

263
00:15:31.125 --> 00:15:32.792
A status report.

264
00:15:32.792 --> 00:15:33.502
>> A meeting?

265
00:15:33.502 --> 00:15:34.425
>> A meeting.

266
00:15:34.425 --> 00:15:37.505
So any of those types of
things are deliverables right?

267
00:15:37.505 --> 00:15:42.105
So anything I give, anything told you
that I'm going to give is a deliverable.

268
00:15:42.105 --> 00:15:44.085
And then another interesting thing, and

00:15:44.085 --> 00:15:47.905

A lot of software,

00:18:56.010 --> 00:19:01.030
So if I were looking at my WBS, what I

00:19:01.030 --> 00:19:04.480
is that each one of those categories,

each one of those categories,

what I'm gonna do is, I'm going to

Now, when I'm completely done creating my

I can add up all my costs, and I will have

this is how much that office

And the reason it gets trickier is that
there's some things that are gonna

So for example,
if I'm waiting on a signature for

Would that make sense?

00:19:45.980 --> 00:19:47.010
>> Yes.
>> So-

the entire project for
something like that.

00:19:50.740 --> 00:19:52.160
Any kind of delay there.

>> Exactly, so
if I did time in a linear fashion,

349
00:19:55.350 --> 00:19:59.020
my office party might take
me two years just to do.

00:19:59.020 --> 00:20:00.920
So, it get's a little tricky.

00:20:00.920 --> 00:20:03.560
So, cost I could just add up.

00:20:03.560 --> 00:20:07.960
And, time, I just want to see what

I also might want to consider what needs

00:20:11.850 --> 00:20:14.120
I might want to look at my dependencies,

355
00:20:15.140 --> 00:20:17.380
>> So
now let's go back to our office party,

356
00:20:17.380 --> 00:20:19.990
and you'll see we've kind

357
00:20:19.990 --> 00:20:21.020
>> Assigned roles.

358

359
00:20:22.480 --> 00:20:27.290
And we have Don, and Dr. Stern, and

00:20:27.290 --> 00:20:30.350
And we've also assigned cost and time.

361
00:20:30.350 --> 00:20:36.360
So, once again, leaner project management,
where project management and all

362
00:20:36.360 --> 00:20:41.790
three of those bodies of knowledge talk
about work breakdown structure, right?

363
00:20:41.790 --> 00:20:43.887
They're talking about
those first two columns.

364
00:20:43.887 --> 00:20:48.739
When you're taking lean and agile
project management, we say you know as

00:20:48.739 --> 00:20:54.280
long as you have to learn this stuff,
why not add those other components in?

366
00:20:54.280 --> 00:20:58.124
Those other three columns technically
aren't part of the work breakdown

367
00:20:58.124 --> 00:21:02.095
structure but that's what we use to
determine our cost and our timeline so,

368
00:21:06.171 --> 00:21:11.830
Now when we're talking about baseline,
it becomes very, very tricky.

369
00:21:11.830 --> 00:21:14.940
Because once I've established my cost and

00:21:14.940 --> 00:21:18.900
my timeline,
that's what I'm judged on forever, okay?

371
00:21:18.900 --> 00:21:23.930
And, the sad thing is that sometimes, even

372
00:21:25.290 --> 00:21:28.770
we shouldn't even be doing that project,
sometimes we get into situations where

00:21:28.770 --> 00:21:32.310
we're still just graded on

374
00:21:32.310 --> 00:21:35.410
Did it cost what I say it was gonna cost,
right?

375
00:21:35.410 --> 00:21:41.390
So the objective, obviously,
is to hit that baseline.

376
00:21:41.390 --> 00:21:45.470
If I go a little over the baseline,

377
00:21:45.470 --> 00:21:49.005
>> [LAUGH] You might get in a little
bit of trouble depending how far you

378
00:21:49.005 --> 00:21:52.055
were from your budget there,
and the timeline also.

00:21:52.055 --> 00:21:54.645
>> And what if I go way over my baseline?

00:21:54.645 --> 00:21:58.875
>> Well, you might be overlapping another
project to getting the company behind you,

381
00:21:58.875 --> 00:22:00.770
may even be terminated.

382
00:22:00.770 --> 00:22:02.105
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly, so,

383
00:22:02.105 --> 00:22:05.970
if I come a little below baseline,
usually they're happy.

384
00:22:05.970 --> 00:22:10.270
So if I'm on baseline or a little below
people are like rah, rah, sis, boom,

385
00:22:10.270 --> 00:22:11.760
ba you did a great job.

386
00:22:11.760 --> 00:22:15.310
If I go way below baseline
that could be a problem too.

387
00:22:15.310 --> 00:22:19.920
Can you think of some problems that there
might be with going way below my baseline?

388
00:22:19.920 --> 00:22:22.510
>> It might raise a red flag
as if you weren't experienced,

389
00:22:22.510 --> 00:22:26.120
you weren't able to
efficiently estimate or

390
00:22:26.120 --> 00:22:30.950
perhaps you decreased quality in an area
that they really didn't want to,

391
00:22:30.950 --> 00:22:34.360
if you were creating some kind of product,
or service, or something like that?

392
00:22:34.360 --> 00:22:37.010
>> Right, and sometimes if I get things,
me personally,

393
00:22:37.010 --> 00:22:40.400
if I get things too quickly I'm thinking,
what did they not give me?

394
00:22:40.400 --> 00:22:41.685
>> Or what did I miss.

395
00:22:41.685 --> 00:22:44.150
[LAUGH]
>> Or what did I forget, right exactly.

396
00:22:44.150 --> 00:22:49.040
So this thing about, and it's a really
big deal when you're studying traditional

397
00:22:49.040 --> 00:22:53.120
project management, no matter which
of those three bodies of knowledge.

398
00:22:53.120 --> 00:22:59.100
A lot of training, a lot of work on how
to estimate your time and your cost line.

399
00:22:59.100 --> 00:23:02.790
But if you do it using the work
breakdown structure, it's leaner and

400
00:23:02.790 --> 00:23:04.430
faster and easier.

401
00:23:04.430 --> 00:23:09.119
Now another way that you can use the work
breakdown structure to help you is when

402
00:23:09.119 --> 00:23:11.409
your boss gives you the project to do.

403
00:23:11.409 --> 00:23:15.597
They just coming and they say this is how
long is gonna take, I'm gonna have you

404
00:23:15.597 --> 00:23:19.276
do this project and this is how much
money I'm gonna budget for you and

405
00:23:19.276 --> 00:23:24.460
this is how long, I need it in two weeks I
am gonna give you $10,000 to do it, right?

406
00:23:24.460 --> 00:23:27.270
They're gonna give you
some sort of parameters.

407
00:23:27.270 --> 00:23:31.850
If you immediately go back to your desk
and just first list, like your one, two,

408
00:23:31.850 --> 00:23:33.150
three, four, five list.

409
00:23:33.150 --> 00:23:36.240
You say these are all the things
that need to happen right.

410
00:23:36.240 --> 00:23:37.770
And then maybe you're gonna order them,

411
00:23:37.770 --> 00:23:40.720
like at first you might not
think of sequential order.

412
00:23:40.720 --> 00:23:44.080
So I'm just gonna write down everything
that has to happen in this project.

413
00:23:44.080 --> 00:23:47.850
And then probably step two what I'm
gonna do is I'm gonna go back and

414
00:23:47.850 --> 00:23:49.890
I'm gonna try to put them
in some sort of order.

415
00:23:49.890 --> 00:23:52.630
Like this should happen
before that happens, right?

416
00:23:52.630 --> 00:23:54.370
Then I'll go and break them down.

417
00:23:54.370 --> 00:23:58.520
Like okay on number one task
there's a 1.1, there's a 1.2, 1.3.

418
00:23:58.520 --> 00:24:03.262
Then I'll take those extra steps
that we saw in our diagram here,

419
00:24:03.262 --> 00:24:06.900
and I'll say cost and
time and resource, right.

420
00:24:06.900 --> 00:24:11.671
And then I'll just kind of step back and
say, what did I come up with?

421
00:24:11.671 --> 00:24:16.231
So let's say my boss said,
we're gonna budget $10,000 for

422
00:24:16.231 --> 00:24:19.355
this project and I came up with 10,500.

423
00:24:19.355 --> 00:24:22.633
I'm probably gonna go back through
my work breakdown structure and

424
00:24:22.633 --> 00:24:24.240
see what can I tweak up.

425
00:24:24.240 --> 00:24:28.050
Because it's just a little over what
they're telling me I can spend, right?

426
00:24:28.050 --> 00:24:31.402
However, if I go through
that entire project and

427
00:24:31.402 --> 00:24:34.526
I come up with twice that, $20,000.

428
00:24:34.526 --> 00:24:37.800
Now what I can do is,
I am not saying no to my boss.

429
00:24:37.800 --> 00:24:40.930
I'm going back in with my work
breakdown structure and I'm saying,

430
00:24:40.930 --> 00:24:45.360
when I did my estimate,
this is everything I came up with.

431
00:24:45.360 --> 00:24:49.372
Here, what I'd like you to do is tell
me what you want me to take out.

432
00:24:49.372 --> 00:24:54.662
So, and there is that small percentage
of bosses who are unreasonable and

433
00:24:54.662 --> 00:24:55.779
kind of crazy.

434
00:24:55.779 --> 00:24:59.703
But for the most part, if you take this
document to your boss and you show them,

435
00:24:59.703 --> 00:25:03.038
these are the things, because they
might not have thought it out.

436
00:25:03.038 --> 00:25:05.890
>> [CROSSTALK] Sure, it's something
tangible and they're able to look at it

437
00:25:05.890 --> 00:25:09.069
and say, you know what, maybe I wasn't
being realistic with this expectation.

438
00:25:09.069 --> 00:25:11.480
>> Exactly, and the same thing with time.

439
00:25:11.480 --> 00:25:15.020
So your boss says, this thing
has to be done on Monday, right?

440
00:25:15.020 --> 00:25:17.990
So in this case I'm looking
at the time column and

441
00:25:17.990 --> 00:25:23.750
I'm looking at each one of those things
and I'm saying, how long is it gonna take,

442
00:25:23.750 --> 00:25:27.680
and I'm looking, if I don't know,
like history, remember, trumps anything.

443
00:25:27.680 --> 00:25:31.560
So if I know the cost of something,
that's what I'm gonna put down.

444
00:25:31.560 --> 00:25:35.010
But what I'm gonna tell you with
time will also work with cost.

445
00:25:35.010 --> 00:25:39.170
So if I've done this task before and
I know how long it's gonna take,

446
00:25:39.170 --> 00:25:40.600
I can just put that down.

447
00:25:40.600 --> 00:25:43.720
But if I don't know,
what I could do is I could say, well,

448
00:25:43.720 --> 00:25:46.420
what was the longest time
it ever took me to do it?

449
00:25:46.420 --> 00:25:48.090
What was the shortest time?

450
00:25:48.090 --> 00:25:50.050
And I'm gonna use my hands here.

451
00:25:50.050 --> 00:25:53.980
Some of you may have seen this in our Lean
Six Sigma program, that I use my hands.

452
00:25:53.980 --> 00:25:56.500
Okay, so
what was the longest time it took me?

453
00:25:56.500 --> 00:25:58.630
What was the shortest time it took me?

454
00:25:58.630 --> 00:26:00.890
And what does it normally take me?

455
00:26:00.890 --> 00:26:02.980
And I'm gonna give that four counts.

456
00:26:02.980 --> 00:26:03.980
So I have six.

457
00:26:03.980 --> 00:26:11.160
I have longest time, shortest time and
four times most likely, right?

458
00:26:11.160 --> 00:26:13.200
So I'm going to add that all together.

459
00:26:13.200 --> 00:26:16.840
I'm gonna add the lowest and highest time.

460
00:26:16.840 --> 00:26:19.740
And then I'm going to go four
times the most likely time and

461
00:26:19.740 --> 00:26:21.700
divide that by six, right?

462
00:26:21.700 --> 00:26:24.190
And so now I have a time estimate.

463
00:26:24.190 --> 00:26:25.424
Remember, history trumps everything.

464
00:26:25.424 --> 00:26:27.510
You can do that with cost as well.

465
00:26:27.510 --> 00:26:28.900
So let's say I'm going through,

466
00:26:28.900 --> 00:26:32.830
my boss says, I have to have this
project on my desk by Monday.

467
00:26:32.830 --> 00:26:36.585
It's still, even though I'm in a panic
now cuz I've gotta work as fast as I can.

468
00:26:36.585 --> 00:26:41.260
If I sit down and
I work on my timeline and I come up with

469
00:26:41.260 --> 00:26:45.160
twice the amount of time, I'm probably
gonna do the same thing I did with cost.

470
00:26:45.160 --> 00:26:48.000
I'm gonna go in and
I'm gonna say here's all the things,

471
00:26:48.000 --> 00:26:51.740
I did this work breakdown structure,
it's simple to understand, simple outline.

472
00:26:51.740 --> 00:26:55.800
Here's all the things that need to
happen to facilitate this request,

473
00:26:55.800 --> 00:26:57.530
which one would you take out?

474
00:26:57.530 --> 00:26:59.970
And consequently,
just like we said with cost,

475
00:26:59.970 --> 00:27:05.860
if they say it has to be done by Monday,
and let's say I have 40 work

476
00:27:05.860 --> 00:27:10.250
hours left to do that, and it turns out
it's gonna take 43 work hours, well yeah.

477
00:27:10.250 --> 00:27:11.440
I'm gonna stay a little late.

478
00:27:11.440 --> 00:27:13.460
I'm gonna find someone that can help me.

479
00:27:13.460 --> 00:27:14.690
I'm gonna tweak it up.

480
00:27:14.690 --> 00:27:20.290
But a lot of times,
people ask us to do unrealistic things and

481
00:27:20.290 --> 00:27:22.450
that's not lean or agile.

482
00:27:22.450 --> 00:27:24.116
If we've been given a task, and

483
00:27:24.116 --> 00:27:28.377
that's an unfair cost or timeline, one of
the beautiful things is that we can fall

484
00:27:28.377 --> 00:27:31.053
back on this beautiful
work breakdown structure.

485
00:27:33.693 --> 00:27:36.270
>> So looks like we're
getting close on time here.

486
00:27:36.270 --> 00:27:37.986
If you don't have any
other final thoughts,

487
00:27:37.986 --> 00:27:39.985
is this a good place where
we can go ahead and wrap up?

488
00:27:39.985 --> 00:27:41.310
>> I think so, Cherokee.

489
00:27:41.310 --> 00:27:46.830
I think work breakdown structure
is probably the most magical tool

490
00:27:46.830 --> 00:27:51.840
in the traditional project management
toolbox that's out there, seriously.

491
00:27:51.840 --> 00:27:53.190
So getting used to doing that, and

492
00:27:53.190 --> 00:27:56.700
even in your daily strategy,
it's a good time management tool.

493
00:27:56.700 --> 00:28:01.259
If you wake up in the morning and you feel
terribly overwhelmed, we have some other

494
00:28:01.259 --> 00:28:05.377
time management tools we'll introduce
you to but this is a good fast one.

495
00:28:05.377 --> 00:28:09.560
Just write down everything you need
to do and kind of segment it out.

496
00:28:09.560 --> 00:28:13.530
>> Perfect, well, I think that does
about wrap it up for session one, but

497
00:28:13.530 --> 00:28:16.574
don't go anywhere,
we have some really great Lean and

498
00:28:16.574 --> 00:28:20.569
Agile project management information
headed your way in session two.

499
00:28:20.569 --> 00:28:24.368
For this episode, we'll go ahead and
sign out, and I'm your show host,

500
00:28:24.368 --> 00:28:25.303
Cherokee Boose.

501
00:28:25.303 --> 00:28:29.582
>> And I'm Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern
from SSD Global Solutions.

502
00:28:29.582 --> 00:28:31.795
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

503
00:28:33.435 --> 00:28:39.212
[MUSIC]

504
00:28:39.212 --> 00:28:42.811
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: This episode is a continuation of the discussion between Cherokee Boose and Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern where they examine tools agreed upon industry defactos. Specifically, you will observe the 7 tools of quality, flowchart symbols, PDCA model and charts/graphs.
episodes.title: Session 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:03.502
Welcome to ITProTV,

2
00:00:03.502 --> 00:00:08.232
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:08.232 --> 00:00:12.065
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:12.065 --> 00:00:16.500
>> Welcome to your Lean and
Agile Project Management series.

5
00:00:16.500 --> 00:00:18.150
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:19.360 --> 00:00:23.020
We're gonna go ahead and begin with
session number two, in session one we

7
00:00:23.020 --> 00:00:27.320
ended talking about WBS work breakdown
structure, and we're gonna go ahead and

8
00:00:27.320 --> 00:00:32.100
I believe we'll pick up there but we have
Doctor Terra Vanzant-Stern in studios

9
00:00:32.100 --> 00:00:33.660
today to go ahead and
help us with these topics.

10
00:00:33.660 --> 00:00:35.230
Thank you for joining us today.

11
00:00:35.230 --> 00:00:37.338
>> Thank you for having me, Cherokee.

12
00:00:37.338 --> 00:00:39.520
>> So, is that a safe place
to go ahead and pick up or?

13
00:00:39.520 --> 00:00:40.610
>> Yeah.
Absolutely.

14
00:00:40.610 --> 00:00:42.270
>> All right.
>> Let's go ahead and get started.

15
00:00:43.360 --> 00:00:48.630
If we can go to my slide deck,
the last thing that we were in session two

16
00:00:50.500 --> 00:00:55.630
and this is just a reminder
of the book and one of

17
00:00:55.630 --> 00:01:00.300
the things that we talked about in session
one that everyone agrees in all those

18
00:01:00.300 --> 00:01:05.760
different project management bodies of
knowledge that we need a project plan.

19
00:01:05.760 --> 00:01:09.440
So another thing that everyone is
concerned about is something called

20
00:01:09.440 --> 00:01:11.360
project scope.

21
00:01:11.360 --> 00:01:15.260
And we always kind of look at
this from the opposite direction.

22
00:01:15.260 --> 00:01:17.730
Why is scope creep such a big deal?

23
00:01:17.730 --> 00:01:21.130
So I'm gonna take us back to
our office party example,

24
00:01:21.130 --> 00:01:24.380
and we're gonna look at
project scope in this example.

25
00:01:24.380 --> 00:01:28.670
So the idea is if I were looking,
and this is, I think,

26
00:01:28.670 --> 00:01:32.850
was the second page of our project plan,

27
00:01:32.850 --> 00:01:37.430
let's say someone came in and
asked me to do something extra.

28
00:01:38.650 --> 00:01:41.490
I've already done my time and baseline.

29
00:01:41.490 --> 00:01:44.780
And if you'll remember from session
one that means I've already told you

30
00:01:44.780 --> 00:01:48.520
how long it's gonna take and how much it's
gonna cost for me to do that project.

31
00:01:48.520 --> 00:01:51.757
So, if you come in and give me one
more task, what's gonna happen?

32
00:01:52.890 --> 00:01:55.070
>> It'll probably add,
depending on what the task is,

33
00:01:55.070 --> 00:01:57.150
if there's a monetary
value attached to it.

34
00:01:57.150 --> 00:02:01.570
Like if I asked you to have a photo booth
so we could take photos at the party or

35
00:02:01.570 --> 00:02:04.190
something like that,
you would need to pay that vendor and

36
00:02:04.190 --> 00:02:06.870
you would take extra time to schedule and

37
00:02:06.870 --> 00:02:09.940
maybe do a little bit of research to
see which vendor you wanted to choose.

38
00:02:09.940 --> 00:02:11.430
So time and money.

39
00:02:11.430 --> 00:02:15.010
>> Exactly, it could push that time and
money line out.

40
00:02:15.010 --> 00:02:18.590
And so that's why people are so concerned
about something called project scope.

41
00:02:19.600 --> 00:02:23.230
Project scope is sometimes
an overcomplicated idea

42
00:02:24.570 --> 00:02:27.340
when all you're really saying
is this is what I'm gonna do.

43
00:02:27.340 --> 00:02:33.610
So, I am planning the office party but
I'm planning the office party for

44
00:02:33.610 --> 00:02:37.920
this month but I'm not planning
the office party fro the next few months.

45
00:02:37.920 --> 00:02:40.620
I'm just sticking to this one thing.

46
00:02:40.620 --> 00:02:42.490
So, something to kind of keep in mind.

47
00:02:42.490 --> 00:02:45.850
Project scope is a very important concept.

48
00:02:45.850 --> 00:02:48.070
What is it that exactly I'm gonna do?

49
00:02:48.070 --> 00:02:51.570
And you almost have to think
of it from the opposite side

50
00:02:51.570 --> 00:02:55.200
of what I'm not gonna do,
to make it really make sense.

51
00:02:55.200 --> 00:02:56.230
>> Define that, sure.

52
00:02:56.230 --> 00:03:00.460
>> Exactly, so another thing that all
the project bodies acknowledge, and

53
00:03:00.460 --> 00:03:04.090
remember we said there's the PMBOK,
there's the PRINCE2.

54
00:03:04.090 --> 00:03:06.280
There's also a new ISO standard.

55
00:03:06.280 --> 00:03:10.300
It's been out for a few years, but
it's much newer than the other two,

56
00:03:10.300 --> 00:03:13.775
so it's still being referred
to as the new ISO standard.

57
00:03:13.775 --> 00:03:17.360
All believe in the seven
analytical problem solving tools.

58
00:03:17.360 --> 00:03:21.110
Now each body of knowledge does call
them something slightly different, but

59
00:03:21.110 --> 00:03:23.450
we're gonna quickly look at those tools.

60
00:03:23.450 --> 00:03:28.270
If you want a more in depth conversation
on these tools you can go back and

61
00:03:28.270 --> 00:03:33.190
look at the Lean Six Sigma Yellow Belt
class and locate where we're

62
00:03:33.190 --> 00:03:37.430
talking about those tools because we go
way into depth in that particular session.

63
00:03:37.430 --> 00:03:38.430
>> Yes, I remember that.

64
00:03:38.430 --> 00:03:42.200
>> Okay, so these are the seven quality
tools that are sometimes called

65
00:03:42.200 --> 00:03:43.550
the critical thinking tools,

66
00:03:43.550 --> 00:03:46.890
which are sometimes called
the seven tools of data analysis.

67
00:03:46.890 --> 00:03:49.710
And we're just gonna briefly
look at each one of these.

68
00:03:49.710 --> 00:03:54.590
So the first one, this is the chocolate
making process and this is a flow chart.

69
00:03:54.590 --> 00:03:59.000
And you'll notice on this particular flow
chart we don't have a lot of symbols.

70
00:03:59.000 --> 00:04:03.630
There are some standard flow charting
symbols but mostly in project

71
00:04:03.630 --> 00:04:08.149
management you're looking at the decision
symbols, and the start and stop symbols.

72
00:04:09.720 --> 00:04:13.560
These are the ones that are the most
common symbols that are used.

73
00:04:13.560 --> 00:04:17.560
As a project manager, if you use these
symbols you're usually going to be okay.

74
00:04:19.230 --> 00:04:22.890
There are additional symbols when you're
looking internationally that mean

75
00:04:22.890 --> 00:04:23.550
other things.

76
00:04:23.550 --> 00:04:26.410
But everyone pretty much
agrees on these symbols.

77
00:04:26.410 --> 00:04:31.460
And they're intuitive, I just want
to quickly go over a couple of them.

78
00:04:31.460 --> 00:04:35.160
Transportation and transmission,

79
00:04:35.160 --> 00:04:38.840
the difference between transportation
is that it's any physical movement, and

80
00:04:38.840 --> 00:04:43.730
transition is any movement through
the computer, any electronic movement.

81
00:04:43.730 --> 00:04:47.408
Do you see any others there,
Cherokee, that need some explanation?

82
00:04:47.408 --> 00:04:50.380
>> Maybe that input/output.

83
00:04:50.380 --> 00:04:51.970
What would be the difference there?

84
00:04:51.970 --> 00:04:55.090
>> Okay, so
everything that goes into the system,

85
00:04:55.090 --> 00:04:56.910
everything that goes out of the system.

86
00:04:56.910 --> 00:04:58.300
And that's a really good question,

87
00:04:58.300 --> 00:05:01.820
because inputs in different literature
are referred to different things.

88
00:05:01.820 --> 00:05:07.620
So primarily in lean and even in agile
environments, your inputs are your xs.

89
00:05:07.620 --> 00:05:11.070
Those are the core things that
are going into the process.

90
00:05:11.070 --> 00:05:13.190
And your outputs are your ys.

91
00:05:13.190 --> 00:05:16.700
So a large Y would mean your major output.

92
00:05:16.700 --> 00:05:20.310
A small y would be maybe
some smaller outputs.

93
00:05:20.310 --> 00:05:22.320
And the same things with xs and ys.

94
00:05:22.320 --> 00:05:26.870
So anything that goes into the process,
anything that goes out of the process.

95
00:05:26.870 --> 00:05:30.470
When you're doing a typical flow chart for
project management,

96
00:05:30.470 --> 00:05:33.860
you're gonna have some major outputs.

97
00:05:33.860 --> 00:05:37.100
>> Yeah, thank you, and the only other
one that I could see that maybe poses

98
00:05:37.100 --> 00:05:38.760
a question would be next to operation.

99
00:05:38.760 --> 00:05:40.060
You have two symbols.

100
00:05:40.060 --> 00:05:41.970
Does that just mean that
either one can be used?

101
00:05:41.970 --> 00:05:45.840
>> Yes, it means that either one
>> The circle or the square.

102
00:05:45.840 --> 00:05:48.330
In the US we have a tendency
to use the square.

103
00:05:48.330 --> 00:05:51.060
In other countries a lot of
times they use the circle.

104
00:05:51.060 --> 00:05:51.560
>> Okay, great.

105
00:05:53.260 --> 00:05:58.160
>> So, the next one we're gonna look at is
we're gonna look at a fishbone diagram.

106
00:05:58.160 --> 00:06:02.790
And in a fishbone diagram we put in
the head of the fish, the problem, right?

107
00:06:02.790 --> 00:06:04.035
>> Sure, no one likes bad coffee.

108
00:06:04.035 --> 00:06:05.380
[LAUGH]
>> This is the one we're gonna fit,

109
00:06:05.380 --> 00:06:08.540
we're gonna put bad coffee
in the head of the fish.

110
00:06:08.540 --> 00:06:13.360
Then the major contributors to the fish
are the major factors you think,

111
00:06:13.360 --> 00:06:14.810
the big bones.

112
00:06:14.810 --> 00:06:17.720
The ones right now that say personnel,
method, material, and

113
00:06:17.720 --> 00:06:19.560
equipment, those bones.

114
00:06:19.560 --> 00:06:22.390
Those are the major things
that play into the problem.

115
00:06:22.390 --> 00:06:25.920
You can use a naming convention,
such as the three Ps,

116
00:06:25.920 --> 00:06:30.440
which is people, process, product/service.

117
00:06:30.440 --> 00:06:33.840
You can use the six Ms which
is there's a series of those

118
00:06:33.840 --> 00:06:35.620
that will be in your student package.

119
00:06:35.620 --> 00:06:39.600
But, machines, mankind, mother nature.

120
00:06:39.600 --> 00:06:41.070
It has to get kinda clever.

121
00:06:41.070 --> 00:06:42.940
Or you can just your own.

122
00:06:42.940 --> 00:06:47.970
The theory behind the fish bonechart,
is the further out I get with those bones,

123
00:06:47.970 --> 00:06:51.580
the more likely I'm going
to identify the root cause.

124
00:06:51.580 --> 00:06:56.370
So, for example,
if we were looking at beans quality,

125
00:06:56.370 --> 00:07:01.380
what are some things Cherokee that you
think might play into beans quality?

126
00:07:02.640 --> 00:07:07.860
>> Age, perhaps the geographical region,
from where they were harvested.

127
00:07:07.860 --> 00:07:10.930
Maybe how they're being stored.

128
00:07:10.930 --> 00:07:15.550
>> Right, and so the theory behind the
fishbone diagram is the further we get it

129
00:07:15.550 --> 00:07:19.280
out there, the more likely we
are to identify the root cause.

130
00:07:21.470 --> 00:07:23.570
So the next of the seven.

131
00:07:23.570 --> 00:07:26.010
So far we've looked at a flow chart.

132
00:07:26.010 --> 00:07:28.040
We've looked at a fishbone diagram.

133
00:07:28.040 --> 00:07:30.550
The next one we're looking
at is a check sheet.

134
00:07:30.550 --> 00:07:34.430
This one's always near and dear to my
heart, because back in the day, one of

135
00:07:34.430 --> 00:07:39.580
the very first jobs I had was at Lolly
Lowell School of Secretarial Science,

136
00:07:39.580 --> 00:07:43.210
where we taught our girls to smarkle,
that's half smile and half sparkle.

137
00:07:43.210 --> 00:07:44.505
I love telling that story.

138
00:07:44.505 --> 00:07:46.442
>> [LAUGH]
>> Across the hall from me,

139
00:07:46.442 --> 00:07:49.354
I had a teacher who actually
graded typing tests And

140
00:07:49.354 --> 00:07:51.669
she had something that looked similar.

141
00:07:51.669 --> 00:07:53.826
So every time I see this,
I have to kind of smile.

142
00:07:53.826 --> 00:07:55.122
>> [LAUGH] Smarkle.

143
00:07:55.122 --> 00:07:56.163
>> Smarkle.

144
00:07:56.163 --> 00:08:00.729
[LAUGH] So the next one that we're
gonna talk about is the histogram, and

145
00:08:00.729 --> 00:08:05.450
I usually like to talk about
histograms and Pareto charts together.

146
00:08:05.450 --> 00:08:08.330
So remember there's seven
tools that all the bodies of

147
00:08:08.330 --> 00:08:12.600
knowledge say these are the most important
analytical problem solving tools.

148
00:08:12.600 --> 00:08:15.940
These tools are called different
things in different environments.

149
00:08:15.940 --> 00:08:19.690
We have a tendency in Lean to
call them the quality tools, but

150
00:08:19.690 --> 00:08:24.060
these are analytical problem solving
tools and the next is a histogram.

151
00:08:24.060 --> 00:08:29.650
Now usually a histogram tracks
the history of a particular event.

152
00:08:29.650 --> 00:08:32.490
So maybe I'm tracking the history
of how many phone calls we get.

153
00:08:34.380 --> 00:08:39.660
But a histogram can also be used
to determine normal distribution,

154
00:08:39.660 --> 00:08:44.140
determine distribution models,
when we see something that looks like

155
00:08:44.140 --> 00:08:48.200
a bell if we're recording
a particular process.

156
00:08:48.200 --> 00:08:50.580
If we see something that looks
like a bell then we say that,

157
00:08:50.580 --> 00:08:53.390
that process has normal distribution.

158
00:08:53.390 --> 00:08:56.160
And so sometimes that's what
people use histograms for.

159
00:08:56.160 --> 00:09:00.965
Now you'll be happy to know that on
the student on the ITProTV student page,

160
00:09:00.965 --> 00:09:03.833
there's templates for all of these things.

161
00:09:03.833 --> 00:09:04.428
>> That's amazing.

162
00:09:04.428 --> 00:09:05.265
>> Yes.

163
00:09:05.265 --> 00:09:09.819
And so here's an example of the Histogram
where it's just collecting buckets

164
00:09:09.819 --> 00:09:11.400
of information.

165
00:09:11.400 --> 00:09:15.010
And on this thing it's
looking at final test scores.

166
00:09:15.010 --> 00:09:17.800
And so it's saying there's
a certain percentage of people.

167
00:09:17.800 --> 00:09:22.750
A certain number of students rather that
made between 80 and 100 on the exam.

168
00:09:22.750 --> 00:09:26.450
But it looks like a lot of students
maade between 60 and 80 on this exam.

169
00:09:26.450 --> 00:09:29.650
>> Yeah, and
the little red all the way to the left.

170
00:09:29.650 --> 00:09:31.970
Maybe those are the scores
that we can have dropped,

171
00:09:31.970 --> 00:09:34.420
the class overall can have a better score.

172
00:09:34.420 --> 00:09:35.430
>> Absolutely.

173
00:09:36.910 --> 00:09:40.590
Now here's An example of
another type of histogram and

174
00:09:40.590 --> 00:09:41.950
it's putting things in buckets.

175
00:09:41.950 --> 00:09:45.350
So it's looking at a typical garage sale,
right?

176
00:09:45.350 --> 00:09:48.020
And so, if I look at this garage sale,
I might say,

177
00:09:48.020 --> 00:09:52.740
let's say I'm doing a community garage
sale and I'm taking it over from

178
00:09:52.740 --> 00:09:56.780
the people that have been doing it once
a year for like the last few years.

179
00:09:56.780 --> 00:10:01.581
So, I might collect all of my information
and say how many items in the $1

180
00:10:01.581 --> 00:10:06.440
to $5 price range was
sold all the way through.

181
00:10:06.440 --> 00:10:10.151
And what this is telling me
is that because on the side,

182
00:10:10.151 --> 00:10:15.100
that x axis is,
could be representing 100, 200, 300.

183
00:10:15.100 --> 00:10:19.790
So we're looking at 800 items
that were sold between 1 and $5,

184
00:10:19.790 --> 00:10:22.510
so I might wanna start including those.

185
00:10:22.510 --> 00:10:24.070
If I look over to the 26 to $30,

186
00:10:24.070 --> 00:10:28.980
right, then that might be where
I made the most money, right?

187
00:10:28.980 --> 00:10:31.970
And you see in this case,

188
00:10:31.970 --> 00:10:35.310
the bars are touching because
they can be touching or separate.

189
00:10:35.310 --> 00:10:38.767
If they're touching it's
kind of accommodating for

190
00:10:38.767 --> 00:10:41.312
that 510, 515, 550 right?

191
00:10:41.312 --> 00:10:42.976
If it falls a little closer to that bar.

192
00:10:42.976 --> 00:10:43.645
>> In between.

193
00:10:43.645 --> 00:10:44.145
>> RIght.

194

421
00:23:36.281 --> 00:23:40.042
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV

422
00:23:40.042 --> 00:23:45.798
[MUSIC]

423
00:23:45.798 --> 00:23:49.738
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose converse upon the phases of the DMAIC model. DMAIC stands for the five phases Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve and Control. You will learn tasks and tools relating to each phase of this model.
episodes.title: Session 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.468
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.468 --> 00:00:03.750
I'm your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:03.750 --> 00:00:05.020
>> Live from San Francisco-

4
00:00:05.020 --> 00:00:08.425
>> [CROSSTALK]

5
00:00:08.425 --> 00:00:12.154
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.154 --> 00:00:16.430
>> Welcome to your Lean and
Agile Project Management series.

7
00:00:16.430 --> 00:00:18.860
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:18.860 --> 00:00:22.540
In the previous episode,
we looked at our seven tools of quality.

9
00:00:22.540 --> 00:00:27.840
And we also started with different models,
and we looked at the PDCA model.

10
00:00:27.840 --> 00:00:30.870
In this episode,
we're gonna further explore those models.

11
00:00:30.870 --> 00:00:34.010
And with us to go ahead and
conceptualize those ideas,

12
00:00:34.010 --> 00:00:36.820
we have Doctor Terra Vanzant-Stern
in studios.

13
00:00:36.820 --> 00:00:38.320
Thank you for joining us today, doctor.

14
00:00:38.320 --> 00:00:39.390
>> Thank you.

15
00:00:39.390 --> 00:00:43.390
>> So we left with PVCA and I think
we'll go ahead and start with DOMAIC.

16
00:00:43.390 --> 00:00:44.140
How does that sound?

17
00:00:44.140 --> 00:00:44.970
>> That sounds great.

18
00:00:44.970 --> 00:00:49.820
And I just wanna remind everyone that
the reason we're looking at these model

19
00:00:49.820 --> 00:00:54.770
is that in order to apply Lean and
Agile principles to

20
00:00:54.770 --> 00:00:58.830
traditional project management,
you have to kinda understand those tools.

21
00:00:58.830 --> 00:01:02.130
And we looked at those seven quality
tools as Cherokee mentioned.

22
00:01:02.130 --> 00:01:05.810
But you also need to be familiar
with the various models.

23
00:01:05.810 --> 00:01:11.720
The model we're going to look at next is a
Six Sigma and also a Lean Six Sigma model.

24
00:01:11.720 --> 00:01:13.720
Even though this program is called Lean,

25
00:01:13.720 --> 00:01:18.790
in Agile project management, it really
is Lean Six Sigma and Agile management.

26
00:01:18.790 --> 00:01:24.149
It was just leaner to say Lean and
Agile project management.

27
00:01:24.149 --> 00:01:27.484
With that in mind,
this is just a reminder of the book,

28
00:01:27.484 --> 00:01:29.669
Lean & Agile Project Management.

29
00:01:29.669 --> 00:01:34.905
And I wanted to side by side show
you we look at the PDCA model and

30
00:01:34.905 --> 00:01:38.450
now we're gonna look at the DMAIC model.

31
00:01:38.450 --> 00:01:43.170
Now the DMAIC model typically is
used to do process improvement.

32
00:01:43.170 --> 00:01:46.120
However, a lot of times
as a project manager,

33
00:01:46.120 --> 00:01:48.460
you're gonna bump up against this model.

34
00:01:48.460 --> 00:01:53.830
Also, even though we talk about this
model in context of a full blown model,

35
00:01:53.830 --> 00:01:56.560
what I'd like you to think
of as a project manager

36
00:01:56.560 --> 00:01:59.690
is that as you start having issues and
problems,

37
00:01:59.690 --> 00:02:05.210
you can actually use DMAIC as a thinking
process as a critical thinking tool.

38
00:02:05.210 --> 00:02:07.620
So if you go through
these different phases.

39
00:02:07.620 --> 00:02:11.490
If you're interested in more in depth
knowledge of each one of these phases,

40
00:02:11.490 --> 00:02:16.160
that is captured in our
Lean Six Sigma green belt program.

41
00:02:16.160 --> 00:02:21.261
>> Yes.
>> So first explain.

42
00:02:21.261 --> 00:02:26.340
D means define, M is for
measure, A, analyze, I for

43
00:02:26.340 --> 00:02:30.860
improve, although the slide says
implement, and C for control.

44
00:02:30.860 --> 00:02:35.240
So define means just what it says,

45
00:02:35.240 --> 00:02:38.340
I'm gonna make sure I'm
working on the right problem.

46
00:02:38.340 --> 00:02:43.570
Measurement or measure means that
I'm gonna get clearer as is picture.

47
00:02:43.570 --> 00:02:48.030
Analyze means I'm gonna go back and
see why that picture looks that way.

48
00:02:48.030 --> 00:02:52.090
And although our slide says implement,
it should say improve.

49
00:02:52.090 --> 00:02:56.760
In improve, a myriad of activities would
happen if I were using it as a process

50
00:02:56.760 --> 00:02:57.950
improvement model.

51
00:02:57.950 --> 00:02:59.220
This is where I get buy in,

52
00:02:59.220 --> 00:03:03.220
this is where I form my project plan
in a work break down structure.

53
00:03:03.220 --> 00:03:08.570
I'd stay and improve until I felt like
there was an improvement made and then

54
00:03:08.570 --> 00:03:14.210
I would move into control and in control
I would articulate those improvements and

55
00:03:14.210 --> 00:03:19.560
then I would give you a plan for
sustainability.

56
00:03:19.560 --> 00:03:21.620
So if we're looking at the first model.

57
00:03:21.620 --> 00:03:26.410
The DMAIC method is a problem solving
model used within the Six Sigma or

58
00:03:26.410 --> 00:03:28.600
Lean Six Sigma strategy.

59
00:03:28.600 --> 00:03:31.730
And it's used to help reduce variation.

60
00:03:31.730 --> 00:03:35.320
There's a thought in Six Sigma,
that if I identify and

61
00:03:35.320 --> 00:03:39.400
start reducing variation I may have
an automatic process improvement.

62
00:03:39.400 --> 00:03:42.870
I would like to point out that in all
process improvement environments,

63
00:03:42.870 --> 00:03:46.870
something that you wanna remember is that
at some point it does become a project.

64
00:03:46.870 --> 00:03:52.087
So even process improvement people,
at some point become project managers.

65
00:03:57.068 --> 00:04:00.280
As mentioned,
the DMAIC follows these 5 steps.

66
00:04:00.280 --> 00:04:02.740
Define, measure, analyze,
improve and control.

67
00:04:02.740 --> 00:04:06.610
And I'm happy to say that the slide says
the right thing this time, Cherokee.

68
00:04:06.610 --> 00:04:09.940
>> Yes.
And like Dr. Stern had mentioned,

69
00:04:09.940 --> 00:04:14.260
if you have any question about
a specific phase, individually,

70
00:04:14.260 --> 00:04:19.070
well we covered them in great depth in
that green belt certification series,

71
00:04:19.070 --> 00:04:21.350
so jump on over and
check those out as well.

72
00:04:21.350 --> 00:04:25.430
>> Right, and so in Define,
there's a number of tools that we'll

73
00:04:25.430 --> 00:04:29.830
be talking about that that you can use
in Lean and Agile project management.

74
00:04:29.830 --> 00:04:31.690
But I'm gonna briefly go over and

75
00:04:31.690 --> 00:04:36.050
define the voice of the customer
is really a big deal.

76
00:04:36.050 --> 00:04:39.610
Okay so,
what the customer thinks is a big deal.

77
00:04:39.610 --> 00:04:44.180
Critical to quality means
what is critical to success,

78
00:04:44.180 --> 00:04:45.990
you can use that as your project too.

79
00:04:45.990 --> 00:04:48.890
What is gonna make this
project successful?

80
00:04:48.890 --> 00:04:53.240
And sometimes when we're thinking about
critical to quality, we're just thinking

81
00:04:53.240 --> 00:04:56.910
about ourselves, and we're thinking
whats critical to quality to me.

82
00:04:56.910 --> 00:04:58.130
But as a project manager,

83
00:04:58.130 --> 00:05:02.050
you wanna think about what is critical to
quality some of those other people right.

84
00:05:02.050 --> 00:05:03.630
>> Sure, getting different perspectives.

85
00:05:03.630 --> 00:05:04.660
>> Exactly.

86
00:05:04.660 --> 00:05:09.580
Now also what happens in define is when
you come up with the project charter.

87
00:05:09.580 --> 00:05:12.980
The project charter in
traditional project management.

88
00:05:12.980 --> 00:05:15.740
And in define are very, very similar.

89
00:05:15.740 --> 00:05:19.960
However, there are some tools in in define
that might make your project charter

90
00:05:19.960 --> 00:05:21.500
a little bit more robust.

91
00:05:22.730 --> 00:05:27.090
SIPOC Mapping means that I'm
going to look at the suppliers,

92
00:05:27.090 --> 00:05:31.070
the input, the process,
the output and, the control.

93
00:05:31.070 --> 00:05:34.560
And I'm gonna see what people and
things are associated with that.

94
00:05:34.560 --> 00:05:39.800
So again, SIPOC is a tool that's
typically used in Define.

95
00:05:39.800 --> 00:05:42.906
But if you have a project and
you're trying to figure out who

96
00:05:42.906 --> 00:05:47.310
are the major stakeholders, it's a tool
that you can use as a project manager.

97
00:05:47.310 --> 00:05:49.000
It's not typically used.

98
00:05:49.000 --> 00:05:52.760
Value stream mapping is
a very interesting process.

99
00:05:52.760 --> 00:05:55.540
When you do a process map,
which, as project managers,

100
00:05:55.540 --> 00:05:56.950
we're pretty familiar with.

101
00:05:56.950 --> 00:05:59.850
Plus, it's one of the seven
analytical problem solving tools.

102
00:06:01.320 --> 00:06:02.930
In those environments,

103
00:06:02.930 --> 00:06:07.450
in a process mapping environment,
I'm trying to collect every single piece

104
00:06:07.450 --> 00:06:12.580
of information that I need to see
what's going on in that process.

105
00:06:12.580 --> 00:06:16.550
Sometimes as a project manager,
I end up with the process map because I've

106
00:06:16.550 --> 00:06:21.690
done the project and now I wanna show you
the steps that I took to do the project.

107
00:06:21.690 --> 00:06:25.400
And so sometimes the In the define model,

108
00:06:25.400 --> 00:06:29.270
the process map happens first, because
I don't know how to solve the problem.

109
00:06:29.270 --> 00:06:33.020
In project management, a lot of times
that it comes after the fact, but

110
00:06:33.020 --> 00:06:36.990
the difference between that and a value
stream map is on the value stream map,

111
00:06:36.990 --> 00:06:43.460
I'm only collecting the actual things that
are essential for that process to work.

112
00:06:43.460 --> 00:06:46.440
As a project manager,
why that might be important,

113
00:06:46.440 --> 00:06:51.430
is I may have a project
within a very large process.

114
00:06:51.430 --> 00:06:56.160
So if I'm trying to determine
what's going on around my project,

115
00:06:56.160 --> 00:06:59.830
doing a value stream map
might be incredibly helpful.

116
00:06:59.830 --> 00:07:01.680
>> So this is a little bit
of a random question, but

117
00:07:01.680 --> 00:07:04.690
I wanted to throw it out there, because
before we had started this series or

118
00:07:04.690 --> 00:07:09.440
earlier today, we were kind of talking
about making this exam a little leaner.

119
00:07:09.440 --> 00:07:12.610
And looking at some of these
terms like that acronym SIPOC,

120
00:07:12.610 --> 00:07:17.440
we serve Suppliers, Input,
Process, Output, and Customers.

121
00:07:17.440 --> 00:07:20.350
And then our VOC for
Voices of Our Customers.

122
00:07:20.350 --> 00:07:23.540
For these acronyms, is that still
something that's really relevant and

123
00:07:23.540 --> 00:07:25.640
important for
this particular certification?

124
00:07:25.640 --> 00:07:27.580
We need to know those.

125
00:07:27.580 --> 00:07:28.350
>> Absolutely,

126
00:07:28.350 --> 00:07:32.446
I think that you need to know the core
tools in each one of the models.

127
00:07:32.446 --> 00:07:37.810
All of the models can go like

128
00:07:38.900 --> 00:07:43.470
into infinity almost, so you can take
each phase, even of the PDCA model.

129
00:07:43.470 --> 00:07:47.260
Which is a much more simpler model than
the one we're looking at right now.

130
00:07:47.260 --> 00:07:49.500
And you can kind of take
them into infinity.

131
00:07:49.500 --> 00:07:52.820
So what this program is gonna show you
is the key ones that you need to know.

132
00:07:52.820 --> 00:07:53.970
>> Perfect.

133
00:07:53.970 --> 00:07:55.084
>> The ones that you can use.

134
00:07:55.084 --> 00:07:58.780
Now the cool thing about this is that some
of the tools, even though in the DMAIC

135
00:07:58.780 --> 00:08:02.151
that I'm introducing them these
are in Define, these are in Measure.

136
00:08:02.151 --> 00:08:05.176
They can be used throughout the model and
independently.

137
00:08:05.176 --> 00:08:09.683
So as a project manager if you decide to
take something through the DMAIC model,

138
00:08:09.683 --> 00:08:13.047
maybe you're unclear,
maybe you've changed your mind or

139
00:08:13.047 --> 00:08:17.060
your unclear about the direction
you want to take your project in.

140
00:08:17.060 --> 00:08:20.830
Kinda keep in mind even though we're
using these tools to the specific model,

141
00:08:20.830 --> 00:08:21.990
you can use them independently.

142
00:08:21.990 --> 00:08:22.790
>> Pretty flexible.

143
00:08:22.790 --> 00:08:23.290
>> Yeah.

144
00:08:24.928 --> 00:08:29.550
So then we move to measure, that's
the second phase of the DMAIC model.

145
00:08:29.550 --> 00:08:34.520
So we could have been exposed to
an environment that's using PDCA.

146
00:08:34.520 --> 00:08:39.270
We could as project managers be exposed
to an environment that's using the DMAIC.

147
00:08:39.270 --> 00:08:42.270
The second phase in
the DMAIC model is measure.

148
00:08:42.270 --> 00:08:46.371
Now one of the other things that you
wanna remember about the DMAIC model

149
00:08:46.371 --> 00:08:51.013
as a project manager is that you could be
doing a project in any one of these steps,

150
00:08:51.013 --> 00:08:55.270
define, measure, analyze, improve and
control within those phases.

151
00:08:55.270 --> 00:09:00.300
So the infrastructure might be
recognizing the DMAIC model.

152
00:09:00.300 --> 00:09:03.430
You may be just doing
a project within that.

153
00:09:03.430 --> 00:09:07.910
Especially if you're on a Six Sigma
project, which is typically very large.

154
00:09:07.910 --> 00:09:10.790
In the Lean Six Sigma projects
a lot of times you're

155
00:09:10.790 --> 00:09:12.800
moving from these phases fairly quickly.

156
00:09:12.800 --> 00:09:13.460
>> Rapid rates.

157
00:09:13.460 --> 00:09:15.600
>> Right, but in a Six Sigma project,

158
00:09:15.600 --> 00:09:17.720
where they're working
with millions of dollars.

159
00:09:17.720 --> 00:09:22.100
>> Especially with government's entities,
it could be yeah, span a decade or so.

160
00:09:22.100 --> 00:09:27.080
>> So within measure of the DMAIC model,
you might have a number of projects.

161
00:09:27.080 --> 00:09:32.070
So in measure, what, typically what
you're trying to do is get a clear as

162
00:09:32.070 --> 00:09:37.310
is picture to where you are today and
sometimes that take a lot of research.

163
00:09:37.310 --> 00:09:41.270
One way you can kind of figure out,
get a kind of a temperature

164
00:09:41.270 --> 00:09:45.480
is if you did CTQs and
customer requirements are always CTQs.

165
00:09:45.480 --> 00:09:48.590
But we said just in our earlier phase

166
00:09:48.590 --> 00:09:53.590
CTQs are also anything that would make
you successful or would be satisfiers.

167
00:09:53.590 --> 00:09:56.660
So if you're trying to get
a really quick idea of clear or

168
00:09:56.660 --> 00:09:59.540
as is state, you could just say,
well, how are we doing on those

169
00:09:59.540 --> 00:10:04.690
customer requirements on a scale from
one to ten, or one to five even?

170
00:10:04.690 --> 00:10:08.640
A lot of times what you're doing in
measure is you're just working through

171
00:10:08.640 --> 00:10:11.630
trying to pick out what is
the appropriate measure?

172
00:10:11.630 --> 00:10:12.920
How should I measure that?

173
00:10:12.920 --> 00:10:16.560
And a very poplar tool
is just observation.

174
00:10:16.560 --> 00:10:17.580
>> Yeah.

175
00:10:17.580 --> 00:10:21.660
>> So the other thing that I'm doing, and
this part I think gets very confusing for

176
00:10:21.660 --> 00:10:26.040
project managers,
is I'm trying to gain baseline data.

177
00:10:26.040 --> 00:10:28.960
And I'm gonna establish
a baseline performance and

178
00:10:28.960 --> 00:10:31.170
those terms are still used.

179
00:10:31.170 --> 00:10:36.050
As a project manager, remember baseline,
in this case, can mean a benchmark,

180
00:10:36.050 --> 00:10:39.680
or a standard, or I'm just trying
to get some foundation information.

181
00:10:39.680 --> 00:10:44.510
But baseline on a project plan,
as mentioned in an earlier session.

182
00:10:44.510 --> 00:10:49.120
Baseline on a project plan is how long is
gonna take, and how much is it gonna cost?

183
00:10:49.120 --> 00:10:50.790
So even as a project manager,

184
00:10:50.790 --> 00:10:55.430
when you're presenting your baseline a lot
of times I think you have to spell it out.

185
00:10:55.430 --> 00:10:59.860
I'm saying how long it's gonna take,
how much it's gonna cost because measure,

186
00:10:59.860 --> 00:11:03.360
where I'm trying to get a clear picture,
a lot of times that word is used.

187
00:11:03.360 --> 00:11:07.870
>> Yeah and even in IT we use the term
baseline to get that as its picture so

188
00:11:07.870 --> 00:11:12.930
you can have something to compare
something to identify any anomalies or

189
00:11:12.930 --> 00:11:15.470
any divergence there, so
it does have a dual meaning.

190
00:11:15.470 --> 00:11:20.370
>> Exactly, and as a project manager you
just need to be aware that if you're

191
00:11:20.370 --> 00:11:23.550
confused, then your audience is
probably pretty confused too.

192
00:11:24.590 --> 00:11:27.280
Okay, so
if you were looking at the DMAIC model,

193
00:11:27.280 --> 00:11:30.970
the third phase of
the DMAIC model is analyze.

194
00:11:30.970 --> 00:11:35.790
And in a lot of classes, if you were
taking the Lean Six Sigma class like say

195
00:11:35.790 --> 00:11:40.590
outside, or even if you were listening
to it a little bit on ITProTV.

196
00:11:40.590 --> 00:11:44.910
There's a tendency in the analyse space
of the DMAIC model to concentrate

197
00:11:44.910 --> 00:11:48.280
on those seven analytical
problem solving tools.

198
00:11:48.280 --> 00:11:50.990
However, a lot of things
are going on in analyse.

199
00:11:50.990 --> 00:11:54.040
One of the things that's going on in
analyse is that you're looking for

200
00:11:55.150 --> 00:11:57.360
forward key positions.

201
00:11:57.360 --> 00:11:59.400
One is you're trying to
figure out root cause.

202
00:11:59.400 --> 00:12:00.640
You've got your information for

203
00:12:00.640 --> 00:12:04.770
measure, now what you're trying to do is
your trying to figure out root cause.

204
00:12:04.770 --> 00:12:08.570
You're also looking for correlations,
you're looking for impact and

205
00:12:08.570 --> 00:12:10.740
you're also looking for variation.

206
00:12:10.740 --> 00:12:15.322
Sometimes in order to do that you need
one of those seven analytical problem

207
00:12:15.322 --> 00:12:18.824
solving tools and
that's why it pops up a lot in analyze.

208
00:12:18.824 --> 00:12:24.038
As a project manager, the cool
thing about analyze is that analyze

209
00:12:24.038 --> 00:12:29.370
has all kinds of tips and
tricks on how to present your logic.

210
00:12:29.370 --> 00:12:32.260
Let's say you already have your
logic completely thought out,

211
00:12:32.260 --> 00:12:34.860
you've got your project plan,
you've rolled it out.

212
00:12:34.860 --> 00:12:39.000
But you know that you're gonna
need a little bit of buy in.

213
00:12:39.000 --> 00:12:42.000
When you present your project or
your project idea.

214
00:12:42.000 --> 00:12:46.030
So analyze is a good place to go
to get some other ideas of how to

215
00:12:46.030 --> 00:12:48.500
package that particular knowledge.

216
00:12:48.500 --> 00:12:50.920
One of the things that

217
00:12:50.920 --> 00:12:55.950
analyze looks at is something called
a Failure Mode Effect Analysis, and

218
00:12:55.950 --> 00:12:59.950
that's a tool that we'll be looking
at a little bit later in our session.

219
00:12:59.950 --> 00:13:05.100
So this particular tool can be at a lot
of different places in the project

220
00:13:05.100 --> 00:13:09.320
life cycle that we've developed, but
one place we can use it is in analyze.

221
00:13:09.320 --> 00:13:11.940
And the reason why we're
bringing it up now,

episodes.description: This episode covers Agile Project Management methodology. While this ideology supports some traditional concepts, several differences are outlined in this show. You will see projects broken down into small batches, teams and continuous improvements.

So if you're in a typical

Storming, there's usually

00:12:49.800 --> 00:12:51.010
So.

00:12:51.010 --> 00:12:54.770
And then the next thing that happens

00:13:17.450 --> 00:13:22.940

there's still a lot of discussion, and

00:13:33.150 --> 00:13:36.755

00:13:40.200 --> 00:13:42.930
Forming, storming,

00:13:42.930 --> 00:13:45.250
Because in a traditional

Whereas in the Agile environment,

00:14:05.500 --> 00:14:09.520

excuse me,

272
00:14:42.208 --> 00:14:47.760
Agile projects,
sometimes during the storming or

273
00:14:47.760 --> 00:14:52.640
even during that time frame, you might
go on a little, I don't know maybe

274
00:14:52.640 --> 00:14:56.700
like a field trip, so that you're removing
the pressure of your work environment.

275
00:14:56.700 --> 00:15:00.690
But in an environment like this, you
might not have the extra time to go and

276
00:15:00.690 --> 00:15:05.110
have that fun, or just that meeting phase.

277
00:15:05.110 --> 00:15:05.904
>> Exactly.

278
00:15:05.904 --> 00:15:08.730
And I think back to that.

279
00:15:08.730 --> 00:15:11.440
The four phases of the team.

280
00:15:11.440 --> 00:15:15.120
I think that's the whole thing is that in
Agile environments they consider stuff

281
00:15:15.120 --> 00:15:19.700
like that, whereas in project management
environments it's really kind of

282
00:15:19.700 --> 00:15:24.950
the communication plan is pretty set like
when she start entering in the project.

283
00:15:24.950 --> 00:15:27.250
It's just, we're not gonna be as creative.

284
00:15:27.250 --> 00:15:29.500
We're just gonna subscribe to [INAUDIBLE]
>> Okay, so like a lunch and

285
00:15:29.500 --> 00:15:33.630
learn would be an acceptable form
of during that storming phase-

286
00:15:33.630 --> 00:15:34.860
>> Yeah, absolutely.

287
00:15:34.860 --> 00:15:35.790
>> Something, okay.

288
00:15:35.790 --> 00:15:37.760
>> Absolutely, absolutely.

289
00:15:37.760 --> 00:15:40.370
And so, and like I said,
in some Agile environments.

290
00:15:40.370 --> 00:15:44.889
Even though this literature is from 2002,
it has been updated multiple times.

291
00:15:46.110 --> 00:15:49.502
But when we're looking at
the 5 dysfunctions of a team,

292
00:15:49.502 --> 00:15:52.552
traditional project managers
study this as well.

293
00:15:52.552 --> 00:15:55.883
So outside those three
bodies of knowledge,

294
00:15:55.883 --> 00:16:00.190
this is like a very popular
work if I'm having to do teams.

295
00:16:00.190 --> 00:16:02.640
So absence of trust is the first one.

296
00:16:03.700 --> 00:16:07.070
And I know you can read this bullets,
so I'm just doing the highlights.

297
00:16:07.070 --> 00:16:10.438
Fear of conflict, lack of commitment,

298
00:16:10.438 --> 00:16:15.890
avoidance of accountability,
and inattention to results.

299
00:16:15.890 --> 00:16:21.370
So if I'm trying to
make my team strong and

300
00:16:21.370 --> 00:16:25.830
I'm the project manager, the nice thing to
know is that if I go into an environment

301
00:16:25.830 --> 00:16:29.400
where they're split, like some
are traditional and some are agile.

302
00:16:29.400 --> 00:16:33.080
Again, happening all the time with
global mergers and acquisitions.

303
00:16:33.080 --> 00:16:36.060
That was a hard thing to say,
with our global mergers and

304
00:16:36.060 --> 00:16:39.360
acquisitions, all the time
you got blended groups.

305
00:16:39.360 --> 00:16:44.140
Even in IT, you've got people that
are working on different platforms in

306
00:16:45.550 --> 00:16:47.860
addition to working on different models.

307
00:16:47.860 --> 00:16:50.270
>> And even different standard
operating procedures,

308
00:16:50.270 --> 00:16:51.740
coming from their different backgrounds.

309
00:16:51.740 --> 00:16:54.182
Their company didn't do things
the way that the new company does.

310
00:16:54.182 --> 00:16:56.130
>> Exactly.
>> So it's gonna be a challenge at times.

311
00:16:56.130 --> 00:16:58.560
>> So this is like,
these five dysfunctions,

312
00:16:58.560 --> 00:17:01.420
this is a safe place as
a project manager to go.

313
00:17:01.420 --> 00:17:05.210
Because everyone seems to like this work,
and, like I said,

314
00:17:05.210 --> 00:17:10.140
even though it came out in 2002,
there's a lot more updated models.

315
00:17:10.140 --> 00:17:13.860
The thing that I think that's
interesting about the 5 dysfunctions is,

316
00:17:13.860 --> 00:17:19.850
there's a couple of things there that go
back to old TQM, Total Quality Management.

317
00:17:19.850 --> 00:17:23.792
That we've been saying this for
a really, really long time so,

318
00:17:23.792 --> 00:17:26.500
it's just something to kinda keep in mind.

319
00:17:28.941 --> 00:17:33.995
So when we're looking at Scrum teams,
when we're looking at a project

320
00:17:33.995 --> 00:17:38.640
management team, it's almost
like whoever we can get, right?

321
00:17:38.640 --> 00:17:40.470
From these different
cross-functional areas.

322
00:17:40.470 --> 00:17:43.820
When we're looking at a Scrum team,
it's usually five to ten people,

323
00:17:43.820 --> 00:17:44.910
that's like optimum.

324
00:17:44.910 --> 00:17:47.205
And this, remember, in a perfect world.

325
00:17:47.205 --> 00:17:48.940
Cross-functional.

326
00:17:48.940 --> 00:17:54.064
So I want to have, and I would think some
agile people might disagree with this.

327
00:17:54.064 --> 00:17:58.170
But I want some quality auditors
on my team, those type of people.

328
00:17:59.470 --> 00:18:03.260
Members of the Scrum team
are supposed to be full-time.

329
00:18:03.260 --> 00:18:08.260
So in a traditional project
management environment,

330
00:18:08.260 --> 00:18:10.340
a lot of times they're matrixed.

331
00:18:10.340 --> 00:18:13.390
