And so that means I have someone
that's working on my team, but

332
00:18:13.390 --> 00:18:15.590
they're dedicated to other things, okay?

333
00:18:15.590 --> 00:18:18.915
So Scrum teams,
in an ideal perfect environment,

334
00:18:18.915 --> 00:18:22.174
they're dedicated to
that particular project.

335
00:18:22.174 --> 00:18:24.700
Teams are self-organizing.

336
00:18:24.700 --> 00:18:29.048
When you're thinking about
self-organizing teams Kind of

337
00:18:29.048 --> 00:18:32.125
think you can vote someone off the island.

338
00:18:32.125 --> 00:18:36.430
[LAUGH] They might need to go be
someone on someone else's team.

339
00:18:36.430 --> 00:18:39.450
Again, in traditional project management,
and like I said the reason I

340
00:18:39.450 --> 00:18:43.920
keep comparing it back to that is the
three primary project management bodies of

341
00:18:43.920 --> 00:18:48.320
knowledge support traditional over
agile project management, right?

342
00:18:48.320 --> 00:18:52.190
And so in a traditional project management
environment you're kinda stuck.

343
00:18:53.830 --> 00:18:57.230
The people you have on your team are the
people you're gonna have on your team.

344
00:18:57.230 --> 00:19:01.286
There's really not a lot of flexibility
to vote people off the island, or maybe-

345
00:19:01.286 --> 00:19:01.799
>> Yeah, but

346
00:19:01.799 --> 00:19:05.566
if you see that two people really are
cohesive, and maybe they just bring it out

347
00:19:05.566 --> 00:19:09.470
to others, they make each other shine,
then why not put them together, right?

348
00:19:09.470 --> 00:19:12.665
>> Exactly, and then membership can
just change only between Sprints,

349
00:19:12.665 --> 00:19:15.384
which we'll be talking about
in the selection part of the-

350
00:19:15.384 --> 00:19:16.688
>> Okay.

351
00:19:16.688 --> 00:19:22.789
>> So, pretty much, you're on that team,
you're dedicated to that team, right?

352
00:19:22.789 --> 00:19:25.484
But in-between you can do it.

353
00:19:25.484 --> 00:19:29.463
All right, so we talked a lot
about agile project management

354
00:19:29.463 --> 00:19:32.282
versus traditional project management.

355
00:19:32.282 --> 00:19:35.286
So I think I'd like to end
up with this schematic.

356
00:19:35.286 --> 00:19:38.370
Because this gives a good comparison,
agile, traditional.

357
00:19:38.370 --> 00:19:42.840
So the first one says, Focus on
customer satisfaction and interaction.

358
00:19:44.360 --> 00:19:48.370
The traditional project managements
has Focus on plans and artifacts.

359
00:19:48.370 --> 00:19:51.700
Now, artifacts are things
that are left over, but

360
00:19:51.700 --> 00:19:54.030
focusing on the plan is not a bad thing.

361
00:19:54.030 --> 00:19:55.056
Would you agree, Cherokee?

362
00:19:55.056 --> 00:19:58.447
>> Right you have to keep that in mind,
that's what your goal is, right?

363
00:19:58.447 --> 00:20:00.462
>> Exactly, but sometimes we're so

364
00:20:00.462 --> 00:20:04.290
married to the plan that we forget
about customer satisfaction.

365
00:20:04.290 --> 00:20:09.080
So when we say agile versus traditional
we're not saying good versus bad.

366
00:20:09.080 --> 00:20:14.510
And keep in mind the bodies of knowledge
support traditional over agile.

367
00:20:14.510 --> 00:20:17.600
So we've got a lot of supporters
of that traditional thing.

368
00:20:17.600 --> 00:20:21.130
It's just that just agile is looking
at it through a different lens.

369
00:20:21.130 --> 00:20:23.950
I will say that lean project management,

370
00:20:23.950 --> 00:20:27.930
because you could be studying just lean
project management, not lean and agile.

371
00:20:27.930 --> 00:20:31.130
Lean has a closer alliance with agile

372
00:20:31.130 --> 00:20:34.790
than it does with traditional
project management, if that helps.

373
00:20:34.790 --> 00:20:39.730
Okay, so the next one,
Response to change via adaptive action.

374
00:20:40.790 --> 00:20:45.880
So in the traditional project
management environment,

375
00:20:45.880 --> 00:20:48.120
if something goes wrong,
we have a tendency,

376
00:20:48.120 --> 00:20:53.130
if you're looking at that second column,
to do a corrective action procedure.

377
00:20:53.130 --> 00:20:56.850
And in fact, a lot of times it's
called a change order, right?

378
00:20:56.850 --> 00:21:02.086
So in the agile environment,
you're a little bit more able to adapt,

379
00:21:02.086 --> 00:21:05.657
as opposed to,
I'm gonna file a change order.

380
00:21:05.657 --> 00:21:06.690
>> Getting the approval.

381
00:21:06.690 --> 00:21:07.800
>> And I'm gonna get the approval.

382
00:21:07.800 --> 00:21:10.400
I can do a little bit more
changing on the fly, and

383
00:21:10.400 --> 00:21:12.490
in some cases that's really a good deal.

384
00:21:13.870 --> 00:21:15.350
We don't have to look at all of them.

385
00:21:15.350 --> 00:21:18.800
This is a handout that you're going
to get in your student package.

386
00:21:18.800 --> 00:21:20.560
But I'd like to look at a couple of more.

387
00:21:20.560 --> 00:21:23.160
Is there anything there that
looks interesting to you?

388
00:21:23.160 --> 00:21:23.670
>> Let's see.

389
00:21:23.670 --> 00:21:28.744
We've got Customer prioritized, time-boxed
delivery, over Manager negotiated.

390
00:21:28.744 --> 00:21:33.708
So it looks like, under that bullet point,
that the customer does have a bit

391
00:21:33.708 --> 00:21:37.913
of a input as far as timeline,
and how things will be delivered.

392
00:21:37.913 --> 00:21:38.877
What else?

393
00:21:38.877 --> 00:21:42.416
Collaboration on self-disciplined and
self-organizing team,

394
00:21:42.416 --> 00:21:46.710
versus a hierarchical, top-down control,
that traditional style.

395
00:21:46.710 --> 00:21:50.925
We also see a Minimal set
of context-sensitive,

396
00:21:50.925 --> 00:21:56.000
generative practices,
versus Prescriptive, heavyweight methods.

397
00:21:56.000 --> 00:21:58.540
So there's definitely a difference there.

398
00:21:58.540 --> 00:22:04.340
And then we also see, on the agile side,
Essential, or value-focused metrics.

399
00:22:04.340 --> 00:22:08.139
Whereas on the traditional side we see
those Non-value added controls, so.

400
00:22:08.139 --> 00:22:11.268
>> Right, and so
it happens in project management,

401
00:22:11.268 --> 00:22:15.970
frequently about, there's a report
that we always do on Friday, right?

402
00:22:15.970 --> 00:22:20.280
And so it's harder for
traditional project management to let go

403
00:22:20.280 --> 00:22:23.730
of some of those non-value added metrics,
it's just harder.

404
00:22:23.730 --> 00:22:27.131
Now this schematic, again,
is kind of indicating good/bad.

405
00:22:27.131 --> 00:22:31.721
And I need you to remember that
it's just a different lens, right?

406
00:22:31.721 --> 00:22:35.710
And there really are projects
that can't be agile.

407
00:22:35.710 --> 00:22:38.220
We can still use some of the agile
tools that we're gonna learn.

408
00:22:38.220 --> 00:22:41.640
And we can still kind of
adopt some of those concepts.

409
00:22:41.640 --> 00:22:44.800
But there's a lot of times when we're
in a compliance environment, and

410
00:22:44.800 --> 00:22:46.340
we have to do traditional.

411
00:22:46.340 --> 00:22:53.610
Or the project is so large, we can't
really afford a lot of flexibility.

412
00:22:53.610 --> 00:22:56.670
>> All right, well thank you for
explaining the agile methodology.

413
00:22:56.670 --> 00:22:59.054
That was actually the first time I've
ever formally taken a look at that.

414
00:22:59.054 --> 00:23:01.490
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I appreciate that very much.

415
00:23:01.490 --> 00:23:03.670
And thank you guys for
tuning in and watching.

416
00:23:03.670 --> 00:23:07.110
Don't go anywhere, because we have
a lot more information headed your way.

417
00:23:07.110 --> 00:23:10.070
I think we'll be looking
at why projects fail.

418
00:23:10.070 --> 00:23:12.570
So get comfortable, stay tuned.

419
00:23:12.570 --> 00:23:15.380
But for this episode,
we'll go ahead and sign off.

420
00:23:15.380 --> 00:23:17.380
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

421
00:23:17.380 --> 00:23:21.070
>> And I'm Dr. Tara Vanzant Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

422
00:23:21.070 --> 00:23:24.784
>> See you next time here at ITPro.TV.

423
00:23:24.784 --> 00:23:30.687
[MUSIC]

424
00:23:30.687 --> 00:23:34.343
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Cherokee Boose and Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern explain why projects fail. Some common reasons include architecture/design, configuration, the decision making process, bad estimates or even just not paying enough attention to theory of constraints. You will also learn theory of constraints as well as types of constraints.
episodes.title: Session 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:01.299
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.299 --> 00:00:02.121
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.121 --> 00:00:08.319
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:08.319 --> 00:00:12.352
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.352 --> 00:00:16.613
>> Welcome to your Lean and
Agile Project Management series,

6
00:00:16.613 --> 00:00:19.263
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:19.263 --> 00:00:24.076
In the last episode we wrapped up
talking about the agile methodology.

8
00:00:24.076 --> 00:00:28.333
In this episode, session five,
we'll be taking a look at, well,

9
00:00:28.333 --> 00:00:29.764
why do projects fail.

10
00:00:29.764 --> 00:00:33.829
I'm sure Dr. Tara Van Zandt-Stern
will have a lot of explanations for

11
00:00:33.829 --> 00:00:37.840
us because you have a good amount of
experience under your belt there.

12
00:00:37.840 --> 00:00:40.456
So why do projects fail Doctor Stern?

13
00:00:40.456 --> 00:00:44.010
>> Well if we can,
I'd like to go to my slide deck.

14
00:00:46.410 --> 00:00:51.024
And here's a good example
of a failed project, right?

15
00:00:51.024 --> 00:00:55.205
>> [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK] Don't put
me that bridge, there you go.

16
00:00:55.205 --> 00:00:57.984
[LAUGH]
>> Now there's certain things that

17
00:00:57.984 --> 00:01:03.384
are given, a lot of times projects failed
because of those triple constraints.

18
00:01:03.384 --> 00:01:08.152
Now, triple constraints in project
management gets a little confusing

19
00:01:08.152 --> 00:01:12.470
because not everyone agrees on
what the triple constraints are.

20
00:01:12.470 --> 00:01:17.940
However, most people will say time,
money, and resources, right?

21
00:01:17.940 --> 00:01:19.880
And sometimes they'll say quality or
scope and

22
00:01:19.880 --> 00:01:23.410
then that's five triple constraints,
right?

23
00:01:23.410 --> 00:01:27.350
But a lot of times it's related
to things such as that, right?

24
00:01:27.350 --> 00:01:30.718
But sometimes there's certain
things that we need to consider.

25
00:01:30.718 --> 00:01:36.352
For example, architecture and design,
configuration, how do the decision process

26
00:01:36.352 --> 00:01:41.927
is making how that's going, how do people
make decisions, bad estimates, right?

27
00:01:41.927 --> 00:01:46.832
So that's a little different than money
because my project could fail because of

28
00:01:46.832 --> 00:01:52.200
money, time, or resources but if I made a
bad judgement, I just made a bad estimate.

29
00:01:52.200 --> 00:01:56.104
I see that it's slightly different,
so it's still related to money and

30
00:01:56.104 --> 00:01:59.560
then not paying enough attention
to the Theory of Constraints,

31
00:01:59.560 --> 00:02:01.480
which we're also going to look at.

32
00:02:01.480 --> 00:02:04.624
>> I guess it also depends on how
bad of an estimate you've made.

33
00:02:04.624 --> 00:02:08.239
If you can compensate by kind
of shifting your budget around,

34
00:02:08.239 --> 00:02:10.126
maybe it's not as noticeable.

35
00:02:10.126 --> 00:02:12.264
>> Exactly, exactly.

36
00:02:12.264 --> 00:02:16.528
So even though it's still one of the
triple constraints, no matter what model

37
00:02:16.528 --> 00:02:20.980
you look at, people will say that
the reason projects fail is the money.

38
00:02:20.980 --> 00:02:25.771
But actually, a lot of studies have
been done and projects that fail

39
00:02:25.771 --> 00:02:29.516
have more to do with the people [LAUGH]-
>> I could believe that.

40
00:02:29.516 --> 00:02:30.517
>> Than the money.

41
00:02:30.517 --> 00:02:36.024
So one reason a project could fail
is the architecture and design.

42
00:02:36.024 --> 00:02:39.711
I actually think this is quite clever,
but I'm just showing you this

43
00:02:39.711 --> 00:02:43.286
picture to give you an example of
what architecture and design is.

44
00:02:43.286 --> 00:02:47.656
So one of the reasons projects
fail is because of that, right?

45
00:02:47.656 --> 00:02:53.296
And then configuration and
information management,

46
00:02:53.296 --> 00:03:01.640
what impact does what I have to do as a
project have over the entire organization?

47
00:03:01.640 --> 00:03:03.839
So, sometimes projects
fail because of that.

48
00:03:03.839 --> 00:03:08.348
So I'm a project manager and
I realize I'm in charge of a project that

49
00:03:08.348 --> 00:03:11.474
is very dependent on architecture and
design.

50
00:03:11.474 --> 00:03:15.182
Well then, if I'm not an architecture and
design person,

51
00:03:15.182 --> 00:03:20.311
I'm just the project manager, I wanna go
back and make sure that that looks okay.

52
00:03:20.311 --> 00:03:23.600
And I want it tested out by some
subject matter experts, right?

53
00:03:23.600 --> 00:03:28.326
Configuration management and information
management has a little bit more

54
00:03:28.326 --> 00:03:31.866
to do with just being aware
of the other departments, and

55
00:03:31.866 --> 00:03:34.301
other things that I'm impacting, and

56
00:03:34.301 --> 00:03:39.205
even some of the software stuff that
I'm putting into my department, right?

57
00:03:39.205 --> 00:03:41.705
How is that all interfacing,
does that make sense?

58
00:03:41.705 --> 00:03:44.588
>> Yeah, just as long as we don't
have any compatibility conflicts,

59
00:03:44.588 --> 00:03:45.860
is that what you're saying?

60
00:03:45.860 --> 00:03:49.795
>> Exactly, in fact that's probably
even a better way of saying it.

61
00:03:49.795 --> 00:03:54.002
Another reason projects fail is
the decision-making process.

62
00:03:54.002 --> 00:03:56.576
And sometimes that's
called the DM Process.

63
00:03:56.576 --> 00:04:00.290
So if I'm looking at this,
I don't know what to do.

64
00:04:00.290 --> 00:04:03.834
>> I guess I can stand there,
and that really looks about it.

65
00:04:03.834 --> 00:04:07.909
>> That's my choice, I can stop,
but where do I go, right?

66
00:04:07.909 --> 00:04:11.589
So, I wanna make sure that people
are giving me clear directions.

67
00:04:11.589 --> 00:04:13.928
So when we talk about decisions,

68
00:04:13.928 --> 00:04:17.444
the outcome of the decision
as a project manager.

69
00:04:17.444 --> 00:04:21.935
I can make a decision but if people don't
know what to do with that decision,

70
00:04:21.935 --> 00:04:26.017
if my decision is too complicated,
they're not gonna follow that.

71
00:04:26.017 --> 00:04:30.677
So, the decision making process as well
as the way I delivered that decision,

72
00:04:30.677 --> 00:04:32.028
does that make sense?

73
00:04:32.028 --> 00:04:33.380
>> I think so.

74
00:04:33.380 --> 00:04:37.889
>> So another reason things fail
is because of bad estimation.

75
00:04:37.889 --> 00:04:42.646
Now, in one of the segments, we already
covered that a good estimating tool,

76
00:04:42.646 --> 00:04:45.891
it's pretty much accepted
by all project managers,

77
00:04:45.891 --> 00:04:49.012
is that tool that I always
have to use my hands with.

78
00:04:49.012 --> 00:04:54.284
If I'm trying to estimate something,
now remember, history trumps everything.

79
00:04:54.284 --> 00:04:56.300
If I know how much it costs,
I don't have to estimate, right?

80
00:04:56.300 --> 00:04:57.181
>> Use that number.

81
00:04:57.181 --> 00:04:58.389
>> I'm done.

82
00:04:58.389 --> 00:05:02.972
But if I'm trying to estimate a cost, what
I would do is I would take the highest

83
00:05:02.972 --> 00:05:05.063
cost and this also works with time.

84
00:05:05.063 --> 00:05:08.720
But I'd take the highest cost,
the lowest cost, and

85
00:05:08.720 --> 00:05:11.329
then four times the most likely cost.

86
00:05:12.420 --> 00:05:17.042
Now I have six fingers up,
now I divide that number by six and

87
00:05:17.042 --> 00:05:20.300
that's gonna give me-
>> An estimated, like a projection.

88
00:05:20.300 --> 00:05:22.774
>> Right,
now we use estimates all the time.

89
00:05:22.774 --> 00:05:24.649
So let's say, for example,

90
00:05:24.649 --> 00:05:28.707
I would like to turn one of my
closets into a wine cellar, right.

91
00:05:28.707 --> 00:05:32.011
Okay, well,
that's kind of an odd request and

92
00:05:32.011 --> 00:05:35.490
I might not know if I have
enough budget to do that.

93
00:05:35.490 --> 00:05:39.363
So I'm gonna go out to the community and
say look, this is what I have,

94
00:05:39.363 --> 00:05:42.265
this is what I wanna do,
can you give me an estimate?

95
00:05:42.265 --> 00:05:45.504
And based on that estimate I'm
gonna make a decision, right.

96
00:05:45.504 --> 00:05:47.360
>> Yes.
>> So if it's like crazy insane,

97
00:05:47.360 --> 00:05:49.864
I'm probably gonna put it off for a while.

98
00:05:49.864 --> 00:05:52.341
But if it's something within my budget,
I'm gonna move forward.

99
00:05:52.341 --> 00:05:58.348
So being able to budget things well
is a core skill for project managers.

100
00:05:58.348 --> 00:06:02.356
I think also you can go and
look at the mode.

101
00:06:02.356 --> 00:06:09.626
There are three measures of central
tendency, median, mode and mean.

102
00:06:09.626 --> 00:06:11.660
And mean is the one that
we work with all the time.

103
00:06:11.660 --> 00:06:13.253
>> Average.
>> That's an average, right.

104
00:06:13.253 --> 00:06:18.025
But in this case I might wanna go out,
so mean is an average,

105
00:06:18.025 --> 00:06:22.426
mean average and
mean average all mean the same thing.

106
00:06:22.426 --> 00:06:25.630
Median would be that number
that's in the middle, right?

107
00:06:25.630 --> 00:06:28.233
A mode would be the number
that happens the most often.

108
00:06:28.233 --> 00:06:33.779
So I have a tendency when I'm doing
cost estimating to look at the mode.

109
00:06:33.779 --> 00:06:36.243
What is most people charging for
that table?

110
00:06:36.243 --> 00:06:40.132
>> Well, right, because geographically
something may cost more in one area

111
00:06:40.132 --> 00:06:43.846
than it does in another, so you have
to kind of keep that in mind as well.

112
00:06:43.846 --> 00:06:44.712
>> Exactly.

113
00:06:44.712 --> 00:06:49.332
So one of the reasons projects fail
is because of the bad money estimate.

114
00:06:49.332 --> 00:06:52.192
But we could also make
a bad time estimate.

115
00:06:52.192 --> 00:06:57.346
And like I said, even though we did cover
that estimation formula in another series,

116
00:06:57.346 --> 00:06:59.363
you could use it for time as well.

117
00:06:59.363 --> 00:07:01.684
>> Yeah, every day I'm trying to estimate,

118
00:07:01.684 --> 00:07:04.465
how long is this concept
going to take us to convey?

119
00:07:04.465 --> 00:07:08.506
We try to keep our shows in 30 minute
segments but as you guys already know,

120
00:07:08.506 --> 00:07:10.562
it doesn't always work out that way.

121
00:07:10.562 --> 00:07:13.326
So really, it's kind of an art.

122
00:07:13.326 --> 00:07:15.831
After a while,
after experience you get better at it, but

123
00:07:15.831 --> 00:07:17.378
you sometimes you just never know.

124
00:07:17.378 --> 00:07:21.199
>> It is, again, just a core skill for
a project manager, but

125
00:07:21.199 --> 00:07:26.488
it's one of the biggest reasons things
fail, bad estimate, bad time estimate.

126
00:07:26.488 --> 00:07:30.967
And remember, we discussed this in another
session, your baseline, what you tell

127
00:07:30.967 --> 00:07:35.340
people, this is how long it's going to
take and this is how much it's gonna cost.

128
00:07:35.340 --> 00:07:39.709
As soon as you come up with that line,
as soon as you say that,

129
00:07:39.709 --> 00:07:42.548
that's what you're graded against.

130
00:07:42.548 --> 00:07:46.878
Even if it's not fair, even if there's
some kind of weird thing that happens that

131
00:07:46.878 --> 00:07:48.398
you hadn't accounted for.

132
00:07:48.398 --> 00:07:53.130
So, another reason projects fail
is something called constraints.

133
00:07:53.130 --> 00:07:56.379
We don't pay enough attention
to the constraints.

134
00:07:56.379 --> 00:07:59.370
Now a constraint is anything
that gets in our way.

135
00:07:59.370 --> 00:08:03.940
Triple constraints, many time people, or
if you're looking at a different model.

136
00:08:03.940 --> 00:08:07.690
Somewhere in that model they're
including scope and quality, right?

137
00:08:07.690 --> 00:08:11.070
However, there are other
areas of constraints, and

138
00:08:11.070 --> 00:08:13.170
that's what we're gonna talk about next.

139
00:08:13.170 --> 00:08:17.990
Typically in project management,
regardless if you're a traditional project

140
00:08:17.990 --> 00:08:22.350
manager or an agile project manager, this
isn't something we really think about.

141
00:08:22.350 --> 00:08:25.140
And so as a Lean and
Agile project manager,

142
00:08:25.140 --> 00:08:29.720
cuz this comes a little bit more from the
Lean side, this is a tip that we can use.

143
00:08:29.720 --> 00:08:34.480
So first I just wanna give credit,
Eli Goldratt was

144
00:08:34.480 --> 00:08:39.680
the person who came up with
a book called The Goal in 1992.

145
00:08:39.680 --> 00:08:42.740
He's passed a few years ago, but

146
00:08:42.740 --> 00:08:48.760
this book in 1992 is why we use terms like
empowerment and those types of things.

147
00:08:48.760 --> 00:08:54.320
He wrote a novel about a man
that went to work and was

148
00:08:55.350 --> 00:09:00.090
subjected to a lot of different meetings
and came up with those types of words.

149
00:09:00.090 --> 00:09:04.190
But one of the things that he did,
I mean that's one of his biggest pieces,

150
00:09:04.190 --> 00:09:09.120
some of you may have read it, some of
you may be too young to have read it.

151
00:09:09.120 --> 00:09:10.460
It's still a good book.

152
00:09:10.460 --> 00:09:12.320
It's a little dated.

153
00:09:12.320 --> 00:09:16.400
But what I think is kind of interesting
is terms we throw around all the time.

154
00:09:16.400 --> 00:09:18.620
These days kinda came from that work.

155
00:09:18.620 --> 00:09:19.540
>> Like the win-win-
>> Yeah-

156
00:09:19.540 --> 00:09:20.268
>> Team building.

157
00:09:20.268 --> 00:09:23.590
>> Exactly, this type of things,
those are things that,

158
00:09:23.590 --> 00:09:28.538
I mean I'm sure there were some people
before '92 saying it, but after '92,

159
00:09:28.538 --> 00:09:32.730
it became part of our vocabulary
it's such a piece of our vocabulary.

160
00:09:32.730 --> 00:09:35.600
Now we didn't always know
where that originated.

161
00:09:35.600 --> 00:09:38.160
So this gentleman that came up with that

162
00:09:38.160 --> 00:09:41.940
also came up with the body of knowledge
called the Theory of Constraints.

163
00:09:43.170 --> 00:09:45.250
Now the types of constraints,

164
00:09:45.250 --> 00:09:49.170
this is the first thing that I think
project managers can benefit from

165
00:09:49.170 --> 00:09:52.650
is that there's a lot more constraints
than we usually think about.

166
00:09:52.650 --> 00:09:54.560
For example, there's a market constraint.

167
00:09:56.170 --> 00:09:58.150
There's a capacity constraint.

168
00:09:58.150 --> 00:10:03.350
My process might not be capable of doing
what you want me to do in this project.

169
00:10:04.370 --> 00:10:08.049
There could be a resource constraint
that goes back to those basic ones.

170
00:10:10.100 --> 00:10:12.540
There could be a supplier constraint.

171
00:10:12.540 --> 00:10:16.790
Now, there is a tendency on the Lean side,
not so much on Agile, but

172
00:10:16.790 --> 00:10:20.160
on the Lean side to still
refer to vendors as suppliers.

173
00:10:20.160 --> 00:10:22.172
>> Okay.
>> But what I want you to kind of think

174
00:10:22.172 --> 00:10:24.860
of as a supplier might be
just someone that you're

175
00:10:24.860 --> 00:10:26.426
depending on to get-
>> Internally.

176
00:10:26.426 --> 00:10:27.380
>> Your work done.

177
00:10:27.380 --> 00:10:28.340
Exactly.

178
00:10:28.340 --> 00:10:33.040
And the example I usually use is
if you have to get a signature

179
00:10:33.040 --> 00:10:36.390
on something before you can move forward,
technically they're your supplier.

180
00:10:36.390 --> 00:10:37.490
>> Okay.

181
00:10:37.490 --> 00:10:41.054
>> However if we think more
from a bigger deal as a vendor,

182
00:10:41.054 --> 00:10:46.013
if I'm a project manager and I need
nonhuman resources from a supplier, and

183
00:10:46.013 --> 00:10:49.669
they're not available,
hey, that's a constraint.

184
00:10:49.669 --> 00:10:53.050
And that's might not be something I
go into the project thinking about.

185
00:10:54.380 --> 00:10:59.880
The Lean and Agile project manager
starts thinking about their constraints

186
00:10:59.880 --> 00:11:02.160
before the project even gets started.

187
00:11:02.160 --> 00:11:04.400
So here's another one with finance.

188
00:11:05.700 --> 00:11:08.180
And again remember finance

189
00:11:08.180 --> 00:11:12.000
is part of that triple constraints when
we're thinking time, money, resources.

190
00:11:12.000 --> 00:11:16.070
Knowledge or competence, and
this one always kinda thrills me.

191
00:11:16.070 --> 00:11:22.080
Do I have a knowledge constraint,
like people are just not that smart?

192
00:11:22.080 --> 00:11:25.350
Do I have a competency constraint?

193
00:11:25.350 --> 00:11:26.660
Like there are people who.

194
00:11:26.660 --> 00:11:31.400
And this could run the gamut from they
don't understand to they just don't care.

195
00:11:31.400 --> 00:11:32.090
>> True.
>> Right.

196
00:11:32.090 --> 00:11:33.259
>> Very true.

197
00:11:33.259 --> 00:11:36.004
>> And so finally a policy constraint.

198
00:11:36.004 --> 00:11:37.660
Could I have a policy constraint?

199
00:11:37.660 --> 00:11:42.008
So I've got this really great idea, but we
have a policy against doing that, right?

200
00:11:42.008 --> 00:11:42.537
>> It's prohibiting.

201
00:11:42.537 --> 00:11:44.280
Yeah.
>> Exactly.

202
00:11:44.280 --> 00:11:51.240
So, as I'm going through my project,
my goal is to get the project done, right?

203
00:11:51.240 --> 00:11:55.190
And I've created, let's say in this case,
I've created my project plan.

204
00:11:56.410 --> 00:11:58.556
I wanna finish.

205
00:11:58.556 --> 00:12:02.285
The Lean and Agile project manager
sits down and thinks about these

206
00:12:02.285 --> 00:12:07.146
constraints before they move forward,
whereas in traditional project management,

207
00:12:07.146 --> 00:12:11.310
we kinda have the tendency when
they come up, we deal with them.

208
00:12:11.310 --> 00:12:16.029
And guess what, if we're dealing with
a constraint that we weren't anticipating,

209
00:12:16.029 --> 00:12:18.180
it can push our project off, right?

210
00:12:18.180 --> 00:12:20.130
>> This is true.
>> Our timeline, our cost, so

211
00:12:20.130 --> 00:12:23.381
thinking about these
constraints is really huge.

212
00:12:23.381 --> 00:12:28.734
Now, the other thing that Eli talks
about that's good for the Lean and

213
00:12:28.734 --> 00:12:34.670
Agile project manager, is this whole
concept of uncertainty, right?

214
00:12:34.670 --> 00:12:38.330
So what are we gonna do if
something unplanned happens?

215
00:12:38.330 --> 00:12:40.420
Now an example of planning for

216
00:12:40.420 --> 00:12:45.140
uncertainty would be let's
say I have a project budget.

217
00:12:45.140 --> 00:12:46.301
I might go ahead and

218
00:12:46.301 --> 00:12:51.317
give you permission to spend up to $300
without coming to consult me, right?

219
00:12:51.317 --> 00:12:54.420
So there might be something
out there that comes up.

220
00:12:54.420 --> 00:12:58.160
I don't want you having to come to
me from [CROSSTALK] Exactly and so

221
00:12:58.160 --> 00:12:59.590
that's another thing.

222
00:12:59.590 --> 00:13:03.802
The Lean and Agile project manager wants
to recognize that there are probably

223
00:13:03.802 --> 00:13:05.485
things, I mean it's highly,

224
00:13:05.485 --> 00:13:10.310
highly unlikely that you're gonna do
a project without a constraint coming up.

225
00:13:10.310 --> 00:13:13.320
So if you can talk through those
constraints before you even start

226
00:13:13.320 --> 00:13:15.830
the project that's a good thing, right?

227
00:13:15.830 --> 00:13:20.220
>> It's very hard to be able to foresee
all the different possibilities that could

228
00:13:20.220 --> 00:13:21.790
arise within your project.

229
00:13:21.790 --> 00:13:24.497
But that's why certain people
get paid the big bucks, right?

230
00:13:24.497 --> 00:13:25.265
It's just from experience and
understanding

231
00:13:25.265 --> 00:13:27.498
>> Exactly.

232
00:13:27.498 --> 00:13:29.593
>> Being able to see
things from another view.

233
00:13:29.593 --> 00:13:31.858
>> Yeah, and
one of the things that I think is so

234
00:13:31.858 --> 00:13:35.534
interesting about Eli's work for
the Lean and Agile project manager,

235
00:13:35.534 --> 00:13:38.779
One of the things I think is
interesting is that, we don't even

236
00:13:38.779 --> 00:13:43.160
spend time talking about normal things
that could go wrong with our project.

237
00:13:43.160 --> 00:13:47.580
Now, we covered a couple of them,
architecture and design and configuration.

238
00:13:47.580 --> 00:13:48.720
Those types of things.

239
00:13:48.720 --> 00:13:50.580
But even simple things like,

240
00:13:50.580 --> 00:13:53.880
we just don't get along with
the people that we have to work with.

241
00:13:53.880 --> 00:13:56.760
I mean we don't even spend
time talking about that.

242
00:13:56.760 --> 00:14:00.110
So Eli kind of forces our hand.

243
00:14:00.110 --> 00:14:04.320
If we wanna be Lean and Agile why not
discuss all of this stuff up front.

244
00:14:04.320 --> 00:14:07.030
We know we're gonna have
an element of uncertainty.

245
00:14:07.030 --> 00:14:13.098
One of my favorite parts of Eli's work is
the concept of exploiting our constraints.

246
00:14:13.098 --> 00:14:15.200
And so if we exploit our constraints,

247
00:14:15.200 --> 00:14:18.980
what that means is that someone throws
something at us and we try to figure out

248
00:14:18.980 --> 00:14:23.260
how can we do something really cool
with that thing that we've been given.

249
00:14:23.260 --> 00:14:28.130
So, for example, when you're designing
programs such as this, if you wanna stay

250
00:14:28.130 --> 00:14:33.570
endorsed by the universities and
just different association entities,

251
00:14:33.570 --> 00:14:36.720
they're always giving you one more
requirement, one more requirement.

252
00:14:36.720 --> 00:14:39.135
And we used to, at SSD Global Solutions,

253
00:14:39.135 --> 00:14:44.210
girl I can't believe In order to get
this endorsement, now I have to do this.

254
00:14:44.210 --> 00:14:49.550
Well now what we do instead of complaining
about it, is we promote it on our website.

255
00:14:49.550 --> 00:14:51.630
We say hey, we are now offering this.

256
00:14:51.630 --> 00:14:57.490
Now not that we have a choice [LAUGH] But
we kind of use it as a promotional thing.

257
00:14:57.490 --> 00:15:01.694
So the idea of taking your constraint and
exploiting that constraint is one step

258
00:15:01.694 --> 00:15:04.659
beyond, I got lemons,
I'm gonna make lemonade.

259
00:15:04.659 --> 00:15:07.298
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's saying, hey, I'm gonna take this

260
00:15:07.298 --> 00:15:11.314
thing that you threw at me, this
constraint that's meant to slow me down,

261
00:15:11.314 --> 00:15:13.960
and I'm gonna do something
really cool with it.

262
00:15:13.960 --> 00:15:15.762
>> Yeah.
So I'm not just making lemonade, but

263
00:15:15.762 --> 00:15:18.790
maybe I'm setting up a lemonade stand,
>> Absolutely.

264
00:15:18.790 --> 00:15:21.430
>> And I'm setting up lemonade stand
franchises, and I'm making a ton of money.

265
00:15:21.430 --> 00:15:24.660
And I think, as a project manager, because
there's always things that get in your

266
00:15:24.660 --> 00:15:28.460
way, you can do the perfect project
plan and something will show up.

267
00:15:28.460 --> 00:15:33.930
I think it's really change my attitude in
project management altogether to just say,

268
00:15:33.930 --> 00:15:35.950
hey, hit me with your best shot.

269
00:15:35.950 --> 00:15:39.930
Because when you do that, I'm gonna take
it and I'm gonna make it work for me.

270
00:15:39.930 --> 00:15:42.400
So finally, the last thing.

271
00:15:42.400 --> 00:15:46.050
Well, I shouldn't say it's the last thing
because he has a plethora of lots of

272
00:15:46.050 --> 00:15:49.257
philosophical things on how to
make projects work better, faster,

273
00:15:49.257 --> 00:15:50.327
more cost effective.

274
00:15:50.327 --> 00:15:53.708
Which is why we're talking about it,
Lean and Agile project management.

275
00:15:53.708 --> 00:15:58.426
But Eli also had a lot of tips on
how to manage multiple projects.

276
00:15:58.426 --> 00:16:02.054
I mean, what would it be like if I
only had one project to manage, and

277
00:16:02.054 --> 00:16:04.551
I didn't have all my
personal projects to do?

278
00:16:04.551 --> 00:16:07.900
And so I'm sure some of you
do just have one project.

279
00:16:07.900 --> 00:16:12.770
But I think most of us, if we look at
a project as having an end, I mean,

280
00:16:12.770 --> 00:16:14.670
having a beginning and an end.

281
00:16:14.670 --> 00:16:17.588
And I'm trying to accomplish
something within a certain timeframe,

282
00:16:17.588 --> 00:16:19.376
I think most of us have multiple projects.

283
00:16:19.376 --> 00:16:20.058
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

284
00:16:20.058 --> 00:16:23.750
some of the tips is that we
wanna prioritize the project.

285
00:16:23.750 --> 00:16:28.510
And even though that sounds incredibly
intuitive, we're a reactive society.

286
00:16:28.510 --> 00:16:30.880
Someone brings us a problem,
we start working on that project.

287
00:16:30.880 --> 00:16:33.550
Someone else brings us a problem,
we start working on that.

288
00:16:33.550 --> 00:16:38.350
So just staying cognizant and just
staying focused that I've got all these

289
00:16:38.350 --> 00:16:42.310
projects on my desk, which ones do I
really need to be working on first.

290
00:16:42.310 --> 00:16:44.100
It's just kind of keeping that in mind.

291
00:16:45.900 --> 00:16:50.240
It says plan projects as
per the critical chain,

292
00:16:50.240 --> 00:16:53.988
one of the things in project management
that all three bodies of knowledge

293
00:16:53.988 --> 00:16:56.730
agree on is that there is a critical path.

294
00:16:56.730 --> 00:16:59.950
So I want you to go back and
think about your WBS, right?

295
00:16:59.950 --> 00:17:01.940
>> Okay.
>> If you look at your work breakdown

296
00:17:01.940 --> 00:17:06.335
structure, there are certain things that
have to be accomplished on a certain time

297
00:17:06.335 --> 00:17:09.630
frame, or
your whole project is gonna tank, right?

298
00:17:09.630 --> 00:17:13.880
So there's a chart called the PERT chart
that actually helps you with this, and

299
00:17:13.880 --> 00:17:16.550
it might pop up a little
bit later in our sessions.

300
00:17:16.550 --> 00:17:21.770
But the thing is is that I need,
if I have multiple projects,

301
00:17:21.770 --> 00:17:25.480
I need to be aware of what
items on my WBS that,

302
00:17:25.480 --> 00:17:30.360
if they slip, if they go longer than
I think they're supposed to go.

303
00:17:30.360 --> 00:17:34.190
I need to be cognizant of those so that
I'm looking at all my project plans and

304
00:17:34.190 --> 00:17:35.600
I've got those, maybe in red.

305
00:17:35.600 --> 00:17:39.000
A lot of times,
critical path is demonstrated in red.

306
00:17:39.000 --> 00:17:41.115
Just so I stay aware when I
get there in the morning.

307
00:17:41.115 --> 00:17:45.011
It's like, okay, I've got this to do,
I've got this to do, I've got this to do.

308
00:17:45.011 --> 00:17:47.679
But, wait a second, these three red task,

309
00:17:47.679 --> 00:17:51.013
they have to happen or
those projects are gonna fall behind.

310
00:17:51.013 --> 00:17:55.630
>> So maybe you could modify your priority
levels because Agile is so flexible.

311
00:17:55.630 --> 00:17:57.800
>> Absolutely, absolutely.

312
00:17:57.800 --> 00:17:59.170
And then, staggering the projects,

313
00:17:59.170 --> 00:18:01.930
I always think this is kind
of funny when I read this.

314
00:18:01.930 --> 00:18:04.748
Because, yeah, in a perfect world,
[LAUGH] I'd stagger my projects.

315
00:18:04.748 --> 00:18:07.408
>> [LAUGH] Exactly.

316
00:18:07.408 --> 00:18:11.487
>> And then it talks about,
report the buffers, and

317
00:18:11.487 --> 00:18:15.189
buffers are just what
it kind of sounds like.

318
00:18:15.189 --> 00:18:20.950
I wanna give myself, Eli calls it safety
time, and all that means is extra time.

319
00:18:20.950 --> 00:18:24.570
I'm trying to give myself extra time,
and then manage those buffers.

320
00:18:24.570 --> 00:18:29.930
So I've got downtime, I've got safety
time, what am I gonna do in that downtime?

321
00:18:29.930 --> 00:18:32.290
I mean what can I do that's productive for
other things?

322
00:18:32.290 --> 00:18:37.027
I know we all have it tendency to
schedule ourselves up a little

323
00:18:37.027 --> 00:18:39.480
bit more than we need to.

324
00:18:39.480 --> 00:18:42.884
So it's saying, hey, watch that.

325
00:18:42.884 --> 00:18:45.180
Make sure that you build some time in for
safety.

326
00:18:45.180 --> 00:18:48.860
You build in some buffers so
that if things don't work exactly the way

327
00:18:48.860 --> 00:18:53.690
you want them to work,
you've got some time to re-strategize.

328
00:18:53.690 --> 00:18:55.560
>> Okay, all right.

329
00:18:55.560 --> 00:18:58.330
So we've seen our theory
of our constraints.

330
00:18:58.330 --> 00:19:01.060
We've seen the types of
constraints that are available.

331
00:19:01.060 --> 00:19:03.810
We've looked at managing
multiple projects.

332
00:19:03.810 --> 00:19:09.820
We also thought about our different
reasons as to why a project would fail.

333
00:19:09.820 --> 00:19:13.625
But are there any other contributing
factors that we should be aware of,

334
00:19:13.625 --> 00:19:14.950
Dr Stern?

335
00:19:14.950 --> 00:19:19.220
>> Well, actually, I'd like to go back
to my slide deck, cuz are a couple.

336
00:19:19.220 --> 00:19:22.080
I think these are pretty intuitive ones.

337
00:19:22.080 --> 00:19:25.650
However, one of the reasons that
projects fail that are very common

338
00:19:25.650 --> 00:19:27.520
is goal and vision.

339
00:19:27.520 --> 00:19:33.280
We just have a different idea of what
we're trying to include in our scope.

340
00:19:33.280 --> 00:19:37.010
One of my favorite books is,
Why Smart Executives Fail, and

341
00:19:37.010 --> 00:19:42.410
they have an entire chapter devoted to
brilliantly fulfilling the wrong mission.

342
00:19:42.410 --> 00:19:44.259
So I think that that happens sometimes.

343
00:19:45.370 --> 00:19:48.970
Another reason, and
this is another common, intuitive one, but

344
00:19:48.970 --> 00:19:54.160
we don't really discuss it a lot,
is leadership and governance.

345
00:19:54.160 --> 00:19:57.370
So, leadership would be
how the project is led,

346
00:19:58.390 --> 00:20:01.950
governance would be kind
of how it's managed, right?

347
00:20:01.950 --> 00:20:04.140
And a lot of times it's easy.

348
00:20:04.140 --> 00:20:08.352
And then, finally, another reason, and
that just happens to be our next topic.

349
00:20:08.352 --> 00:20:14.109
A lot of times, the reason projects fail
is because they aren't planned properly,

350
00:20:14.109 --> 00:20:17.200
or they're not tracked properly, or both.

351
00:20:19.060 --> 00:20:23.730
So I think I'd like to end with this
last slide, which is Parkinson's Law.

352
00:20:23.730 --> 00:20:27.160
I've heard this all my life,
I didn't realize it was Parkinson's Law.

353
00:20:27.160 --> 00:20:31.480
And it says,
work expands to fill the time available.

354
00:20:31.480 --> 00:20:34.630
So you wanna be very careful
with your project planning and

355
00:20:34.630 --> 00:20:37.150
tracking, which, like I said,
is what we talk about next.

356
00:20:37.150 --> 00:20:40.087
>> I know, you think about,
definitely is applicable to my life.

357
00:20:40.087 --> 00:20:42.997
I think, I'm becoming really efficient or
good at something,

358
00:20:42.997 --> 00:20:45.665
and then I find myself picking
up little things here and there.

359
00:20:45.665 --> 00:20:50.270
And I'm always just so busy, but
I definitely think that is very true.

360
00:20:50.270 --> 00:20:53.430
You're right, I think we are out of time,
so we'll go ahead and wrap up here.

361
00:20:53.430 --> 00:20:54.660
It's a perfect place.

362
00:20:54.660 --> 00:20:56.200
We'll pick back up with Parkinson's Law,

363
00:20:56.200 --> 00:21:00.140
and I think we'll go ahead and
sign off for this particular show.

364
00:21:00.140 --> 00:21:03.540
And just as a reminder,
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

365
00:21:03.540 --> 00:21:07.440
>> And I'm Dr. Terra Vanzant-Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

366
00:21:07.440 --> 00:21:10.312
>> And
we'll see you very soon here at ITPRO.TV.

367
00:21:10.312 --> 00:21:17.560
[MUSIC]

368
00:21:17.560 --> 00:21:22.810
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: This episode covers project tracking techniques and introduces you to the Lean and Agile Project Management lifecycle. Specifically, you will examine the Selection phase. In this phase the project purpose should be determined to verify the strategic fit. Objectives should be determined in addition to the scope, terms of reference, the draft schedule as well as the budget estimate.
episodes.title: Session 6
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.940 --> 00:00:06.373
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.373 --> 00:00:08.255
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.255 --> 00:00:10.010
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:10.010 --> 00:00:16.680
>> Welcome to your Lean and
Agile Project Management Series.

5
00:00:16.680 --> 00:00:19.290
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:19.290 --> 00:00:24.420
In the last episode, we were looking at
things like our types of constraints,

7
00:00:24.420 --> 00:00:28.110
and we also looked at
managing multiple projects.

8
00:00:28.110 --> 00:00:31.610
We also looked at reasons
as to why projects fail.

9
00:00:31.610 --> 00:00:34.910
I believe we left off
looking at Parkinson's law.

10
00:00:34.910 --> 00:00:37.720
So I think that's a good place
to go ahead and pick up.

11
00:00:37.720 --> 00:00:40.460
In studios today we have Dr.
Terra Vanzant-Stern.

12
00:00:40.460 --> 00:00:42.680
And thank you for
joining us today, doctor.

13
00:00:42.680 --> 00:00:44.740
>> Thank you, Cherokee, I appreciate it.

14
00:00:44.740 --> 00:00:47.360
>> So, do you think that's a good place
just to kind of pick up and recap?

15
00:00:47.360 --> 00:00:48.285
>> I do, absolutely.

16
00:00:49.803 --> 00:00:53.050
So, when we're thinking
about project failure,

17
00:00:53.050 --> 00:00:57.210
one of the things that can happen
is the way we track our projects.

18
00:00:57.210 --> 00:00:59.740
Because we can do a great job planning.

19
00:00:59.740 --> 00:01:02.430
But then maybe the tracking goes awry.

20
00:01:02.430 --> 00:01:06.470
And so there's some difference in
traditional versus Agile project tracking.

21
00:01:06.470 --> 00:01:08.290
And that's what I think
we'll talk about next.

22
00:01:08.290 --> 00:01:08.790
>> Okay, great.

23
00:01:10.250 --> 00:01:14.120
>> So the first thing that you wanna
remember is that in project planning and

24
00:01:14.120 --> 00:01:18.850
project tracking, there's formal,
there's informal and

25
00:01:18.850 --> 00:01:20.940
there's visual versus the outline, right.

26
00:01:20.940 --> 00:01:25.620
And so when we say formal,
a lot of times I kinda think of

27
00:01:25.620 --> 00:01:29.850
MS project software but there's also
other project software out there.

28
00:01:29.850 --> 00:01:33.620
When I'm thinking informal,
I'm just tracking on a spreadsheet.

29
00:01:33.620 --> 00:01:38.040
And when I'm thinking visual versus
an outline, we could have a chart or

30
00:01:38.040 --> 00:01:42.670
a graph or a process flow map,
or not really a process,

31
00:01:42.670 --> 00:01:47.270
a project map that shows us,
or we could have that WBS.

32
00:01:47.270 --> 00:01:53.420
So a lot of that depends on how
the item that I pick depends

33
00:01:53.420 --> 00:01:57.790
on how much of commitment do I want, so-
>> And Probably also what the company is

34
00:01:57.790 --> 00:01:58.540
already using-
>> Exactly.

35
00:01:58.540 --> 00:02:00.760
>> If they're kind of married to an idea.

36
00:02:00.760 --> 00:02:01.360
>> Exactly.

37
00:02:01.360 --> 00:02:03.350
That's a really good point, Cherokee.

38
00:02:03.350 --> 00:02:06.910
Because what they're using,
that's what I wanna use too, right?

39
00:02:06.910 --> 00:02:11.780
So the more formal types of
project management software

40
00:02:11.780 --> 00:02:15.359
really do take a committment, but
they can do some really cool stuff.

41
00:02:16.640 --> 00:02:20.630
So here's an example of different
ways I might track, you'll see here,

42
00:02:20.630 --> 00:02:22.580
that's kind of a visual tracking method.

43
00:02:23.680 --> 00:02:28.200
Another example of visual tracking
method is the Gantt chart, and

44
00:02:28.200 --> 00:02:33.060
this is basically taking the WBS and
just putting a picture to it.

45
00:02:33.060 --> 00:02:39.710
You'll notice along top there where
it has the date, generally speaking,

46
00:02:39.710 --> 00:02:44.910
Gantt charts are going to have some
kind of time-bound thing on that line.

47
00:02:44.910 --> 00:02:46.790
It could be even by hours.

48
00:02:46.790 --> 00:02:48.600
>> Okay.
>> Or by quarters.

49
00:02:48.600 --> 00:02:53.160
And on the left hand side I'm
gonna have my WBS, basically.

50
00:02:53.160 --> 00:02:55.830
Now this one doesn't have
the numbers associated with it but

51
00:02:55.830 --> 00:03:01.290
a lot of times your project software will
just go ahead and renumber, for example,

52
00:03:01.290 --> 00:03:06.580
if I wanna add a 1.2.3,
I can go in there and renumber it.

53
00:03:06.580 --> 00:03:10.630
I can do a Gantt chart on Excel,
I'm just doing it in a manual way.

54
00:03:10.630 --> 00:03:13.710
>> Yeah, if we look at things
like Microsoft Project

55
00:03:13.710 --> 00:03:18.840
it looks very similar to Excel but just
with a ton more features, it seems like.

56
00:03:18.840 --> 00:03:20.100
>> Yeah, absolutely,

57
00:03:20.100 --> 00:03:24.710
and in project software you can add
things like schedules and all kinds

58
00:03:24.710 --> 00:03:29.340
of different things that you have to just
put on manually on your spreadsheet.

59
00:03:29.340 --> 00:03:33.190
So, one of the things that we wanna
think about is our project plan,

60
00:03:33.190 --> 00:03:37.650
which should be done in a WBS fashion
if we're in a traditional environment.

61
00:03:37.650 --> 00:03:40.395
Should be a living document.

62
00:03:40.395 --> 00:03:45.090
We wanna make sure that we're always going
back and checking it and tracking, like,

63
00:03:45.090 --> 00:03:49.275
we said this task is gonna take three
months, how long does it take really?

64
00:03:49.275 --> 00:03:52.981
So, when we're in the agile environment,

65
00:03:52.981 --> 00:03:58.190
there is a tendency as opposed to
using a work breakdown structure.

66
00:03:58.190 --> 00:04:02.688
And having the Gantt chart associated
with that using a burndown chart.

67
00:04:02.688 --> 00:04:07.070
So a burndown chart, I have the body
of work that I'm trying to accomplish.

68
00:04:07.070 --> 00:04:10.840
And it's also time-bound
usually on the x-axis, and

69
00:04:10.840 --> 00:04:13.990
as time goes on it just
shows that the work is done.

70
00:04:13.990 --> 00:04:16.340
Does that make sense?

71
00:04:16.340 --> 00:04:17.790
>> Yes.

72
00:04:17.790 --> 00:04:22.630
>> Now how communication is handled in
a traditional versus agile environment

73
00:04:22.630 --> 00:04:26.120
is also important if we wanna make
sure that our project is successful.

74
00:04:27.270 --> 00:04:31.970
So, in a traditional project management
environment the project manager

75
00:04:31.970 --> 00:04:36.960
watches the process and
checks the deliverable being made.

76
00:04:36.960 --> 00:04:40.060
And they do meetings and
agendas and memos and email,

77
00:04:40.060 --> 00:04:41.730
that's kind of
the traditional way we do it.

78
00:04:41.730 --> 00:04:44.700
>> And they would normally
even just have an approved

79
00:04:44.700 --> 00:04:47.400
method of communication as well,
like approved methods.

80
00:04:47.400 --> 00:04:51.420
>> Absolutely, and in the agile
environments, in a perfect world, they

81
00:04:51.420 --> 00:04:56.550
have daily standup meetings which is what
you were talking about that ITProTV does.

82
00:04:56.550 --> 00:04:59.980
Now, in a true Agile environment,
they ask the same questions.

83
00:04:59.980 --> 00:05:01.910
What did you do yesterday?

84
00:05:01.910 --> 00:05:03.530
What will you do today?

85
00:05:03.530 --> 00:05:06.620
And what's in your way, right?

86
00:05:06.620 --> 00:05:10.690
And again, we say standup meeting,
the concept behind that standup

87
00:05:10.690 --> 00:05:13.120
meeting is it's quick, and
we're not gonna get relaxed, and

88
00:05:13.120 --> 00:05:15.800
we're not gonna let this
meeting go on forever, right?

89
00:05:15.800 --> 00:05:20.480
>> Exactly, and here at ITProTV, They even
kind of condense it a little bit more.

90
00:05:20.480 --> 00:05:24.630
The main topic that we cover
is what we will do today, and

91
00:05:24.630 --> 00:05:29.300
if there's anything really cool or
significant that we did the previous day,

92
00:05:29.300 --> 00:05:34.240
or maybe something that just had a really
big impact on the organization, or

93
00:05:34.240 --> 00:05:35.480
if there are any obstacles.

94
00:05:35.480 --> 00:05:39.310
Those are kind of like too optional,
but the middle one is a must for us.

95
00:05:39.310 --> 00:05:40.740
>> Perfect, perfect.

96
00:05:40.740 --> 00:05:44.790
And you know what makes this different
from a traditional environment is that

97
00:05:44.790 --> 00:05:49.590
a lot of times these meetings are handled
by a weekly or a bi-weekly basis.

98
00:05:49.590 --> 00:05:54.390
There isn't really a, everyday we touch
each other and see what's going on.

99
00:05:55.730 --> 00:06:00.240
So Scrum, which is the meeting,
it's a Agile process that focuses on

100
00:06:00.240 --> 00:06:03.470
delivering the highest business value
in the shortest period of time.

101
00:06:03.470 --> 00:06:06.110
So if you were thinking
of Scrum in 100 words,

102
00:06:06.110 --> 00:06:08.720
these are kind of the high level points.

103
00:06:08.720 --> 00:06:12.510
The business sets a priority,
our teams are self managed,

104
00:06:12.510 --> 00:06:15.790
every two weeks to a month
everyone can see the real work.

105
00:06:15.790 --> 00:06:16.470
Right?

106
00:06:16.470 --> 00:06:18.900
So this is just a handout slide.

107
00:06:18.900 --> 00:06:23.020
I just wanted you to see kind of
an example of some stuff that's in your

108
00:06:23.020 --> 00:06:26.190
student package if you were
studying to take the exam.

109
00:06:26.190 --> 00:06:26.690
>> Okay.

110
00:06:28.650 --> 00:06:34.725
>> Now Sprints, what happens with
Sprints is that they're a series.

111
00:06:34.725 --> 00:06:37.260
And usually sprints are two to four weeks.

112
00:06:37.260 --> 00:06:39.880
Most of the sprints that
I've been participating in

113
00:06:39.880 --> 00:06:42.240
are closer to the two week side.

114
00:06:42.240 --> 00:06:47.750
And the idea is that I'm gonna do
this body of work in this Sprint.

115
00:06:49.030 --> 00:06:51.570
And during the Sprint,
whatever we're agreed to,

116
00:06:51.570 --> 00:06:55.662
everyone's just gonna stay
laser-focused on that.

117
00:06:55.662 --> 00:07:01.010
Now, between Sprints we
can be more flexible and

118
00:07:01.010 --> 00:07:02.890
come up with the next body of work.

119
00:07:02.890 --> 00:07:06.470
Do you guys do Sprints here at ITPro.TV?

120
00:07:06.470 --> 00:07:10.800
>> I think for
the host it's a little more scheduled,

121
00:07:10.800 --> 00:07:13.960
we go far out with our scheduling,
or at least we try to.

122
00:07:13.960 --> 00:07:17.030
But on the development team,
I'm pretty sure they do.

123
00:07:17.030 --> 00:07:21.330
>> Okay, so
there are those daily Scrub meetings where

124
00:07:21.330 --> 00:07:25.690
you have those three questions, but
then also the projects work in Sprints.

125
00:07:25.690 --> 00:07:29.050
So for that two or
four week period of time,

126
00:07:29.050 --> 00:07:34.470
typically people just stay focused on
that and there's not a lot of changes.

127
00:07:34.470 --> 00:07:37.320
So everything's done
kind of in iterations.

128
00:07:37.320 --> 00:07:39.060
Do you guys do Sprints, as well?

129
00:07:39.060 --> 00:07:41.845
>> I'm not really sure
about other departments.

130
00:07:41.845 --> 00:07:45.805
Perhaps the development team does,
but as a host,

131
00:07:45.805 --> 00:07:50.785
it's normally pretty scheduled far
out when we try to adhere to that.

132
00:07:50.785 --> 00:07:55.059
And so it's not anything that would be
needing to be addressed in a short period

133
00:07:55.059 --> 00:07:55.593
of time.

134
00:07:55.593 --> 00:07:59.160
Unless we have a certain event or
party or something coming up,

135
00:07:59.160 --> 00:08:02.340
then we might kind of work
together as a team in that way.

136
00:08:02.340 --> 00:08:05.253
So, not in a structured format.

137
00:08:05.253 --> 00:08:06.637
Okay, thank you, Cherokee.

138
00:08:06.637 --> 00:08:11.213
I have noticed here at ITProTV
that they do recognize kind of

139
00:08:11.213 --> 00:08:13.510
the Agile work environment.

140
00:08:13.510 --> 00:08:17.680
Everything's very open,
where people can talk to one another.

141
00:08:17.680 --> 00:08:22.020
So there are a lot of Agile principles
that ITProTV does recognize.

142
00:08:22.020 --> 00:08:27.570
So now we're gonna go back to
that Project Life Cycle slide.

143
00:08:27.570 --> 00:08:30.340
We talked about that in
one of our first sessions.

144
00:08:30.340 --> 00:08:34.860
What we did with the Project Life Cycle
is in order to study Lean and

145
00:08:34.860 --> 00:08:38.300
Agile project management,
we did a composite.

146
00:08:38.300 --> 00:08:43.760
So what this means is that in the PMBOCK,
PRINCE2, and

147
00:08:43.760 --> 00:08:48.570
the new ISO standard, they all have their
take on the project management life cycle.

148
00:08:48.570 --> 00:08:51.580
So we call ours just
the Project Life Cycle.

149
00:08:51.580 --> 00:08:55.520
And we took all the key things and
put it into four phases.

150
00:08:55.520 --> 00:08:58.317
In some literature on project
management in general,

151
00:08:58.317 --> 00:09:01.722
even if you're looking at bodies
of knowledge outside those three

152
00:09:01.722 --> 00:09:06.244
primary ones, some are moving towards six
or eight cycles, some are, I think, four.

153
00:09:06.244 --> 00:09:11.050
I think we have the least
amount of cycles possible.

154
00:09:11.050 --> 00:09:14.848
But we just thought it was easier to
digest and the things that are in these

155
00:09:14.848 --> 00:09:18.560
four categories are things that
everyone agrees needs to be done.

156
00:09:18.560 --> 00:09:20.380
>> Okay.
>> So in some bodies of knowledge,

157
00:09:20.380 --> 00:09:21.920
you're gonna see some extra things,

158
00:09:21.920 --> 00:09:25.180
or you're gonna seem some things that
are fleshed out a little bit more But

159
00:09:25.180 --> 00:09:27.540
everyone agrees that these
things have to happen.

160
00:09:27.540 --> 00:09:30.720
We just broke them into
these four categories.

161
00:09:30.720 --> 00:09:32.780
So the first category is selection.

162
00:09:32.780 --> 00:09:34.550
And we're gonna look at that.

163
00:09:34.550 --> 00:09:39.240
And in selection, what we're looking for
is we're looking for strategic fit.

164
00:09:39.240 --> 00:09:40.670
We're looking for scope.

165
00:09:40.670 --> 00:09:44.490
We're looking for draft schedules,
budget estimates.

166
00:09:44.490 --> 00:09:49.440
We're just trying to select what
is the biggest bang for our buck?

167
00:09:49.440 --> 00:09:51.700
There might be a number of
different things going on.

168
00:09:51.700 --> 00:09:56.180
And we just want to make sure that
we're working on the right thing.

169
00:09:56.180 --> 00:09:58.290
So when we're looking at Lean and

170
00:09:58.290 --> 00:10:02.640
Agile tools that are outside
the typical project management toolbox,

171
00:10:02.640 --> 00:10:07.310
cuz we're trying to apply Lean and Agile
tools to what's already there, right?

172
00:10:07.310 --> 00:10:10.430
There's a number of tools that we can
look at that are not typically covered

173
00:10:10.430 --> 00:10:13.390
in project management bodies of knowledge.

174
00:10:13.390 --> 00:10:15.270
And one of those are rapid
improvement events.

175
00:10:15.270 --> 00:10:17.190
So we're gonna talk
a little bit about that.

176
00:10:17.190 --> 00:10:19.119
Standard work.

177
00:10:19.119 --> 00:10:23.664
Root cause analysis tools,
smart goals, and FMEA.

178
00:10:25.717 --> 00:10:29.870
So the first one we're gonna talk about
is we're gonna talk about RCA tools.

179
00:10:29.870 --> 00:10:32.960
Cuz that's easy and
we've already sort of covered it.

180
00:10:32.960 --> 00:10:35.730
So one of the ways that
we can get to the root

181
00:10:35.730 --> 00:10:39.070
cause is by doing a fishbone analysis.

182
00:10:39.070 --> 00:10:42.270
We put the problem in
the head of the fish.

183
00:10:42.270 --> 00:10:47.140
And then of course all the big bones that
play into that are the major factors.

184
00:10:47.140 --> 00:10:50.070
And what we're looking for, which is
kind of a reminder from one of our

185
00:10:50.070 --> 00:10:52.960
other sessions, is we're looking for
those smaller bones.

186
00:10:52.960 --> 00:10:57.000
Because the theory is the root
cause is probably going to come

187
00:10:57.000 --> 00:10:58.880
from one of those smaller bones.

188
00:10:58.880 --> 00:11:03.490
When we're in the selection process,
another way that we can use the fishbone

189
00:11:03.490 --> 00:11:09.480
to help us in selection is to just kind of
go through different ideas for projects.

190
00:11:09.480 --> 00:11:11.860
And then look at what
are the contributing bones?

191
00:11:11.860 --> 00:11:14.240
In other words, what kind of resources?

192
00:11:14.240 --> 00:11:16.220
What kind of time?

193
00:11:16.220 --> 00:11:19.280
What kind of cost would
be involved to fix that?

194
00:11:19.280 --> 00:11:21.950
So we could have like
a brainstorming session.

195
00:11:21.950 --> 00:11:24.870
And at this point,
we're not looking for root cause,

196
00:11:24.870 --> 00:11:27.570
we're just looking for ideas for projects.

197
00:11:27.570 --> 00:11:31.990
And those big bones are gonna just give us
all kinds of information on how doable is

198
00:11:31.990 --> 00:11:32.950
it, right?

199
00:11:34.545 --> 00:11:39.475
So, I wanna also remind everyone
that you can combine tools.

200
00:11:39.475 --> 00:11:43.295
That's a very Lean and
Agile way to manage projects.

201
00:11:43.295 --> 00:11:48.785
So in this case, this particular fish
bone diagram includes some metrics.

202
00:11:48.785 --> 00:11:53.715
The topic of this one is understand and
reduce risk in factors of older adults.

203
00:11:53.715 --> 00:11:57.230
I'm not really sure where we picked that
one but we're really just showing you

204
00:11:57.230 --> 00:12:02.230
as an example that one way to be Lean and
Agile is to think about those seven tools.

205
00:12:03.260 --> 00:12:06.240
We call them seven tools of
quality in the Lean world.

206
00:12:06.240 --> 00:12:07.830
But in the project management world,

207
00:12:07.830 --> 00:12:11.530
they're called the seven
analytical problem-solving tools.

208
00:12:11.530 --> 00:12:14.400
So which is a real mouthful,
that's not very Lean.

209
00:12:14.400 --> 00:12:17.380
But just kinda keep in mind,
there's no reason you can't combine them.

210
00:12:17.380 --> 00:12:19.200
That's a real Lean way to do it.

211
00:12:19.200 --> 00:12:22.751
On this particular example, in addition
to showing you the fishbone diagram,

212
00:12:22.751 --> 00:12:24.558
there's all these kinda cool metrics.

213
00:12:26.636 --> 00:12:30.720
So when we're working an Agile selection.

214
00:12:30.720 --> 00:12:35.280
So keep in mind right now we're talking
about that first phase of the model.

215
00:12:35.280 --> 00:12:37.579
There's a lot more face
to face communication.

216
00:12:37.579 --> 00:12:39.297
There's a lot more discussion.

217
00:12:39.297 --> 00:12:42.390
There's less initial documentation.

218
00:12:42.390 --> 00:12:46.413
There's more risk because of that.

219
00:12:46.413 --> 00:12:50.560
In theory, Agile would be

220
00:12:50.560 --> 00:12:54.570
paying more attention to the theory
of constraints that we looked at.

221
00:12:54.570 --> 00:12:58.960
And they're also, in theory, paying more
attention to voice of the customer and

222
00:12:58.960 --> 00:13:00.620
voice of the employee.

223
00:13:00.620 --> 00:13:04.620
So if I'm in a traditional project
management environment, and

224
00:13:04.620 --> 00:13:07.650
what I'm kind of used to is one or
two people sitting in a room,

225
00:13:07.650 --> 00:13:11.390
or even just myself going I think
this is a good idea for a project.

226
00:13:11.390 --> 00:13:15.430
A lot of times people in upper management
are accused of that all the time.

227
00:13:15.430 --> 00:13:17.020
That they come up with an idea for

228
00:13:17.020 --> 00:13:20.730
a project without considering voice of
the employee and voice of the customer.

229
00:13:20.730 --> 00:13:23.800
They're just thinking this
would be a really good idea.

230
00:13:23.800 --> 00:13:28.060
So here are some Agile ways
that you can integrate

231
00:13:28.060 --> 00:13:31.020
into the selection
process of your project.

232
00:13:31.020 --> 00:13:33.850
And certainly more face
to face communication

233
00:13:33.850 --> 00:13:36.250
plays into the voice of the employee.

234
00:13:36.250 --> 00:13:40.840
And that less initial documentation,
sometimes that

235
00:13:40.840 --> 00:13:45.190
really works better in a project because
you might not be on the right track.

236
00:13:46.860 --> 00:13:51.370
So as we move forward, a reminder,
we're still in selection.

237
00:13:51.370 --> 00:13:54.468
We're talking about the selection
part of the Project Life Cycle.

238
00:13:54.468 --> 00:13:56.950
The composite, right?

239
00:13:56.950 --> 00:13:59.630
So if I was looking at the whole thing,
this would be the whole thing.

240
00:13:59.630 --> 00:14:01.590
I'm in the selection part.

241
00:14:01.590 --> 00:14:03.360
Still in this selection part.

242
00:14:03.360 --> 00:14:07.920
Okay, so another thing that you might
want to think about in selection

243
00:14:07.920 --> 00:14:12.380
is if you could do a rapid
improvement event, a Kaizen event.

244
00:14:12.380 --> 00:14:14.650
Now, in project management environments,

245
00:14:14.650 --> 00:14:21.230
a lot of times that Kaizen event would
take the form of a hypothetical PDCA.

246
00:14:21.230 --> 00:14:24.990
So a PDCA, remember,
was Plan, Do, Check, Act.

247
00:14:24.990 --> 00:14:28.800
So I'm trying to figure out
what do I wanna work on.

248
00:14:28.800 --> 00:14:30.590
I'm in project selection.

249
00:14:30.590 --> 00:14:33.820
So a way I could use a Lean tool, and

250
00:14:33.820 --> 00:14:37.540
I'm still being Agile cuz I'm doing
this face-to-face communication.

251
00:14:37.540 --> 00:14:39.700
I would bring everyone
in a room together and

252
00:14:39.700 --> 00:14:43.270
I would say okay, here's a problem
that we're gonna work on, right?

253
00:14:43.270 --> 00:14:44.530
And so I would mock plan.

254
00:14:44.530 --> 00:14:47.200
I wouldn't maybe go
through the whole plan.

255
00:14:47.200 --> 00:14:51.690
I would say what could happen when I
execute, what could happen when I check?

256
00:14:51.690 --> 00:14:55.575
Is there anything from this
hypothetical PDCA that I could learn?

257
00:14:55.575 --> 00:15:00.025
I could also approach it
as a real live project.

258
00:15:00.025 --> 00:15:03.885
I could bring people in the room and
say look we just gotta plan really fast.

259
00:15:03.885 --> 00:15:08.415
And then we're gonna have to assign
someone to execute this project and then

260
00:15:08.415 --> 00:15:12.485
we'll assign someone else to come in and
check to see if it's doing well, right?

261
00:15:12.485 --> 00:15:17.275
And then we will move on to deciding
if we want to act, abandon, or adapt.

262
00:15:17.275 --> 00:15:22.750
So rapid improvement events sometimes,
in the selection process, we

263
00:15:22.750 --> 00:15:26.580
wanna step back and say is this a problem
that we could just knock out right away?

264
00:15:26.580 --> 00:15:30.540
Is this something we could just go
out to the manufacturing floor or

265
00:15:30.540 --> 00:15:33.745
bring the right players into the room and
just plan it out quickly?

266
00:15:33.745 --> 00:15:38.100
It's not a typical
project management tool.

267
00:15:38.100 --> 00:15:40.110
Now when we're in selection,

268
00:15:40.110 --> 00:15:43.850
we want to end up with something
called the Y statement.

269
00:15:43.850 --> 00:15:48.620
When we're on the Lean side,
the Y statement is always the activity

270
00:15:48.620 --> 00:15:51.830
that I wanna make better,
faster, more cost effective.

271
00:15:51.830 --> 00:15:56.030
In project management, that Y statement
could be more like a problem statement.

272
00:15:56.030 --> 00:15:57.910
What is it that I'm trying to do?

273
00:15:57.910 --> 00:16:01.942
And the formula that I'm going to show
you works whether you're trying to do

274
00:16:01.942 --> 00:16:05.798
a process improvement or if you're
just trying to do a regular project.

275
00:16:05.798 --> 00:16:10.864
So let's say if you were tasked with
your boss to do a project, this is what

276
00:16:10.864 --> 00:16:16.740
they want you to do and they want you
to go write to the project plan, right?

277
00:16:16.740 --> 00:16:23.130
So, before you write the project plan, you
might wanna consider the Y=f(x) formula.

278
00:16:23.130 --> 00:16:26.840
So they're telling you the project,
that would be represented by the big Y,

279
00:16:26.840 --> 00:16:28.770
this is the positive outcome.

280
00:16:28.770 --> 00:16:32.490
Keep in mind if I'm only in a Lean
environment, that positive outcome is

281
00:16:32.490 --> 00:16:36.540
always going to be the activity I wanna
make better, faster, more cost effective.

282
00:16:36.540 --> 00:16:40.100
But in regular project management,
it's just what they're asking me to do.

283
00:16:40.100 --> 00:16:43.240
Doesn't really matter,
it could be from scratch, right?

284
00:16:43.240 --> 00:16:45.700
It could be something that's
never been done before.

285
00:16:45.700 --> 00:16:50.410
So the next thing that I want to do is,
I want to consider the x's.

286
00:16:50.410 --> 00:16:55.330
And that x represents all the inputs
that have to go in to make that

287
00:16:55.330 --> 00:16:56.970
project successful.

288
00:16:56.970 --> 00:16:59.930
So I wanna sit down before I
even do the project plan, and

289
00:16:59.930 --> 00:17:05.000
I wanna think, do I have all the inputs
necessary, are they available?

290
00:17:05.000 --> 00:17:08.690
Because if those inputs are not available,

291
00:17:08.690 --> 00:17:12.180
I'm not gonna be able to achieve
this project successfully right?

292
00:17:12.180 --> 00:17:14.376
>> Right.
>> And that's the conversation that I'm

293
00:17:14.376 --> 00:17:16.548
gonna wanna have with my project manager.

294
00:17:16.548 --> 00:17:20.255
>> And you've given us some really great
ideas before, where you take things like

295
00:17:20.255 --> 00:17:23.649
your WBS, or maybe even the project
charter, and really outline that.

296
00:17:23.649 --> 00:17:26.826
And say look,
this process currently is not capable,

297
00:17:26.826 --> 00:17:28.790
what do you want me to modify?

298
00:17:28.790 --> 00:17:32.320
Then kind of put the ball back in their
court, or your supervisor's court.

299
00:17:32.320 --> 00:17:36.600
>> Exactly, and that's a perfect example
because this is something that I can also

300
00:17:36.600 --> 00:17:38.130
use for capability.

301
00:17:38.130 --> 00:17:42.200
If I go one step further,
I'm missing these inputs,

302
00:17:42.200 --> 00:17:44.340
so that's the conversation I need to have.

303
00:17:44.340 --> 00:17:48.330
But I go one step further, maybe those
inputs aren't functioning properly.

304
00:17:48.330 --> 00:17:51.910
So I have them available,
so maybe I have resources,

305
00:17:51.910 --> 00:17:53.960
I have human resource available.

306
00:17:53.960 --> 00:17:56.530
But they need training, so

307
00:17:56.530 --> 00:18:00.100
my human resources are not functioning
well because they need training.

308
00:18:00.100 --> 00:18:01.690
>> Okay.
>> Or they need more hours,

309
00:18:01.690 --> 00:18:05.810
or they need more time, right, so
I'm in that selection process.

310
00:18:05.810 --> 00:18:10.930
And a good Lean or
Agile tool that I could use,

311
00:18:10.930 --> 00:18:15.480
is this Y=f(x) to try to figure out
what it is I should be working on.

312
00:18:15.480 --> 00:18:16.290
>> Okay.

313
00:18:16.290 --> 00:18:18.022
>> Then finally, I'm in selection,

314
00:18:18.022 --> 00:18:21.035
I'm trying to figure out what
the heck I should be working on.

315
00:18:21.035 --> 00:18:25.427
Another tool that's kind of cool when
I'm trying to select the project, and

316
00:18:25.427 --> 00:18:29.548
there could be some projects on the table
that I run through this as well,

317
00:18:29.548 --> 00:18:32.170
is something called FMEA Thinking.

318
00:18:32.170 --> 00:18:34.810
Now, if you're really
interested in FMEA Thinking,

319
00:18:34.810 --> 00:18:38.940
it's covered in depth in our
Lean Six Sigma Green Belt program.

320
00:18:38.940 --> 00:18:43.530
The idea behind FMEA Thinking is that
there's actually a form, that a lot of you

321
00:18:43.530 --> 00:18:48.980
may already be familiar with, called the
FMEA failure mode effect analyses form.

322
00:18:48.980 --> 00:18:52.680
And typically it's used
to record information.

323
00:18:52.680 --> 00:18:56.566
There is a belief in Lean and
Agile project, just Lean and

324
00:18:56.566 --> 00:19:01.547
Agile environments period, that
sometimes the psychology behind the form

325
00:19:01.547 --> 00:19:04.950
can lead us to some
good critical thinking.

326
00:19:04.950 --> 00:19:10.200
So this is pulled out of the middle of
the form and it says, what's the activity?

327
00:19:10.200 --> 00:19:13.490
What's the potential failure,
what's the effect of the failure,

328
00:19:13.490 --> 00:19:15.730
what's the cause of the failure?

329
00:19:15.730 --> 00:19:18.270
And what current processes are in control?

330
00:19:18.270 --> 00:19:21.420
Now when you're in the Lean and
Six Sigma environment,

331
00:19:21.420 --> 00:19:26.350
and you're trying to make process
improvements, that last column is key.

332
00:19:26.350 --> 00:19:29.920
Because if there's nothing in place to
keep the bad things from happening,

333
00:19:29.920 --> 00:19:32.480
that's an automatic process improvement.

334
00:19:32.480 --> 00:19:37.520
When you're using this same model for

335
00:19:37.520 --> 00:19:41.710
project management,
you're using it more as a risk model.

336
00:19:41.710 --> 00:19:45.160
Now certainly you would want to know
if there's some controls in place, but

337
00:19:45.160 --> 00:19:49.620
I have the activity, what's the potential
failure, which is just the opposite.

338
00:19:49.620 --> 00:19:51.450
What's the effect of the failure?

339
00:19:51.450 --> 00:19:54.600
I'm going to concentrate
on those causes of failure,

340
00:19:54.600 --> 00:19:57.760
because I'm saying these
are risks to my project.

341
00:19:57.760 --> 00:20:01.850
So let's say my project
was putting gas in my car.

342
00:20:01.850 --> 00:20:03.150
And I didn't put gas, so

343
00:20:03.150 --> 00:20:06.570
the potential failure is there's
no gas in the car, right?

344
00:20:06.570 --> 00:20:09.227
And the potential effect of the failure
is I can't get to work, right?

345
00:20:10.420 --> 00:20:13.846
So what are the causes of those failures?

346
00:20:13.846 --> 00:20:15.650
I might have forgot, right?

347
00:20:15.650 --> 00:20:17.500
>> I don't have enough money to buy gas.

348
00:20:17.500 --> 00:20:20.970
>> I don't have enough money to buy gas,
for sure.

349
00:20:20.970 --> 00:20:22.009
Anything else?

350
00:20:22.009 --> 00:20:26.540
>> I was out in the middle of nowhere,
and there wasn't a gas station nearby.

351
00:20:26.540 --> 00:20:30.340
>> Exactly, so if my project is
to put gas in the car, I mean,

352
00:20:30.340 --> 00:20:31.990
it's a small project, right?

353
00:20:31.990 --> 00:20:34.420
But I don't particularly like
putting gas in my car, and

354
00:20:34.420 --> 00:20:37.030
I'm always really happy
when someone else does it.

355
00:20:37.030 --> 00:20:38.400
But it's one of my projects today,

356
00:20:38.400 --> 00:20:41.270
one of my projects today is
to go get gas in the car.

357
00:20:41.270 --> 00:20:42.290
So one of the things,

358
00:20:42.290 --> 00:20:47.100
if I ran it through an FMEA, I could look
at those potential causes of failure.

359
00:20:47.100 --> 00:20:50.440
And kind of build that into my thinking,
okay, I don't wanna forget.

360
00:20:50.440 --> 00:20:52.970
I don't wanna make sure I'm
too far from the gas station,

361
00:20:52.970 --> 00:20:54.870
out in the middle of nowhere, right?

362
00:20:54.870 --> 00:20:58.670
So that's kind of the thinking,
and we can just do

363
00:20:58.670 --> 00:21:03.060
in our Lean Six Sigma Green Belt class,
we did the brushing teeth one.

364
00:21:03.060 --> 00:21:05.790
>> Yes.
>> And we said our grandchildren or

365
00:21:05.790 --> 00:21:08.845
our children, we're trying to
get them to brush their teeth.

366
00:21:08.845 --> 00:21:09.660
>> Mm-hm.
>> Do you wanna just go

367
00:21:09.660 --> 00:21:10.450
with that one again?

368
00:21:10.450 --> 00:21:11.130
>> Sure.

369
00:21:11.130 --> 00:21:11.730
>> Okay.

370
00:21:11.730 --> 00:21:16.120
So, the function is, our children,
our grandchildren, in my case,

371
00:21:16.120 --> 00:21:17.280
brush their teeth.

372
00:21:17.280 --> 00:21:17.940
>> Yes.
>> And so

373
00:21:17.940 --> 00:21:21.330
the potential failure is the opposite,
the children or

374
00:21:21.330 --> 00:21:23.180
grandchildren didn't brush their teeth.

375
00:21:23.180 --> 00:21:26.680
So what are some of the potential
effects of that failure?

376
00:21:26.680 --> 00:21:32.435
>> So I think we had said cavities,
bad breath, gingivitis.

377
00:21:32.435 --> 00:21:34.655
>> [LAUGH]
>> Those are some pretty bad effects.

378
00:21:34.655 --> 00:21:36.560
[LAUGH]
>> And so what are the causes?

379
00:21:36.560 --> 00:21:40.820
Why wouldn't our children, as many times
as we talk to them, and our grandchildren,

380
00:21:40.820 --> 00:21:42.660
why wouldn't they brush their teeth?

381
00:21:42.660 --> 00:21:47.940
>> Well, they might be watching TV,
or not listening to the adult.

382
00:21:47.940 --> 00:21:49.970
They just think it's busy work or

383
00:21:49.970 --> 00:21:54.120
something, just taking away
from their normal activities.

384
00:21:54.120 --> 00:21:54.780
>> Exactly.
>> I guess, yeah.

385
00:21:54.780 --> 00:21:56.660
>> So
that could be a big cause of failure.

386
00:21:56.660 --> 00:22:00.220
Now, in this case we're gonna go ahead and
look at that current process control,

387
00:22:00.220 --> 00:22:03.220
because Cherokee has
a great process control.

388
00:22:03.220 --> 00:22:06.730
Which means what am I gonna put in
place to keep that from happening?

389
00:22:06.730 --> 00:22:09.160
So you had a great one that you did.

390
00:22:09.160 --> 00:22:12.580
>> Sometimes it can be difficult to
get my kids to bush their teeth.

391
00:22:12.580 --> 00:22:16.710
So a little idea I had was well,
during the holidays,

392
00:22:16.710 --> 00:22:18.730
we have some visitors that come and
see us.

393
00:22:18.730 --> 00:22:21.515
That you guys might even
know about Elf on the Shelf,

394
00:22:21.515 --> 00:22:24.000
that is something that
we do have at our house.

395
00:22:24.000 --> 00:22:27.936
So I figured if I could integrate that,
it might help with this situation.

396
00:22:27.936 --> 00:22:33.070
So if we take a look at my screen,
I just kind of made them have troll hair.

397
00:22:33.070 --> 00:22:37.290
Because there's also a popular
movie out right now called Trolls.

398
00:22:37.290 --> 00:22:41.190
And then I had them bring some
troll toothpaste and toothbrush and

399
00:22:41.190 --> 00:22:42.440
some mouthwash.

400
00:22:42.440 --> 00:22:46.408
Just to make it a little bit more fun,
and it's not the basic hearing me say,

401
00:22:46.408 --> 00:22:47.533
go brush your teeth!

402
00:22:47.533 --> 00:22:49.533
>> [LAUGH]
>> So it's a little different there, but

403
00:22:49.533 --> 00:22:52.210
I don't know, just to try to
make it a little fun I guess.

404
00:22:52.210 --> 00:22:57.890
>> Well I think making the process
control fun is a huge thing.

405
00:22:57.890 --> 00:22:59.025
And as project managers,

406
00:22:59.025 --> 00:23:03.110
if there are things that you want
people to do, to keep things in place.

407
00:23:03.110 --> 00:23:06.590
Making it a little bit more fun or
exciting I think is a great thing.

408
00:23:06.590 --> 00:23:11.610
So if you don't mind looking at my
screen again, my FMEA Thinking screen.

409
00:23:11.610 --> 00:23:16.120
I just wanna reiterate that this model
can be used for process improvement.

410
00:23:16.120 --> 00:23:21.410
If you have nothing in that current
control, that's an automatic opportunity.

411
00:23:21.410 --> 00:23:22.360
If you're looking for

412
00:23:22.360 --> 00:23:26.160
a project to do, that's a place
where you could start looking.

413
00:23:26.160 --> 00:23:30.200
In the project management world, a lot of
times what I want you to think about using

414
00:23:30.200 --> 00:23:33.530
this model is again,
those potential causes of failure.

415
00:23:33.530 --> 00:23:36.260
Because there could be
a whole project there, right?

416
00:23:36.260 --> 00:23:37.470
>> Exactly.

417
00:23:37.470 --> 00:23:41.830
>> So, I wanna remind you of that formula,
because we're still in the selection.

418
00:23:41.830 --> 00:23:46.400
We're wrapping up the selection
part of the project life cycle.
