419
00:23:46.400 --> 00:23:50.153
And I just wanna remind you
again of that Y=f(x) formula,

420
00:23:50.153 --> 00:23:54.802
because I want to mention something
about Agile in the selection process.

421
00:23:54.802 --> 00:23:58.043
So Y=,
what is it I'm trying to accomplish?

422
00:23:58.043 --> 00:24:01.813
In a lean environment, remember it's
specifically what activity am I trying

423
00:24:01.813 --> 00:24:04.165
to make better, faster,
most cost effective.

424
00:24:04.165 --> 00:24:09.070
But in lean and agile project management,
what is the outcome?

425
00:24:09.070 --> 00:24:11.770
What is it I'm trying to
get out of this project?

426
00:24:11.770 --> 00:24:15.310
The x's would be any of
the inputs that I would need and

427
00:24:15.310 --> 00:24:18.620
then the f would be how do
those inputs need to function?

428
00:24:18.620 --> 00:24:20.770
So Cherokee,
do you mind doing one with me?

429
00:24:20.770 --> 00:24:25.640
If I wanted to have the perfect
training session, what would be my x's?

430
00:24:25.640 --> 00:24:28.910
>> So for an x, an input for

431
00:24:28.910 --> 00:24:33.710
a perfect training session, well you would
need some kind of knowledge to transfer.

432
00:24:33.710 --> 00:24:36.190
So, you would need
someone with experience.

433
00:24:36.190 --> 00:24:38.530
You would need some subjects or students.

434
00:24:38.530 --> 00:24:43.150
And then you would need, depending on the
format that you were giving that training,

435
00:24:43.150 --> 00:24:48.450
whether it be an online live or
here we're using the internet.

436
00:24:48.450 --> 00:24:49.970
Unless you were teaching in real life and

437
00:24:49.970 --> 00:24:52.710
then you would need a space to
go ahead and have that training.

438
00:24:52.710 --> 00:24:55.970
And you might also wanna have some kind
of training materials or handouts and

439
00:24:55.970 --> 00:24:59.585
some space for the students to work,
just a few things, I don't know.

440
00:24:59.585 --> 00:25:01.070
[LAUGH]
>> Absolutely, and

441
00:25:01.070 --> 00:25:05.500
if I were trying to think about,
like I'm looking in the selection stage.

442
00:25:05.500 --> 00:25:08.670
Maybe I have a number of different
projects that I can choose.

443
00:25:08.670 --> 00:25:11.780
This is one of the projects
that I could choose to work on.

444
00:25:11.780 --> 00:25:14.280
I've looked at the inputs,
and I've said, you know what?

445
00:25:14.280 --> 00:25:18.720
I have all those inputs, so
this project could be successful.

446
00:25:18.720 --> 00:25:23.670
But I wanna take one more step back before
I actually make it my final project and

447
00:25:23.670 --> 00:25:26.100
look at how those inputs have to function.

448
00:25:26.100 --> 00:25:29.308
So for example, let's just take
one of them, which was handouts.

449
00:25:29.308 --> 00:25:31.520
How would handouts have to be,

450
00:25:31.520 --> 00:25:35.400
how would they have to work to
make my project successful?

451
00:25:35.400 --> 00:25:38.157
>> Well, if I were teaching
a number of classes that week and

452
00:25:38.157 --> 00:25:41.100
I had brought maybe the wrong
hand outs for that class, and

453
00:25:41.100 --> 00:25:43.835
then I'm going over over topics, and
they're looking at the handouts,

454
00:25:43.835 --> 00:25:46.945
and the students are just
looking at it all cross-eyed.

455
00:25:46.945 --> 00:25:49.085
And they're like, none of this
stuff matches to what she's saying.

456
00:25:49.085 --> 00:25:50.405
So I guess that would be one way.

457
00:25:50.405 --> 00:25:51.365
>> So accuracy.

458
00:25:51.365 --> 00:25:53.965
So, my handouts need to be accurate.

459
00:25:53.965 --> 00:25:55.155
>> Correct.
>> That's one.

460
00:25:55.155 --> 00:25:57.875
I need to have enough of those handouts,
right?

461
00:25:57.875 --> 00:25:59.475
>> Correct.
>> So these are things that I could

462
00:25:59.475 --> 00:26:00.055
look at.

463
00:26:00.055 --> 00:26:03.930
I've got, when I'm trying to
select a project, I know my why.

464
00:26:05.850 --> 00:26:09.280
Or let's say I have a high level idea
of what I'm trying to accomplish.

465
00:26:09.280 --> 00:26:13.010
So, my first step in selection is to make
sure I have all the inputs necessary.

466
00:26:13.010 --> 00:26:16.030
Because if I don't,
I need to rethink that project or

467
00:26:16.030 --> 00:26:18.390
go back to whoever gave it to me, right?

468
00:26:18.390 --> 00:26:21.560
But then,
I also before I move on to planning,

469
00:26:21.560 --> 00:26:26.540
I wanna make sure that
the inputs are okay.

470
00:26:26.540 --> 00:26:30.651
That the inputs all function properly
in the case of hand-outs that I have

471
00:26:30.651 --> 00:26:31.528
enough, etc.

472
00:26:31.528 --> 00:26:32.500
>> [INAUDIBLE] Things like that.

473
00:26:32.500 --> 00:26:34.430
>> Right.
Now the reason why we're talking about

474
00:26:34.430 --> 00:26:38.500
this again, because we did briefly mention
it a little earlier in the session.

475
00:26:38.500 --> 00:26:44.270
Is that Agile, you can actually go to
the planning stage without a Y statement.

476
00:26:44.270 --> 00:26:48.050
And that's probably what makes
everyone a little crazy,

477
00:26:48.050 --> 00:26:51.030
the people that are totally in
traditional project management.

478
00:26:51.030 --> 00:26:55.350
It's like, how can you go from
selection to planning when you're not

479
00:26:55.350 --> 00:26:57.490
totally sure what it is
you're gonna work on?

480
00:26:57.490 --> 00:26:59.770
But just kind of a word to the wise.

481
00:26:59.770 --> 00:27:03.420
In Agile environments, a lot of times
you have selected a project, but

482
00:27:03.420 --> 00:27:07.990
it's not absolutely necessary, because
the concept is if you go to the planning

483
00:27:07.990 --> 00:27:10.690
phase, you may uncover some other things.

484
00:27:10.690 --> 00:27:16.790
So in the DMAIC model, a lot of times some
of the things that are being used and

485
00:27:16.790 --> 00:27:21.130
defined are used in planning
in the Agile model.

486
00:27:21.130 --> 00:27:23.920
>> So, I think that pretty much wraps up

487
00:27:23.920 --> 00:27:28.125
the selection part of our project
life cycle composite model.

488
00:27:28.125 --> 00:27:34.330
>> [LAUGH] So that's the first phase in
our project life cycle composite model.

489
00:27:34.330 --> 00:27:37.160
I just want to reiterate that
because it is a new term.

490
00:27:37.160 --> 00:27:40.640
So I appreciate you for taking
the time to explain our first phase.

491
00:27:40.640 --> 00:27:44.860
We have three more headed your way, so
don't go anywhere, get comfortable.

492
00:27:44.860 --> 00:27:48.080
But we are gonna go ahead and
sign off for this particular episode.

493
00:27:48.080 --> 00:27:51.360
So, as your show host remember
my name is Cherokee Boothe.

494
00:27:51.360 --> 00:27:55.060
>> And I'm Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

495
00:27:55.060 --> 00:27:58.665
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

496
00:27:58.665 --> 00:28:04.502
[MUSIC]

497
00:28:04.502 --> 00:28:07.594
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose continue covering the Lean and Agile Project Management Project Life Cycle. Particularly, they explore the second phase, Planning. In this phase the scope should be finalized, team members selected, deliverables scheduled, and communications plan established amongst other tasks.
episodes.title: Session 7
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:04.106
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:04.106 --> 00:00:08.173
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.173 --> 00:00:12.012
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.012 --> 00:00:15.811
>> Welcome to your Lean and
Agile Project Management series.

5
00:00:15.811 --> 00:00:18.210
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:19.390 --> 00:00:24.920
In the last episode we were looking at our
Project Life-Cycle Composite methodology.

7
00:00:24.920 --> 00:00:28.100
And we looked at the first phase
which is the selection phase.

8
00:00:28.100 --> 00:00:31.960
However in this episode we're gonna
be taking a look at the second phase,

9
00:00:31.960 --> 00:00:33.570
which is the planning phase.

10
00:00:33.570 --> 00:00:38.020
To help us through this topic we have Dr.
Tara Vanzant Stern in studios today.

11
00:00:38.020 --> 00:00:39.730
Thank you for joining us today Doctor.

12
00:00:39.730 --> 00:00:40.268
>> Thank you.

13
00:00:40.268 --> 00:00:43.740
>> So after we exit

14
00:00:43.740 --> 00:00:46.730
the selection phase we're gonna be
entering in the planning, is that correct?

15
00:00:46.730 --> 00:00:47.270
>> That's correct.

16
00:00:47.270 --> 00:00:50.090
>> And what are some things that we
should really be looking for and

17
00:00:50.090 --> 00:00:52.030
executing during the planning phase?

18
00:00:52.030 --> 00:00:55.110
>> Okay, well I'd like to take
a look at my slide deck and

19
00:00:55.110 --> 00:00:56.600
I'm gonna pull that up right now.

20
00:00:57.920 --> 00:01:01.970
And you see this again, it's the book that
we're kind of working from the Lean and

21
00:01:01.970 --> 00:01:04.120
Agile Project Management book.

22
00:01:04.120 --> 00:01:08.890
And actually I want to remind everyone of
what the project life cycle looks like and

23
00:01:08.890 --> 00:01:11.200
that's what you're seeing
on the screen right now.

24
00:01:11.200 --> 00:01:15.230
We are going to focus in
this session on planning.

25
00:01:15.230 --> 00:01:18.485
I did have a couple of things I wanted
to mention about selection just to kind

26
00:01:18.485 --> 00:01:20.538
of help us segue into planning.

27
00:01:20.538 --> 00:01:21.508
>> Okay.

28
00:01:21.508 --> 00:01:26.429
>> The Project Life Cycle,
as a reminder, is a composite of all

29
00:01:26.429 --> 00:01:31.770
the different project management
life cycles out there.

30
00:01:31.770 --> 00:01:34.690
Some universities are now
heading towards a seven and

31
00:01:34.690 --> 00:01:39.200
eight phase model and
even in those three bodies of knowledge,

32
00:01:39.200 --> 00:01:42.388
you're going to see the life
cycle look slightly different.

33
00:01:42.388 --> 00:01:43.410
Our life cycle,

34
00:01:43.410 --> 00:01:47.260
however, captures all the key things
that need to happen in a project.

35
00:01:47.260 --> 00:01:48.750
We just think it's leaner.

36
00:01:48.750 --> 00:01:51.000
And since this is lean and
agile project management,

37
00:01:51.000 --> 00:01:55.490
we thought atarting with the model
that's lean is gonna be very helpful.

38
00:01:55.490 --> 00:01:59.590
So we did cover selection
in the last section but

39
00:01:59.590 --> 00:02:02.590
I wanted to point out a couple
of things about selection.

40
00:02:02.590 --> 00:02:04.510
And these are just kind of funny things.

41
00:02:04.510 --> 00:02:09.540
So what you're supposed to do is you're
supposed to start with a strategic plan.

42
00:02:09.540 --> 00:02:12.360
But what really happens
is projects are reactive.

43
00:02:12.360 --> 00:02:14.730
I mean people run in and
they throw projects on your desk.

44
00:02:14.730 --> 00:02:16.950
But in a perfect world in selection,

45
00:02:16.950 --> 00:02:19.300
you wanna start with that strategic plan,
right.

46
00:02:19.300 --> 00:02:20.947
You wanna kinda see how does that fit.

47
00:02:20.947 --> 00:02:24.410
You want to decide what is
important in choosing a project but

48
00:02:24.410 --> 00:02:29.490
here's the reality, common criteria
does not exist or it's not documented.

49
00:02:29.490 --> 00:02:34.060
So our book and our material, and really
which is supported by all the bodies of

50
00:02:34.060 --> 00:02:38.030
project management, are gonna say
that that's an important thing but

51
00:02:38.030 --> 00:02:41.350
sometimes that criteria
just is non-existent.

52
00:02:41.350 --> 00:02:45.910
In a prefect world you wanna establish and
follow a specific process.

53
00:02:45.910 --> 00:02:50.880
If your working for a company that's not
used to putting, doing projects there

54
00:02:50.880 --> 00:02:54.700
might not be a process, you might
be kinda making up as you go along.

55
00:02:54.700 --> 00:02:58.020
And so they could have a process,
no process, or

56
00:02:58.020 --> 00:03:00.300
the process that they have is out-dated.

57
00:03:00.300 --> 00:03:01.180
>> Really old.

58
00:03:01.180 --> 00:03:04.399
>> Right, exactly
>> So in a perfect world, in selection,

59
00:03:04.399 --> 00:03:06.789
the things that are in black
would be what you have.

60
00:03:06.789 --> 00:03:10.790
So use rigor and evaluating alternatives.

61
00:03:10.790 --> 00:03:14.750
And the reality is a lot of
times alternatives have not

62
00:03:14.750 --> 00:03:16.290
been evaluated, right?

63
00:03:16.290 --> 00:03:20.180
We kind of,
we're living in this reactive society,

64
00:03:20.180 --> 00:03:24.210
which is point one about
the projects are reactive.

65
00:03:24.210 --> 00:03:26.030
But sometimes we're just in such a rush,

66
00:03:26.030 --> 00:03:28.480
we don't really take a step back and
look at that.

67
00:03:28.480 --> 00:03:32.560
And also in a perfect world,
you use a cross-functional team.

68
00:03:32.560 --> 00:03:35.060
But in reality sometimes
the team is just you.

69
00:03:36.160 --> 00:03:39.340
So these are things that are supposed
to happen in the selection process,

70
00:03:39.340 --> 00:03:41.270
they're certainly what you're striving for
but

71
00:03:41.270 --> 00:03:43.520
just don't be discouraged
if they don't happen.

72
00:03:45.000 --> 00:03:47.730
Now one of the things that
we didn't discuss, and

73
00:03:47.730 --> 00:03:53.210
the thing that I think is very interesting
about the SWOT analysis, is that it wasn't

74
00:03:53.210 --> 00:03:57.500
a project management tool, it wasn't
a lean tool, it wasn't an agile tool.

75
00:03:57.500 --> 00:04:01.650
But lean and agile project management
take full advantage of this tool.

76
00:04:01.650 --> 00:04:03.850
So I'm in the selection process and

77
00:04:03.850 --> 00:04:08.760
in this case I'm coming up with an idea
and I want to run it through the SWOT.

78
00:04:08.760 --> 00:04:12.170
Or perhaps I have several
projects I can work on and

79
00:04:12.170 --> 00:04:15.910
I wanna work on the one that has
the biggest bang for its buck.

80
00:04:15.910 --> 00:04:18.910
Now if you're very interested
in SWOT this is covered

81
00:04:18.910 --> 00:04:22.890
a little bit more in depth in our
Lean Six Sigma green belt program.

82
00:04:22.890 --> 00:04:25.540
But we're just gonna briefly
go over it for right now.

83
00:04:25.540 --> 00:04:28.980
So let's say I have a really great idea.

84
00:04:28.980 --> 00:04:32.340
Strengths is the same way as saying pros.

85
00:04:32.340 --> 00:04:35.590
Weaknesses are the same
way as saying cons.

86
00:04:35.590 --> 00:04:38.070
Opportunities are things
that could happen.

87
00:04:38.070 --> 00:04:40.400
Threats are risks that could happen.

88
00:04:40.400 --> 00:04:43.720
So if I'm pretty darn sure that
something's gonna happen I'm

89
00:04:43.720 --> 00:04:45.280
gonna make it a strength.

90
00:04:45.280 --> 00:04:50.630
If I am pretty clear than it's gonna be
a detriment I am gonna make it a weakness.

91
00:04:50.630 --> 00:04:55.000
Common weaknesses are gonna be time and
money, right?

92
00:04:55.000 --> 00:04:56.442
That's gonna always be something.

93
00:04:56.442 --> 00:04:59.640
If I'm doing a new project that's
probably either gonna spend time or

94
00:04:59.640 --> 00:05:01.370
money or both, right?

95
00:05:01.370 --> 00:05:04.830
Opportunities, as I said,
are things that could happen.

96
00:05:04.830 --> 00:05:08.710
So if I'm thinking well that would be a
really good thing but I really am unclear.

97
00:05:08.710 --> 00:05:10.340
It could happen it might not happen.

98
00:05:10.340 --> 00:05:14.020
Opportunities and
again the same with threats or risk.

99
00:05:14.020 --> 00:05:17.590
Now the thing that's really good
about this model is that it

100
00:05:17.590 --> 00:05:21.270
used to be that strengths and weaknesses
were the only things that we looked at and

101
00:05:21.270 --> 00:05:23.800
that was called a force field analysis.

102
00:05:23.800 --> 00:05:27.570
But lean and agile project management says
if you don't look at the opportunities and

103
00:05:27.570 --> 00:05:30.000
threats then you're kind
of short changing yourself.

104
00:05:30.000 --> 00:05:31.680
So let's just do one together.

105
00:05:31.680 --> 00:05:35.000

00:16:58.940 --> 00:17:00.080
you give me an office.

336
00:17:01.175 --> 00:17:03.317
And these are all the things
that we're doing and planning.

337
00:17:03.317 --> 00:17:08.619
We wanna get this all up front and settled
before we move into execution, right?

338
00:17:09.710 --> 00:17:13.777
We might want to, if there's some
business process changes and

339
00:17:13.777 --> 00:17:17.919
even though it's not on the list,
if you're doing a project that

340
00:17:17.919 --> 00:17:22.620
could be impacted by an act that's
being passed or there's some coding.

341
00:17:22.620 --> 00:17:24.852
That would all fall into that.

342
00:17:24.852 --> 00:17:27.330
You wanna make sure that if
you're not the project manager,

343
00:17:27.330 --> 00:17:31.570
that you say who the project manager is,
who the team is, budget, signatures.

344
00:17:31.570 --> 00:17:34.290
So that's more in a full
blown project charter.

345
00:17:34.290 --> 00:17:39.030
So if you stick to the stuff on
the left-hand side, you're covered if

346
00:17:39.030 --> 00:17:42.990
you're not doing a formal project charter,
you're just basically telling your boss.

347
00:17:42.990 --> 00:17:46.210
>> [CROSSTALK] Sending that email or-
>> Yeah, sending that email, exactly.

348
00:17:46.210 --> 00:17:49.000
So here's an example of process mapping.

349
00:17:49.000 --> 00:17:53.659
Now in process improvement, which we cover
in the Lean Six Sigma Green Belt program,

350
00:17:53.659 --> 00:17:57.801
there's a commitment to knowing what's
happening now in order to make some

351
00:17:57.801 --> 00:18:02.220
improvements, in order to make things
better, faster, more cost effective.

352
00:18:02.220 --> 00:18:06.126
As a project manager It's important,
as we said earlier in this session,

353
00:18:06.126 --> 00:18:09.120
just to figure out,
where do I fit in the puzzle?

354
00:18:09.120 --> 00:18:15.290
So one thing that you can do is you can do
a overall process map for your department.

355
00:18:15.290 --> 00:18:17.790
And then do something
called a swim lane chart.

356
00:18:17.790 --> 00:18:20.610
And in the swim lane chart,
this is very lean, it just says,

357
00:18:20.610 --> 00:18:24.110
what types of things happen
in different departments.

358
00:18:24.110 --> 00:18:27.440
Now along the left hand side,
I mean the right hand side, sorry.

359
00:18:28.840 --> 00:18:30.030
You'll see different departments.

360
00:18:30.030 --> 00:18:32.590
But those could be different
people's names in your department.

361
00:18:32.590 --> 00:18:37.184
So that could be Barry, Bob, Sue, right?

362
00:18:37.184 --> 00:18:40.095
The reason why you might
be doing a process map and

363
00:18:40.095 --> 00:18:45.000
planning is you're trying to get a high
level idea of what's going on around you.

364
00:18:45.000 --> 00:18:48.180
You wanna know that first
before you start executing.

365
00:18:48.180 --> 00:18:52.640
So if you have a piece that you need to
execute, that needs another department, or

366
00:18:52.640 --> 00:18:55.190
someone in your group is
gonna be responsible for it.

367
00:18:55.190 --> 00:18:58.662
That would be why you would
be doing a process map.

368
00:19:00.640 --> 00:19:03.840
It also helps you create
your project scope.

369
00:19:03.840 --> 00:19:06.020
And we talked a little
earlier about project scope.

370
00:19:06.020 --> 00:19:08.530
It's almost easier to think backwards.

371
00:19:08.530 --> 00:19:12.430
When I'm in the planning process,
what am I not agreeing to?

372
00:19:12.430 --> 00:19:14.840
Your project scope is going to come,

373
00:19:14.840 --> 00:19:19.150
is gonna almost be natural
if you stick to that WBS.

374
00:19:19.150 --> 00:19:21.650
Because if you're looking at your
work breakdown structure and

375
00:19:21.650 --> 00:19:25.490
you're calculating everything that you're
saying you're gonna be responsible for.

376
00:19:25.490 --> 00:19:28.330
You can come up with a scoping statement.

377
00:19:28.330 --> 00:19:33.670
Now a lot of times, just to be leaner,
we say, that in lean and

378
00:19:33.670 --> 00:19:37.180
agile environments, especially,
you'll notice this in agile environments.

379
00:19:37.180 --> 00:19:41.830
If there is a way that you can create
a sentence that includes all of that,

380
00:19:41.830 --> 00:19:42.380
that's great.

381
00:19:42.380 --> 00:19:44.266
So kind of practice that elevator speech.

382
00:19:44.266 --> 00:19:46.890
This is what I I'm going to do,
this is why I'm going to do it,

383
00:19:46.890 --> 00:19:48.760
and this is what I'm not gonna do.

384
00:19:48.760 --> 00:19:51.626
>> [CROSSTALK] Okay that's
what I was getting at.

385
00:19:51.626 --> 00:19:56.369
It's all right to kind of clearly define,
this is not what will be happening if you

386
00:19:56.369 --> 00:19:59.807
already have an idea that you
know that's what they want but

387
00:19:59.807 --> 00:20:03.170
really your number one
priority is something else.

388
00:20:03.170 --> 00:20:06.650
And you feel as there may be
a tendency for them to try to add on.

389
00:20:06.650 --> 00:20:07.590
But you can clearly say,

390
00:20:07.590 --> 00:20:11.830
look, we're gonna put this in that,
so we don't see that scope creep, and

391
00:20:11.830 --> 00:20:15.690
we have to plan it and budget out
separately for that particular project.

392
00:20:15.690 --> 00:20:17.670
>> Exactly, exactly.

393
00:20:17.670 --> 00:20:21.705
So I'm still in the planning phase and
now what I'm gonna talk a little bit about

394
00:20:21.705 --> 00:20:25.355
is the difference between traditional
planning and agile planning.

395
00:20:25.355 --> 00:20:29.215
So on the traditional project management
planning side, and keep in mind,

396
00:20:29.215 --> 00:20:31.985
these days, they can be mixed,
and they can morph over.

397
00:20:31.985 --> 00:20:36.505
But if I were just a traditional project
manager, I'd be looking at scope review.

398
00:20:36.505 --> 00:20:41.160
I wanna make sure that my scope's correct,
I'm gonna be selecting my team members.

399
00:20:41.160 --> 00:20:43.640
I'm gonna plan my deliverables and
I'm gonna review it and

400
00:20:43.640 --> 00:20:47.880
make sure everybody agrees, hey,
these deliverables are the right ones.

401
00:20:47.880 --> 00:20:50.720
I might even run it by my,
whoever, I'm doing the project for

402
00:20:50.720 --> 00:20:55.390
before I actually end up with my formal
plan, anything that I can piece out.

403
00:20:55.390 --> 00:20:59.810
I'm gonna look at my CTQs which we'll
be covering a little bit later.

404
00:20:59.810 --> 00:21:04.620
And then I'm also going to come up
with my baseline schedule, which,

405
00:21:04.620 --> 00:21:08.610
remember, we've said this a lot,
that's how long I say it's gonna take, and

406
00:21:08.610 --> 00:21:10.780
how much it's gonna cost, right?

407
00:21:10.780 --> 00:21:14.490
So that's what I'm gonna do, I'm gonna be
doing that if I'm a traditional project

408
00:21:14.490 --> 00:21:17.240
manager, or if I'm a lean project manager.

409
00:21:17.240 --> 00:21:19.960
That's kind of the path I'm gonna take.

410
00:21:19.960 --> 00:21:24.890
Now, if I'm managing it
in an agile environment,

411
00:21:24.890 --> 00:21:28.920
my planning is gonna take
kind of an extra step.

412
00:21:28.920 --> 00:21:31.630
Some of those things are still
gonna take place, right?

413
00:21:31.630 --> 00:21:35.160
But one of the things I'm
gonna concentrate on is roles.

414
00:21:35.160 --> 00:21:36.360
Who's doing what?

415
00:21:36.360 --> 00:21:41.653
And what I think is so beautiful about
this is that there's been a number of very

416
00:21:41.653 --> 00:21:47.160
popular works done on why
employees leave companies.

417
00:21:47.160 --> 00:21:50.170
And one of the number one reasons is
they don't really understand their

418
00:21:50.170 --> 00:21:50.980
expectations.

419
00:21:50.980 --> 00:21:52.870
They don't know what it is
they're supposed to do.

420
00:21:52.870 --> 00:21:53.831
>> [CROSSTALK] I can see that, yeah.

421
00:21:53.831 --> 00:21:55.883
>> And it's like,
I have a job description,

422
00:21:55.883 --> 00:21:58.630
I'm not doing anything
like my job description.

423
00:21:58.630 --> 00:22:02.760
Now the nice thing, if you're running
this more like a scrum manager instead of

424
00:22:02.760 --> 00:22:06.980
a traditional project manager,
is you're not really responsible for

425
00:22:06.980 --> 00:22:08.760
their role in the company.

426
00:22:08.760 --> 00:22:10.530
So that kind of takes
a little pressure off.

427
00:22:10.530 --> 00:22:13.070
Just the role in this particular project.

428
00:22:13.070 --> 00:22:17.040
But agile feels like it's important
that before we go execute,

429
00:22:17.040 --> 00:22:19.680
that everyone really understands,
what is their piece?

430
00:22:19.680 --> 00:22:22.350
So in the planning process,
you wanna talk that out.

431
00:22:22.350 --> 00:22:26.768
And sometimes it's not gonna necessarily
be the person that you think it's

432
00:22:26.768 --> 00:22:27.534
going to be.

433
00:22:27.534 --> 00:22:30.560
I mean you can toss things out and
it's you know.

434
00:22:30.560 --> 00:22:32.420
So there's also the ScrumMaster.

435
00:22:32.420 --> 00:22:36.490
Now the other thing in agile environments
is that you might be the ScrumMaster for

436
00:22:36.490 --> 00:22:38.680
one project but not the other.

437
00:22:38.680 --> 00:22:42.154
You might be a team member, you might
have simultaneous projects going on.

438
00:22:42.154 --> 00:22:44.920
And you're in charge of one but
not in charge of the other.

439
00:22:44.920 --> 00:22:48.970
In traditional project
management environments,

440
00:22:48.970 --> 00:22:50.890
there's usually one
person who is designated.

441
00:22:50.890 --> 00:22:53.060
You are the project manager, right?

442
00:22:53.060 --> 00:22:57.492
But in these environments, if you
have a little bit more expertise, and

443
00:22:57.492 --> 00:22:58.510
the training and

444
00:22:58.510 --> 00:23:02.883
stuff, there's no reason why you
might not be managing that project.

445
00:23:02.883 --> 00:23:03.930
And then the team.

446
00:23:03.930 --> 00:23:05.230
Who's gonna be working on this?

447
00:23:05.230 --> 00:23:09.860
And remember, in the agile environments,
since things are segmented out,

448
00:23:09.860 --> 00:23:13.190
it's really important to know who's
your team for this particular project.

449
00:23:14.450 --> 00:23:16.740
There are different what
they call ceremonies.

450
00:23:16.740 --> 00:23:19.160
The sprint planning, the sprint review.

451
00:23:19.160 --> 00:23:22.800
The sprint retrospective,
that's kind of hard to say.

452
00:23:22.800 --> 00:23:24.000
And the daily scrum.

453
00:23:24.000 --> 00:23:27.213
So in the planning phase,
what you're doing in that

454
00:23:27.213 --> 00:23:30.948
project lifecycle is you're
kind of putting dates to that.

455
00:23:30.948 --> 00:23:33.960
Now a daily scrum meeting, you don't
really have to put a date to that.

456
00:23:33.960 --> 00:23:37.580
I mean, Monday through Friday,
we're gonna have our daily scrum, right?

457
00:23:37.580 --> 00:23:42.630
Sprint, retrospectives and reviews and
planning all kind of come together.

458
00:23:42.630 --> 00:23:46.718
Sprint, remember, typically two to four
weeks but they can be shorter or longer.

459
00:23:46.718 --> 00:23:49.070
That's just kind of a generalization.

460
00:23:49.070 --> 00:23:52.842
We're gonna have at the End of each
one of those sprints, a review?

461
00:23:52.842 --> 00:23:55.249
And then at the end of the reviews,
we're gonna go back and

462
00:23:55.249 --> 00:23:57.490
say, what did we do wrong,
what did we do right?

463
00:23:57.490 --> 00:23:59.880
What do we wanna keep and
move forward with?

464
00:23:59.880 --> 00:24:03.360
So when you're in the planning
phase of the project lifecycle,

465
00:24:03.360 --> 00:24:07.097
at this point, I think the biggest
thing you're looking at is more,

466
00:24:07.097 --> 00:24:09.104
when are we going to do that, right?

467
00:24:09.104 --> 00:24:12.062
Some of it's gonna be very natural,
but getting it on the calendar,

468
00:24:12.062 --> 00:24:15.587
getting everyone's buy in, that these
are the times we're gonna need, right?

469
00:24:15.587 --> 00:24:19.727
So that is part of the planning process,
and then looking at things like

470
00:24:19.727 --> 00:24:24.695
the backlog, like Sprint backlog, burndown
charts, we might actually, if we were

471
00:24:24.695 --> 00:24:28.904
doing this in a more agile environment,
agree on the tools, look at what

472
00:24:28.904 --> 00:24:33.880
we've got still on the table that we still
need to finish, and those types of things.

473
00:24:33.880 --> 00:24:39.580
So the planning might have to be
a little bit longer in Sprint.

474
00:24:39.580 --> 00:24:41.390
I mean, I'm sorry in Agile.

475
00:24:42.761 --> 00:24:45.134
So here's the Sprint planning meeting, and

476
00:24:45.134 --> 00:24:49.006
this I'm just gonna go through very
quickly because this is the example of

477
00:24:49.006 --> 00:24:51.910
a handout you'll get in
your student package.

478
00:24:51.910 --> 00:24:54.140
What we're trying to do is to be lean, so

479
00:24:54.140 --> 00:24:57.280
we're putting a lot of
information on one page.

480
00:24:57.280 --> 00:25:00.820
And the reason why that's lean,
is because if you're in a meeting and

481
00:25:00.820 --> 00:25:04.240
you need to pull it out,
all the information is right there.

482
00:25:04.240 --> 00:25:07.670
It doesn't make for a good slide, so
when you're doing presentations, you

483
00:25:07.670 --> 00:25:11.420
typically don't want, we're just showing
you an example of what you're gonna get.

484
00:25:11.420 --> 00:25:12.117
>> Okay.

485
00:25:12.117 --> 00:25:14.808
>> But you typically don't want all
of this [CROSSTALK] information on

486
00:25:14.808 --> 00:25:15.630
the slide, right?

487
00:25:15.630 --> 00:25:20.109
But we do, the handouts, I think having
as much information as possible,

488
00:25:20.109 --> 00:25:24.392
as long it's still clear, kind of
is a good idea, and it's very lean.

489
00:25:26.378 --> 00:25:29.507
So this kind of explains a lot of
what I was just talking about,

490
00:25:29.507 --> 00:25:33.357
the different types and keep in mind,
you're in the planning phase, and so

491
00:25:33.357 --> 00:25:37.569
if you're doing more of an agile project,
these types of things are gonna come up,

492
00:25:37.569 --> 00:25:41.840
where it's a little bit more dictatorial
in the traditional project management.

493
00:25:41.840 --> 00:25:45.757
This is what we're gonna do, here's our
meetings In the Agile environment and

494
00:25:45.757 --> 00:25:48.340
planning, everyone kinda
has a little bit of a say.

495
00:25:49.866 --> 00:25:53.737
So one of the things that's important,
and this is in all projects,

496
00:25:53.737 --> 00:25:57.360
is that you understand the project
goal versus the objectives.

497
00:25:57.360 --> 00:26:01.940
And this is, you can take a whole class
on goals, objectives, mission, vision.

498
00:26:01.940 --> 00:26:05.910
So I'm not gonna really belabor this, but

499
00:26:05.910 --> 00:26:11.570
it's important that the project
goals represents your intent.

500
00:26:11.570 --> 00:26:15.200
And this is kind of a bit
of a sticky wicket.

501
00:26:15.200 --> 00:26:20.020
You don't wanna leave the planning
phase unless you've got that down.

502
00:26:20.020 --> 00:26:23.130
And a lot of times,
we said this earlier in other sessions,

503
00:26:23.130 --> 00:26:26.779
sometimes we're on a road that's not
the road we're supposed to be on, right?

504
00:26:27.800 --> 00:26:29.870
>> And just to ask a quick question.

505
00:26:30.930 --> 00:26:34.750
Were we looking at the same duration for
each one of these phases?

506
00:26:34.750 --> 00:26:35.960
Is that how we were breaking it up?

507
00:26:35.960 --> 00:26:41.760
Or is it really confined to any kind
of time limits there for each phase?

508
00:26:41.760 --> 00:26:43.570
>> That's such a good question, Cherokee.

509
00:26:43.570 --> 00:26:48.580
Because, the thing is, is that
the selection phase could end up taking

510
00:26:48.580 --> 00:26:52.770
a while, if you have to run your project
ideas through a steering committee.

511
00:26:52.770 --> 00:26:56.940
So you may have to end up spending a
little bit more time in project selection.

512
00:26:56.940 --> 00:27:01.210
If it's just you and your boss,
selection can go really fast.

513
00:27:01.210 --> 00:27:05.090
Or it might be you have so many projects
to work on, the only thing you're doing is

514
00:27:05.090 --> 00:27:07.110
trying to figure out which
one that you wanna work on.

515
00:27:07.110 --> 00:27:09.781
And then that SWOT analysis will help you.

516
00:27:09.781 --> 00:27:14.513
Planning, just like anything else,
the more time you can spend in planning,

517
00:27:14.513 --> 00:27:15.812
the better, right?

518
00:27:15.812 --> 00:27:20.242
But most of your time is gonna happen
in the third phase, which is execution,

519
00:27:20.242 --> 00:27:23.531
that's where you're gonna
spend the most of your time.

520
00:27:23.531 --> 00:27:28.447
So what you wanna do when you're looking
at the phases, is you wanna figure out,

521
00:27:28.447 --> 00:27:31.934
when is the project due,
you wanna work from backwards.

522
00:27:31.934 --> 00:27:35.002
So If the project's due next month,
on the 15th,

523
00:27:35.002 --> 00:27:39.603
that gives you an idea of how much can I
really spend in each one of those phases,

524
00:27:39.603 --> 00:27:41.935
if the objective is supposed to be met?

525
00:27:41.935 --> 00:27:46.079
But I think it's the same thing as when
you're working with the DMAIC model,

526
00:27:46.079 --> 00:27:48.755
in the DMAIC model which
is a Lean Six Sigma model,

527
00:27:48.755 --> 00:27:51.660
you wanna spend as much
time as you can and define.

528
00:27:51.660 --> 00:27:54.710
But just keep in mind that in Improve,
that's where all the action's

529
00:27:54.710 --> 00:27:56.890
gonna happen, so
you don't wanna short change yourself.

530
00:27:56.890 --> 00:27:58.690
>> Perfect, thank you.

531
00:27:58.690 --> 00:28:01.200
>> So I think we're very,
very good planners.

532
00:28:01.200 --> 00:28:03.900
And that when we move over into the next
phase that we're gonna be talking about,

533
00:28:03.900 --> 00:28:07.900
execution, some crazy
things happen sometimes.

534
00:28:07.900 --> 00:28:10.712
So we were talking about project
goal versus the objective.

535
00:28:10.712 --> 00:28:14.322
We wanna make sure before we leave,
that our goals represents our intent.

536
00:28:14.322 --> 00:28:18.330
We wanna make sure that there are things
that we can cross off our list

537
00:28:18.330 --> 00:28:22.230
especially for an agile environment
because remember in the agile environment,

538
00:28:22.230 --> 00:28:26.040
as opposed to a WBS, sometimes they
like to used burned down chart.

539
00:28:26.040 --> 00:28:29.020
So we want to make sure that the
activities that we're planning are things

540
00:28:29.020 --> 00:28:32.650
that we can cross of, right,
so we can burn down our chart.

541
00:28:32.650 --> 00:28:36.210
And we wanna make sure that
the projects have specific tasks.

542
00:28:36.210 --> 00:28:38.850
So these are all kinds of things
that we're talking about when in

543
00:28:38.850 --> 00:28:40.220
the planning phase.

544
00:28:40.220 --> 00:28:42.090
We wanna make sure if we're doing the WBS,

545
00:28:42.090 --> 00:28:45.740
which is still the preferred way
to present your project plan,

546
00:28:45.740 --> 00:28:49.650
even in an agile environment, if you have
a way of presenting what you're gonna do,

547
00:28:49.650 --> 00:28:53.500
it's gonna be easier, we just wanna
make sure that we involve people.

548
00:28:53.500 --> 00:28:56.660
And we mention the GEMBA Planning.

549
00:28:56.660 --> 00:29:00.230
Sometimes it's important to just walk
around, hang out in departments.

550
00:29:00.230 --> 00:29:03.650
If there's a process that
impacts your project,

551
00:29:03.650 --> 00:29:05.260
then I would suggest a GEMBA walk.

552
00:29:05.260 --> 00:29:07.040
And that's where you go grab
a couple of people, and

553
00:29:07.040 --> 00:29:10.250
you just walk the process because,
to Cherokee's point,

554
00:29:10.250 --> 00:29:13.920
you're gonna see some things that
you might have missed, right?

555
00:29:13.920 --> 00:29:18.730
And then finally, I wanted to show
you a model called the SIPOC and

556
00:29:18.730 --> 00:29:23.094
the SIPOC model is,
as I mentioned earlier in the session,

557
00:29:23.094 --> 00:29:26.450
covered in depth in
the Lean Six Sigma Green Belt.

558
00:29:26.450 --> 00:29:28.000
We're just gonna quickly look at it,

559
00:29:28.000 --> 00:29:31.660
it is a template that you
have in your student package.

560
00:29:31.660 --> 00:29:36.500
But I just wanna quickly show you how this
could be a very great planning tool, and

561
00:29:36.500 --> 00:29:40.530
this comes from the Lean and
SixSigma environment, but

562
00:29:40.530 --> 00:29:42.650
Agile people use it as well.

563
00:29:42.650 --> 00:29:46.350
So if I were looking at a SIPOC,
it stands for

564
00:29:46.350 --> 00:29:49.760
supplier, input, process,
output and customer.

565
00:29:49.760 --> 00:29:54.000
And just very quickly, Cherokee, if you
were thinking about suppliers which is

566
00:29:54.000 --> 00:29:58.180
just another word for vendors,
who are some vendors for your supermarket?

567
00:29:58.180 --> 00:30:01.160
>> That would be whomever
has the groceries.

568
00:30:01.160 --> 00:30:03.120
So I guess the farmers?

569
00:30:03.120 --> 00:30:08.210
And I know you wanted to really stress
that suppliers could also be internal,

570
00:30:08.210 --> 00:30:12.200
so maybe
>> You're waiting on a signature from

571
00:30:12.200 --> 00:30:12.720
someone.

572
00:30:12.720 --> 00:30:17.420
>> Yeah, so anyone who works within
that organization or that grocery store.

573
00:30:17.420 --> 00:30:20.330
Other suppliers would
be the utility company,

574
00:30:20.330 --> 00:30:22.270
to make sure that that building has power.

575
00:30:23.610 --> 00:30:27.500
Whoever is managing that point of sale
system, your Internet service provider,

576
00:30:27.500 --> 00:30:29.510
so I guess utilities.

577
00:30:29.510 --> 00:30:30.520
>> Yeah, that's good.

578
00:30:30.520 --> 00:30:31.980
Yeah, that's plenty.

579
00:30:31.980 --> 00:30:33.710
And if you were doing this in real life,

580
00:30:33.710 --> 00:30:36.580
you wouldn't stop until you
got them all down, right?

581
00:30:36.580 --> 00:30:40.640
Input, who is walking through
your supermarket doors?

582
00:30:40.640 --> 00:30:44.160
>> That is going to be our customers or
our patrons.

583
00:30:44.160 --> 00:30:48.520
Any kind of maintenance people, employees.

584
00:30:49.790 --> 00:30:50.427
>> Perfect.
And

585
00:30:50.427 --> 00:30:55.409
then we get to processes in a supermarket,
there's the butcher process,

586
00:30:55.409 --> 00:30:57.551
there's the produce process.

587
00:30:57.551 --> 00:31:01.503
>> Making sandwiches in the deli and
baking the gorgeous cakes [LAUGH].

588
00:31:01.503 --> 00:31:03.263
>> Tons of processes, right?

589
00:31:03.263 --> 00:31:07.512
>> And then the output, what goes out
of your supermarket, what's a big one?

590
00:31:07.512 --> 00:31:09.853
>> The groceries.
>> Groceries, okay and customers again.

591
00:31:09.853 --> 00:31:10.995
>> Your customers, yes.

592
00:31:10.995 --> 00:31:12.246
>> Right, okay.

593
00:31:12.246 --> 00:31:13.066
>> Carts.

594
00:31:13.066 --> 00:31:16.972
>> Carts and then when I'm thinking
about customers at my supermarket,

595
00:31:16.972 --> 00:31:21.880
when I'm thinking about customers,
definitely my customers that buy the food.

596
00:31:21.880 --> 00:31:24.770
But there could be the neighborhood,
I mean I'm sure a lot of you have seen

597
00:31:24.770 --> 00:31:27.880
those specials about where
they put grocery stores, so

598
00:31:27.880 --> 00:31:32.895
my neighborhood, my community,
maybe the franchise I belong to.

599
00:31:32.895 --> 00:31:37.940
So we define customers in the SIPOC model
as anyone that you have to keep happy.

600
00:31:37.940 --> 00:31:42.110
Now you can do this pencil and paper.

601
00:31:42.110 --> 00:31:45.870
And what you can end up with, and this is
an example of a template that you will

602
00:31:45.870 --> 00:31:49.400
receive in your student pack,
is something that looks like this.

603
00:31:49.400 --> 00:31:53.260
So, as you're planning, you can say,
okay, well here's all the vendors and

604
00:31:53.260 --> 00:31:55.710
suppliers that play into my project.

605
00:31:55.710 --> 00:31:57.560
Here's the input and the output.

606
00:31:57.560 --> 00:32:02.260
This is what's gonna go into my project,
this is ultimately what I'm hoping will go

607
00:32:02.260 --> 00:32:05.960
out, here's all the processes and
I'm looking in this case again for

608
00:32:05.960 --> 00:32:10.880
processes that might impact my project and
my customers.

609
00:32:10.880 --> 00:32:12.630
Who do I need to keep happy?

610
00:32:12.630 --> 00:32:17.210
And the other,
I think this one's even a little funner,

611
00:32:17.210 --> 00:32:19.920
if you don't have a lot of
time as a project manager,

612
00:32:19.920 --> 00:32:25.330
you don't have to fill in all of that
stuff, you can create the template,

613
00:32:25.330 --> 00:32:29.170
or the form, kind of just on your
whiteboard and you can segment it out.

614
00:32:29.170 --> 00:32:30.130
>> Do this during a meeting?

615
00:32:30.130 --> 00:32:30.730
>> Exactly.

616
00:32:30.730 --> 00:32:32.750
And bring your team in and say hey,

617
00:32:32.750 --> 00:32:37.170
who are our suppliers, who is the input,
what are some of the process.

618
00:32:37.170 --> 00:32:40.250
And then when you get into process,
you can put your process maps there.

619
00:32:40.250 --> 00:32:46.520
So especially, this is especially good if
you're in IT or if you are a consultant.

620
00:32:46.520 --> 00:32:49.280
Because if they want you
to work on a project,

621
00:32:49.280 --> 00:32:53.500
this is a fast way to figure out in
the planning stage, who's involved.

622
00:32:53.500 --> 00:32:54.770
>> Okay.
>> Okay.

623
00:32:54.770 --> 00:32:58.588
So I think that's about it on the planning
phase of the Project lifecycle

624
00:32:58.588 --> 00:32:59.660
composite module.

625
00:32:59.660 --> 00:33:00.790
>> Yeah, we did cover quite a bit.

626
00:33:00.790 --> 00:33:03.820
We were able to kind of recap
that selection phase and

627
00:33:03.820 --> 00:33:07.000
we also looked at our SWOT Analysis.

628
00:33:07.000 --> 00:33:11.250
We looked at the planning phase and
tools such as our side poc and

629
00:33:11.250 --> 00:33:13.150
running through with a Gemba walk.

630
00:33:13.150 --> 00:33:16.410
But I think that's about it for
this particular episode.

631
00:33:16.410 --> 00:33:18.750
Stay tuned,
we're coming back with the next phase.

632
00:33:18.750 --> 00:33:20.250
So don't go anywhere.

633
00:33:20.250 --> 00:33:23.220
We're gonna go ahead and sign off for
this particular episode.

634
00:33:23.220 --> 00:33:25.660
And I'm your show host, Cherokee Booths.

635
00:33:25.660 --> 00:33:29.520
>> And I'm Dr. Tara Vanstandt Stern,
with SSD Global Solutions.

636
00:33:29.520 --> 00:33:32.788
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

637
00:33:32.788 --> 00:33:38.937
[MUSIC]

638
00:33:38.937 --> 00:33:40.980
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose continue covering the Lean and Agile Project Management Project Life Cycle. Particularly, they explore the third phase, Execution. This is the phase where all the previous planning actually gets implemented. This episode explains important phases tasks as well as a comparison of Agile versus traditional elements.
episodes.title: Session 8
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:03.525
Welcome to IT Pro TV,

2
00:00:03.525 --> 00:00:08.294
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:08.294 --> 00:00:12.027
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:12.027 --> 00:00:15.830
>> Welcome to your Lean and
Agile Project Management series.

5
00:00:15.830 --> 00:00:18.350
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:18.350 --> 00:00:20.050
Now if you've been following along,

7
00:00:20.050 --> 00:00:24.670
you'll know that we've been taking a look
at our project life cycle composite.

8
00:00:24.670 --> 00:00:29.190
In the last episode, we were really
focusing on the planning phase, and

9
00:00:29.190 --> 00:00:33.320
in this episode we're gonna get started
looking at the execution phase.

10
00:00:33.320 --> 00:00:36.945
And to help us with that, we have Doctor
Terra Vanzant Stern in studio today.

11
00:00:36.945 --> 00:00:38.785
Thank you for joining us today Doctor.

12
00:00:38.785 --> 00:00:40.110
>> Thank you Cherokee.

13
00:00:40.110 --> 00:00:43.920
>> So Dr. Stern, is there anything that we
need to do before we leave the planning

14
00:00:43.920 --> 00:00:47.790
phase to actually begin
the execution of our project?

15
00:00:47.790 --> 00:00:51.250
>> I'm so glad that you asked that
Cherokee cuz there were a couple of things

16
00:00:51.250 --> 00:00:54.900
that we didn't talk about in selection
that I'd like to talk about first before

17
00:00:54.900 --> 00:00:56.050
we go into execution.

18
00:00:56.050 --> 00:01:01.420
And if we can go to my slide deck,
this is a reminder

19
00:01:01.420 --> 00:01:05.600
of the book that we're working from,
Lean and Agile Project Management and

20
00:01:05.600 --> 00:01:08.910
a reminder that we're working
within the Project Life Cycle.

21
00:01:08.910 --> 00:01:12.590
This segment, as Cherokee said,
is gonna focus on execute, but

22
00:01:12.590 --> 00:01:18.080
I'd like to talk a couple of tools that
you might be able to use in selection.

23
00:01:18.080 --> 00:01:18.710
In selection?

24
00:01:18.710 --> 00:01:19.570
>> I mean I'm sorry.

25
00:01:19.570 --> 00:01:20.230
In planning.
[LAUGH]

26
00:01:20.230 --> 00:01:20.950
>> Okay, no worries.

27
00:01:20.950 --> 00:01:21.780
I just wanted to verify.

28
00:01:21.780 --> 00:01:23.300
>> Yeah, in the planning part.

29
00:01:23.300 --> 00:01:26.470
One of the things in planning
that might be very important,

30
00:01:26.470 --> 00:01:28.250
is to sequence the tasks.

31
00:01:28.250 --> 00:01:32.545
Now this wouldn't really matter if I
were in a traditional Lean or Agile.

32
00:01:32.545 --> 00:01:36.880
I might want to look at what
has to happen in order for

33
00:01:36.880 --> 00:01:41.040
my project plan to be successful,
or to meet the time deadline.

34
00:01:41.040 --> 00:01:42.800
Or in the case of agile,

35
00:01:42.800 --> 00:01:46.420
what has to happen to meet that
particular segment that I'm working on.

36
00:01:46.420 --> 00:01:49.380
And the idea is that this PERT chart,

37
00:01:49.380 --> 00:01:54.760
which the template is part of your student
package, helps me kind of sequence things.

38
00:01:54.760 --> 00:01:58.140
So there are some things that have
to happen before other things.

39
00:01:58.140 --> 00:02:00.170
Some things can happen in tandem.

40
00:02:00.170 --> 00:02:02.630
We do PERT charts in
our head all the time.

41
00:02:02.630 --> 00:02:05.340
That's why we start the coffee when
we first get up in the morning or

42
00:02:05.340 --> 00:02:08.880
we have it started for us first
thing when we get up in the morning.

43
00:02:08.880 --> 00:02:12.360
It's so it will be ready when
we're walking out the door, right?

44
00:02:12.360 --> 00:02:13.750
So that's all a PERT chart is.

45
00:02:13.750 --> 00:02:18.190
It's taking your work breakdown
structure or your to do list, and

46
00:02:18.190 --> 00:02:21.310
it's saying you know what things
have to happen in this order.

47
00:02:21.310 --> 00:02:26.340
The reason why this is important in
project planning is because critical path,

48
00:02:26.340 --> 00:02:29.210
these are the items that have to happen,
and

49
00:02:29.210 --> 00:02:33.640
they have to happen in that time sequence
or the project will be late, right?

50
00:02:33.640 --> 00:02:37.249
So this allows us to study our
critical path in an easier way.

51
00:02:38.410 --> 00:02:40.790
The other thing that I wanted to address,

52
00:02:40.790 --> 00:02:44.260
that we might have even
looked at in selection, but

53
00:02:44.260 --> 00:02:48.930
we could have looked at in planning,
is the concept of something called CTQs.

54
00:02:48.930 --> 00:02:53.050
Now this is a Lean Six Sigma concept
that's heavily used in Agile.

55
00:02:53.050 --> 00:02:54.760
It's just called different
things in Agile.

56
00:02:54.760 --> 00:02:57.070
Sometimes it's called
customer requirements.

57
00:02:57.070 --> 00:03:00.090
Sometimes it's called customer wants or
desires.

58
00:03:00.090 --> 00:03:06.110
But basically what a STQ is, is what needs
to happen to make the project successful.

59
00:03:06.110 --> 00:03:09.760
Customer requirements are CTQs by default,
right?

60
00:03:09.760 --> 00:03:14.300
And so if the customer wants something
then we definitely wanna concentrate

61
00:03:14.300 --> 00:03:18.310
on that on our project would
our customer is internal or

62
00:03:18.310 --> 00:03:21.100
external we want to concentrate on that.

63
00:03:21.100 --> 00:03:24.971
But CTQ goes one step further and
makes our project lean and

64
00:03:24.971 --> 00:03:29.802
more agile because in the CTQ world
it's almost like being Steve Covey.

65
00:03:29.802 --> 00:03:33.828
We're saying what does everyone need
from me, as the project manager or

66
00:03:33.828 --> 00:03:37.100
the scrum master,
to be successful in this project.

67
00:03:37.100 --> 00:03:41.880
So it's not just about me, what I want,
what I would like to see happen.

68
00:03:41.880 --> 00:03:47.270
It's a little bit more about what do all
the people that play into my project need?

69
00:03:47.270 --> 00:03:50.200
Now sometimes you want to think
what is critical to quality.

70
00:03:50.200 --> 00:03:54.550
So what is critical quality is kind
of a buzz word now for better.

71
00:03:54.550 --> 00:03:57.660
What is critical to make things better?

72
00:03:57.660 --> 00:04:00.650
What's critical to make
things happen quickly?

73
00:04:00.650 --> 00:04:02.960
What's critical to the price argument?

74
00:04:02.960 --> 00:04:07.698
And remember,
when we talk about cost-effectiveness,

75
00:04:07.698 --> 00:04:11.760
we're talking about return on investment.

76
00:04:11.760 --> 00:04:14.240
And we're saying, what did I make,
save, or avoid spending?

77
00:04:14.240 --> 00:04:18.220
So what's critical to that particular
argument when we're looking at that?

78
00:04:18.220 --> 00:04:22.980
And then finally what's critical
to quality to our scope?

79
00:04:22.980 --> 00:04:25.720
So these are some things that when
we're in the planning session

80
00:04:26.770 --> 00:04:30.280
of the project life cycle composite
that we might wanna look at.

81
00:04:31.370 --> 00:04:35.170
If we can, we might even wanna
start looking at that in select.

82
00:04:35.170 --> 00:04:39.450
But we wanna have that story down before
we move into the next phase of the model

83
00:04:39.450 --> 00:04:40.470
which is execution.

84
00:04:41.680 --> 00:04:47.550
So once again, keep in mind you have
the full model in your student package.

85
00:04:47.550 --> 00:04:50.300
We don't expect you to
memorize these things.

86
00:04:50.300 --> 00:04:54.970
This is just to help you go through the
model, we are now in the Execution phase.

87
00:04:54.970 --> 00:04:59.180
Now this is gonna go very quickly because
if we did a good job in planning,

88
00:04:59.180 --> 00:05:02.190
then all we're doing in
Execution is making it happen.

89
00:05:03.890 --> 00:05:08.074
However, I want to remind
you of The Agile Manifesto.

90
00:05:08.074 --> 00:05:09.862
And I'm just going to pull these all up.

91
00:05:09.862 --> 00:05:12.703
This again is one of
those student handouts so

92
00:05:12.703 --> 00:05:15.696
when you're working
an agile environment even

93
00:05:15.696 --> 00:05:20.430
though you're in the execution mode
you want to keep these values in mind.

94
00:05:20.430 --> 00:05:25.420
So individuals and
interaction over process and tools, right?

95
00:05:25.420 --> 00:05:26.612
In the traditional and

96
00:05:26.612 --> 00:05:30.810
lean environments you might be
looking more at the process and tools.

97
00:05:30.810 --> 00:05:35.710
If you’re in the agile environment,
working software and what that means

98
00:05:35.710 --> 00:05:38.768
is that you might be developed in
your software as you go along,

99
00:05:38.768 --> 00:05:41.140
you're in the execution stage, right?

100
00:05:41.140 --> 00:05:44.884
In traditional and lean project management
there's more of a tendency to have

101
00:05:44.884 --> 00:05:47.892
complete documentation before
you start rolling things out so

102
00:05:47.892 --> 00:05:49.381
that's another difference.

103
00:05:49.381 --> 00:05:53.878
Customer collaboration as opposed
to contract negotiation so

104
00:05:53.878 --> 00:05:56.336
if I'm in an agile environment and

105
00:05:56.336 --> 00:06:02.060
I'm executing I might be looking at
more face-to-face with the customer.

106
00:06:02.060 --> 00:06:05.970
As I'm actually developing,
as I'm actually doing that project,

107
00:06:05.970 --> 00:06:09.810
I might be having more interface
with the customer than normal.

108
00:06:09.810 --> 00:06:13.790
On the lean and traditional side,
it's a little bit more about contract

109
00:06:13.790 --> 00:06:17.570
negotiations and what did my contract
say I was gonna do for that customer?

110
00:06:17.570 --> 00:06:18.310
And then finally,

111
00:06:18.310 --> 00:06:23.090
responding to change in a flexible
way as opposed to following a plan.

112
00:06:23.090 --> 00:06:26.820
Now, we're talking about Lean and
Agile project management and

113
00:06:26.820 --> 00:06:31.730
the reason why I'm bringing this up in
the execution phase is that if we have

114
00:06:31.730 --> 00:06:36.260
movement in one way or the other, that
might be something that we're considering.

115
00:06:36.260 --> 00:06:40.810
I don't particularly see these
things as being mutually exclusive.

116
00:06:40.810 --> 00:06:42.950
I think we can have
customer collaboration, for

117
00:06:42.950 --> 00:06:46.800
example, and
still honor our contract negotiations.

118
00:06:46.800 --> 00:06:49.113
So if you find yourself, no pun intended,

119
00:06:49.113 --> 00:06:53.100
leaning more towards one than the other
in execution, to be a good lean and

120
00:06:53.100 --> 00:06:57.306
agile project manager, I think you need
to consider both sides of the story.

121
00:06:59.453 --> 00:07:01.760
So, things to remember in execute.

122
00:07:01.760 --> 00:07:03.060
These are big things.

123
00:07:03.060 --> 00:07:07.903
The first thing is that in selection and
planning you may be incredibly busy,

124
00:07:07.903 --> 00:07:10.286
you may be burning that midnight oil,

125
00:07:10.286 --> 00:07:15.310
but there's an increased expectation
on you when you start executing.

126
00:07:15.310 --> 00:07:19.370
So even as a project manager or
scrum master you may have in the scrum

127
00:07:19.370 --> 00:07:23.880
master role,
just at everything you possibly could,

128
00:07:23.880 --> 00:07:27.650
to satisfy your employer and
the people in your environment.

129
00:07:27.650 --> 00:07:28.670
But now suddenly,

130
00:07:28.670 --> 00:07:32.180
Azure executing this project,
there's just more expectations on you.

131
00:07:32.180 --> 00:07:34.510
You need to keep your energy level up.

132
00:07:34.510 --> 00:07:38.690
And a lean and agile environment,
we believe that less is more.

133
00:07:38.690 --> 00:07:42.070
So a lot of you have been in environments,
especially in IT,

134
00:07:42.070 --> 00:07:45.370
where you think, if I just put in
those extra two or three hours.

135
00:07:45.370 --> 00:07:48.140
There's been several
studies done recently,

136
00:07:48.140 --> 00:07:51.950
that says that diminishing
returns is a real thing.

137
00:07:51.950 --> 00:07:56.090
And that it's important that if you're
working in this execution mode,

138
00:07:56.090 --> 00:07:59.310
it is important to get out and
get air, and exercise, and

139
00:07:59.310 --> 00:08:02.990
breathe, and meditate, and
do all of those things to do a good job.

140
00:08:02.990 --> 00:08:06.590
The other thing that you need to remember
is that there's an increased work

141
00:08:06.590 --> 00:08:08.090
pressure on your team.

142
00:08:08.090 --> 00:08:12.020
The same people that were with you
in select and with you in planning,

143
00:08:12.020 --> 00:08:15.660
now all of a sudden they're
having to do stuff.

144
00:08:15.660 --> 00:08:19.360
And generally speaking, they're doing
stuff in conjunction with tons of

145
00:08:19.360 --> 00:08:21.800
other personal and
other business projects.

146
00:08:21.800 --> 00:08:26.350
So you're in execution,
the lean and agile approach

147
00:08:26.350 --> 00:08:31.640
to project execution is to stay
cognizant of the people on your team.

148
00:08:31.640 --> 00:08:34.810
To respect the people on your team and
this is huge because in traditional

149
00:08:34.810 --> 00:08:38.880
project management, no one's ever
gonna say don't respect your team but

150
00:08:38.880 --> 00:08:42.320
there is a very strong push.

151
00:08:42.320 --> 00:08:44.940
Get to the next task,
get to the next task, right?

152
00:08:44.940 --> 00:08:48.440
And lean on agile project management,
we're saying you know what, no,

153
00:08:48.440 --> 00:08:51.660
stop, take lunch, breath, meditate,

154
00:08:51.660 --> 00:08:55.880
know that the people are under
pressure that is just not normal.

155
00:08:57.500 --> 00:09:02.370
So when we're in execution,
another lean and agile thinking

156
00:09:02.370 --> 00:09:07.160
is that there are teaming issues and
when you're building your project plan,

157
00:09:07.160 --> 00:09:11.430
you don't wanna build it so tight that
you can't get together with your team.

158
00:09:11.430 --> 00:09:15.540
So even if you're not gonna
go to that daily scrum,

159
00:09:15.540 --> 00:09:20.230
just kind of keep in mind if you
wanna execute in a fluid, good way,

160
00:09:20.230 --> 00:09:23.360
then what you're wanting to do is make
sure that you have time for your team.

161
00:09:23.360 --> 00:09:24.900
That there is that face-to-face,

162
00:09:24.900 --> 00:09:28.580
even if you don't go all the way to
where you're meeting with them everyday.

163
00:09:28.580 --> 00:09:30.180
Be sure that you build that in.

164
00:09:30.180 --> 00:09:32.700
>> So,
I have a really interesting point here.

165
00:09:32.700 --> 00:09:33.420
>> Okay.
>> Well, this is

166
00:09:33.420 --> 00:09:35.670
interesting to me because
I get to go see a movie.

167
00:09:35.670 --> 00:09:36.910
>> Yeah.
>> And so

168
00:09:36.910 --> 00:09:41.460
the owner of ITProTV is taking us,
everyone,

169
00:09:41.460 --> 00:09:44.640
to the movies next Tuesday including
our family or whoever we want to bring.

170
00:09:44.640 --> 00:09:45.820
>> That's really great.

171
00:09:45.820 --> 00:09:50.372
>> Yeah, just having that extra
team building fun kind of exercise,

172
00:09:50.372 --> 00:09:54.782
it really brings and boosts morale,
I think it's a great idea.

173
00:09:54.782 --> 00:09:57.807
>> I think what's so cool about it
is that even though, like I said,

174
00:09:57.807 --> 00:10:01.330
traditional project management
isn't gonna say it's a bad idea.

175
00:10:01.330 --> 00:10:03.800
It's just not part of
its body of knowledge.

176
00:10:03.800 --> 00:10:04.640
Where as a lean and

177
00:10:04.640 --> 00:10:09.010
agile project manager you're saying our
people are just as important as the work.

178
00:10:09.010 --> 00:10:10.740
And I just love that part.

179
00:10:10.740 --> 00:10:16.380
Another thing that you want to think about
in execution is called Level Scheduling.

180
00:10:16.380 --> 00:10:19.050
And Level Scheduling
also has this Heijunka.

181
00:10:19.050 --> 00:10:20.575
>> Don't ask me to pronounce it.

182
00:10:20.575 --> 00:10:22.400
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's a Japanese word, but

183
00:10:22.400 --> 00:10:27.415
the deal is, that when you're executing I
think the take away that lean and agile

184
00:10:27.415 --> 00:10:31.415
gives you is make sure there isn't one
person on your team that has all the work.

185
00:10:31.415 --> 00:10:33.335
>> And how do you pronounce that?

186
00:10:33.335 --> 00:10:34.150
>> Heijunka.

187
00:10:34.150 --> 00:10:34.945
>> Okay.

188
00:10:34.945 --> 00:10:35.793
>> I'm pretty sure.

189
00:10:35.793 --> 00:10:39.090
>> Okay [LAUGH]
>> So, when we're teaching just Lean,

190
00:10:39.090 --> 00:10:44.410
because we also do SST global solutions
also just teaching Lean training and

191
00:10:44.410 --> 00:10:47.550
we have to all go back and
practice all those Japanese words.

192
00:10:47.550 --> 00:10:51.760
But the concept that I want you to
take away with you is that when you

193
00:10:51.760 --> 00:10:57.110
are executing just make
sure that it's level.

194
00:10:57.110 --> 00:11:00.680
That no one has the bulk of the work or,
if they have the bulk of the work,

195
00:11:00.680 --> 00:11:05.940
that you have work arounds where they
have time off to compensate for that.

196
00:11:05.940 --> 00:11:07.230
And that happens a lot.

197
00:11:07.230 --> 00:11:10.400
I mean, it happens in our
religious environments, and

198
00:11:10.400 --> 00:11:13.050
our homeowner's associations, and our PTA.

199
00:11:13.050 --> 00:11:15.860
Where there's that quarter of a people
that are doing all the work [LAUGH].

200
00:11:15.860 --> 00:11:16.960
>> Right.
>> And so

201
00:11:16.960 --> 00:11:19.700
you just, resource leveling is
just making sure it's there.

202
00:11:19.700 --> 00:11:22.800
>> And kind of by breaking it down
into the teams that we spoke about,

203
00:11:22.800 --> 00:11:25.870
we kind of are dividing that
workload up amongst the teams.

204
00:11:25.870 --> 00:11:29.580
And then the teams, they've pledged
their allegiance to their team, right?

205
00:11:29.580 --> 00:11:31.030
>> Exactly.
>> So they're saying,

206
00:11:31.030 --> 00:11:34.430
if you don't get this test done,
I'm gonna stay here

207
00:11:34.430 --> 00:11:37.210
until it's finished to help you so
that we can offset that workload.

208
00:11:38.600 --> 00:11:40.650
>> Exactly, and

209
00:11:40.650 --> 00:11:45.360
I want you to also remember a concept
called takt time when you're executing.

210
00:11:45.360 --> 00:11:49.260
Now, in a perfect world you would have
done this in planning, but sometimes when

211
00:11:49.260 --> 00:11:54.270
you start executing you realize that
you haven't thought this through.

212
00:11:54.270 --> 00:11:58.570
So Takt Time is just the customer demand.

213
00:11:58.570 --> 00:12:02.900
So in your case as a project manager,
the customer might be your boss, right.

214
00:12:02.900 --> 00:12:06.330
Your boss expects a certain thing
to happen at a certain time.

215
00:12:06.330 --> 00:12:09.580
So Takt Time is a way of calculating, and

216
00:12:09.580 --> 00:12:14.000
those formulas are on the student page,
or in your student package, rather.

217
00:12:14.000 --> 00:12:18.570
Takt time is a way of calculating how fast
you have to work to meet that demand.

218
00:12:18.570 --> 00:12:21.020
And like I said, in the planning stage,

219
00:12:21.020 --> 00:12:23.180
that's something to think
about if you think about it.

220
00:12:23.180 --> 00:12:27.020
But sometimes you get into execution,
and you realize, my goodness,

221
00:12:27.020 --> 00:12:29.210
this task can't meet the demand.

222
00:12:29.210 --> 00:12:33.720
So, that you sometimes have to step
back in execution and do that.

223
00:12:33.720 --> 00:12:36.930
Then I just wanna kind of
remind you that execution

224
00:12:36.930 --> 00:12:39.997
in traditional verses Agile environments.

225
00:12:39.997 --> 00:12:44.460
Execution in the project life cycle
if you're following mostly lean, or

226
00:12:44.460 --> 00:12:47.620
mostly traditional you're
executing everything.

227
00:12:47.620 --> 00:12:49.320
You're going cradle to grave.

228
00:12:49.320 --> 00:12:51.730
You're looking at your WBS,
that's what you're doing.

229
00:12:51.730 --> 00:12:57.200
In the agile environment, sometimes you're
executing in two week chunks, right?

230
00:12:57.200 --> 00:12:59.500
And then you're having
those daily meetings,

231
00:12:59.500 --> 00:13:03.020
those two week chunks are subject to
something called a burn down chart,

232
00:13:03.020 --> 00:13:07.010
whereas the traditional project management
where I'm executing cradle to grave

233
00:13:07.010 --> 00:13:11.570
the whole projects over I'm just
knocking off those WBSs, right?

234
00:13:11.570 --> 00:13:12.870
Everything that's on there.

235
00:13:12.870 --> 00:13:16.220
But in the Agile environment,
I'm burning that down.

236
00:13:16.220 --> 00:13:21.000
And then I kinda keep in mind that in
the execution stage, if you're working in

237
00:13:21.000 --> 00:13:25.490
an Agile environment, your job as a
project manager is a little bit different.

238
00:13:25.490 --> 00:13:29.320
We mentioned that in the earlier
sessions in this Lean and

239
00:13:29.320 --> 00:13:32.400
Agile project management program.

240
00:13:32.400 --> 00:13:36.320
But in the Agile environments the scrum
master's rule is really to kinda

241
00:13:36.320 --> 00:13:39.471
remove obstacles and
make sure things are out of the way and

242
00:13:39.471 --> 00:13:42.762
that everyone can do the job
that they say they're gonna do.

243
00:13:42.762 --> 00:13:47.250
Whereas in the traditional project
management when you're in the execution

244
00:13:47.250 --> 00:13:51.873
mode you're going around checking to
make sure everyone is doing what they're

245
00:13:51.873 --> 00:13:53.199
supposed to be doing.

246
00:13:53.199 --> 00:13:57.419
So, the other thing to remember,
and I kind of already said this but

247
00:13:57.419 --> 00:13:59.350
I'll just reiterate it.

248
00:13:59.350 --> 00:14:04.869
The work breakdown structure is looking
at point 1.2 and then 1.3 and 1.3.3.

249
00:14:04.869 --> 00:14:06.930
I'm gonna do these tasks.

250
00:14:06.930 --> 00:14:12.820
In the work breakdown structure in the
planning phase sometimes you don't realize

251
00:14:12.820 --> 00:14:15.610
that some of these tasks
are contingent on other tasks and

252
00:14:15.610 --> 00:14:17.340
those are called dependencies.

253
00:14:17.340 --> 00:14:21.770
So you want it a lot for the dependencies
as much as possible in planning but

254
00:14:21.770 --> 00:14:25.030
once again you might get into
the work breakdown structure and

255
00:14:25.030 --> 00:14:27.920
realize, my goodness,
this should have been done before that.

256
00:14:27.920 --> 00:14:29.140
And that's where that PERT chart,

257
00:14:29.140 --> 00:14:32.370
that we looked at when we first
came into this session, is handy.

258
00:14:32.370 --> 00:14:34.460
But let's say you didn't do that.

259
00:14:34.460 --> 00:14:39.700
Just kind of keep in mind that sometimes
your goal, in a work breakdown structure,

260
00:14:39.700 --> 00:14:42.940
is kinda hierarchical and
I'm just gonna knock these things off.

261
00:14:42.940 --> 00:14:48.470
Whereas if I'm in execution in
a more of an Agile environment,

262
00:14:48.470 --> 00:14:50.080
then I'm looking at iterations.

263
00:14:50.080 --> 00:14:51.271
I'm looking at those sprints.

264
00:14:53.700 --> 00:14:58.511
And sprints, once again, are two to
four week cycles and during that cycle,

265
00:14:58.511 --> 00:15:01.560
nothing is supposed to
change in that activity.

266
00:15:01.560 --> 00:15:05.010
Everyone has just agreed this is the body
of work that I'm going to take on for

267
00:15:05.010 --> 00:15:06.450
the next two weeks.

268
00:15:06.450 --> 00:15:09.800
So I think that's really pretty much
what I had to tell you about execution.

269
00:15:11.005 --> 00:15:16.215
It goes more smoothly the more
time you spend in planning.

270
00:15:16.215 --> 00:15:19.535
But you don't want to get caught,
we mentioned this in another session,

271
00:15:19.535 --> 00:15:21.435
you don't want to get caught
where you're planning so

272
00:15:21.435 --> 00:15:23.785
long you don't have time to execute.

273
00:15:23.785 --> 00:15:25.295
>> Well, thank you for that.

274
00:15:25.295 --> 00:15:28.405
And now we can go ahead and
take the information we learned,

275
00:15:28.405 --> 00:15:31.935
apply it in our daily lives or if you
guys are just studying for the exam.

276
00:15:31.935 --> 00:15:37.770
We also looked at aspects of how it
relates to traditional project management,

277
00:15:37.770 --> 00:15:39.990
to the newer agile thinking.

278
00:15:39.990 --> 00:15:41.010
So thank you for that.

279
00:15:41.010 --> 00:15:43.620
And I appreciate you guys for
staying and watching.

280
00:15:43.620 --> 00:15:47.670
But we do have another phase to cover,
we still have our closeout phase.

281
00:15:47.670 --> 00:15:49.215
So don't go anywhere just yet.

282
00:15:49.215 --> 00:15:51.320
We have some really great Lean and

283
00:15:51.320 --> 00:15:54.360
Agile project management
information headed your way.

284
00:15:54.360 --> 00:15:57.760
So I'm gonna go ahead and
sign off as your show host Cherokee Boose.

285
00:15:57.760 --> 00:16:01.190
>> And this is Dr. Tara Vanzant Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

286
00:16:01.190 --> 00:16:03.779
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

287
00:16:03.779 --> 00:16:09.613
[MUSIC]

288
00:16:09.613 --> 00:16:12.491
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose continue covering the Lean and Agile Project Management Project Life Cycle. Particularly, they explore the last phase, Close-Out. This show encompasses all recommended post implementation project activities.
episodes.title: Session 9
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.065
Welcome to ITProTV I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.065 --> 00:00:06.863
[CROSSTALK]
You're

3
00:00:06.863 --> 00:00:11.962
watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.962 --> 00:00:16.080
>> Welcome to your Lean and
Agile Project Management series.

5
00:00:16.080 --> 00:00:17.620
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:18.802 --> 00:00:21.740
In this segment we will
be looking at the last

7
00:00:21.740 --> 00:00:26.190
phase within our project management life
cycle, which is the close-out phase.

8
00:00:26.190 --> 00:00:27.769
And to explain that to us today,

9
00:00:27.769 --> 00:00:30.590
we have Doctor Doctor Terra Vanzant-Stern
in studios.

10
00:00:30.590 --> 00:00:32.400
So thank you for being here today Doctor.

11
00:00:32.400 --> 00:00:33.480
>> Thank you, Cherokee.

12
00:00:33.480 --> 00:00:34.910
I appreciate being here.

13
00:00:34.910 --> 00:00:36.080
>> So what are we gonna be looking at?

14
00:00:36.080 --> 00:00:39.960
What are some really important key
concepts within that closeout phase to,

15
00:00:39.960 --> 00:00:42.170
well, wrap up a project?

16
00:00:42.170 --> 00:00:46.290
>> Well this is the beautiful thing
about the project life cycle.

17
00:00:46.290 --> 00:00:50.480
If you do everything you're supposed
to do in those first three phases,

18
00:00:50.480 --> 00:00:52.820
close out is really simple.

19
00:00:52.820 --> 00:00:54.510
So I'd like to bring up my slide deck.

20
00:00:55.890 --> 00:01:00.410
And as a reminder, we're working from
the Lean and Project Management deck.

21
00:01:00.410 --> 00:01:04.720
We're working from the project life
cycle and this is a composite model.

22
00:01:04.720 --> 00:01:08.093
Once again, just as a reminder the PMBOK,

23
00:01:08.093 --> 00:01:12.830
the PRINCE2 and the new ISO standard for
project management

24
00:01:12.830 --> 00:01:16.857
all have different versions of this
project management life cycle.

25
00:01:16.857 --> 00:01:20.155
And at some of the universities now,
they've expanded it.

26
00:01:20.155 --> 00:01:23.445
We thought it was more lean and
agile to kind of condense it, and

27
00:01:23.445 --> 00:01:27.075
put it into the four major categories
of what you're working on.

28
00:01:27.075 --> 00:01:30.205
So, we're now in the close-out phase, and

29
00:01:30.205 --> 00:01:33.830
notice the very first thing we
put on close-out was celebrate.

30
00:01:33.830 --> 00:01:39.330
And you want to get your team feedback,
and recommendations for further actions.

31
00:01:39.330 --> 00:01:42.650
If you do the PLC the way
we're suggesting it, and

32
00:01:42.650 --> 00:01:45.800
lean in agile project management,
close-out.

33
00:01:45.800 --> 00:01:48.880
You're just really doing
a lot of documentation.

34
00:01:48.880 --> 00:01:52.712
So as far as in time frame,
I know I keep asking these questions.

35
00:01:52.712 --> 00:01:58.370
But would be safe to say it's really
good to go through a lot of these steps,

36
00:01:58.370 --> 00:02:01.160
will that information is
still fresh in your head and

37
00:02:01.160 --> 00:02:05.040
you can Identify anything that your
team did exceptionally well, and

38
00:02:05.040 --> 00:02:08.680
then kind of point out things that maybe
you didn't do so well, but while it's

39
00:02:08.680 --> 00:02:12.250
still fresh so people don't forget about
everything that you've just accomplished.

40
00:02:12.250 --> 00:02:15.410
>> That's a very good point
Cherokee because my suggestion

41
00:02:15.410 --> 00:02:17.670
is to start logging this in execute.

42
00:02:17.670 --> 00:02:21.356
And so then when you get to the close-out
stage, you're really just writing it up.

43
00:02:21.356 --> 00:02:25.020
That's what we want to make
close out phase the fun phase.

44
00:02:25.020 --> 00:02:27.100
Where you are celebrating and
you are looking for

45
00:02:27.100 --> 00:02:29.470
new work and
you are doing really cool new things.

46
00:02:29.470 --> 00:02:32.231
So, if you're journaling as
you go along and execute,

47
00:02:32.231 --> 00:02:34.071
close out is going to be very simple.

48
00:02:34.071 --> 00:02:38.890
But some of the things we wanted to
talk about because it is a lean and

49
00:02:38.890 --> 00:02:44.458
agile project is to introduce
the concept of continuous improvement.

50
00:02:44.458 --> 00:02:48.390
So my project's over and in a traditional
project management environment,

51
00:02:48.390 --> 00:02:51.300
I'm done, I just go and
get another project.

52
00:02:51.300 --> 00:02:55.656
One of the things that we learned from
process improvement is that we might wanna

53
00:02:55.656 --> 00:02:59.882
make sure that that project, that simple
project has some sustainability or

54
00:02:59.882 --> 00:03:03.473
maybe that people can build on that for
continuous improvement.

55
00:03:03.473 --> 00:03:07.592
So continuous improvement is sort of
more than a concept than anything else.

56
00:03:07.592 --> 00:03:12.389
I wanna make sure I do my best practices,
but I'm looking for

57
00:03:12.389 --> 00:03:17.659
opportunities, as I close out this
project, to make other things

58
00:03:17.659 --> 00:03:22.670
in my environment better,
faster, and most cost effective.

59
00:03:22.670 --> 00:03:27.390
The other concept in lean and
agile project management that

60
00:03:27.390 --> 00:03:32.570
often is not there in traditional project
management is the idea of standard work.

61
00:03:32.570 --> 00:03:36.260
As I'm going through my executables,
from time to time,

62
00:03:36.260 --> 00:03:40.990
I might notice a repeatable thing and
it might be just with that project but

63
00:03:40.990 --> 00:03:44.070
it could be something that
people do in other projects.

64
00:03:44.070 --> 00:03:46.960
>> Integrated into even other departments,
as well?

65
00:03:46.960 --> 00:03:48.020
>> Absolutely.

66
00:03:48.020 --> 00:03:50.740
And so I want to take the time
to actually record my actions.

67
00:03:50.740 --> 00:03:54.470
These are the steps that I took, so
that if someone wants to do it again,

68
00:03:54.470 --> 00:03:55.830
it's a repeatable.

69
00:03:55.830 --> 00:03:57.100
And that's called standard work.

70
00:03:57.100 --> 00:03:59.710
Now sometimes you do that
repeatable work process and

71
00:03:59.710 --> 00:04:03.480
you find something that's even better,
so then you're gonna go ahead and

72
00:04:03.480 --> 00:04:06.700
you're going to rewrite your
standard work to include that.

73
00:04:06.700 --> 00:04:10.770
And then finally, 5S,
which is a physical organization

74
00:04:10.770 --> 00:04:14.760
model to help us be more organized for
our next project.

75
00:04:14.760 --> 00:04:18.250
Sometimes people do 5S before they
even get started on the project,

76
00:04:18.250 --> 00:04:21.480
because the environment is such
a mess they can't even think.

77
00:04:21.480 --> 00:04:22.790
But we're putting it at the end.

78
00:04:22.790 --> 00:04:27.210
We're saying this is an example of
not only continuous improvement, but

79
00:04:27.210 --> 00:04:30.620
sometimes you have to be at the end
of the project before you know how to

80
